Finite Element Methods for the
Laplace-Beltrami Operator

Andrea Bonito Department of Mathematics, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA; bonito@math.tamu.edu ,  Alan Demlow Department of Mathematics, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA; demlow@math.tamu.edu  and  Ricardo H. Nochetto University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, USA; rhn@math.umd.edu
(Date: September 18, 2025)
Abstract.

Partial differential equations posed on surfaces arise in a number of applications. In this survey we describe three popular finite element methods for approximating solutions to the Laplace-Beltrami problem posed on an n-dimensional surface γ embedded in ℝn+1: the parametric, trace, and narrow band methods. The parametric method entails constructing an approximating polyhedral surface Γ whose faces comprise the finite element triangulation. The finite element method is then posed over the approximate surface Γ in a manner very similar to standard FEM on Euclidean domains. In the trace method it is assumed that the given surface γ is embedded in an n+1-dimensional domain Ω which has itself been triangulated. An n-dimensional approximate surface Γ is then constructed roughly speaking by interpolating γ over the triangulation of Ω, and the finite element space over Γ consists of the trace (restriction) of a standard finite element space on Ω to Γ. In the narrow band method the PDE posed on the surface is extended to a triangulated n+1-dimensional band about γ whose width is proportional to the diameter of elements in the triangulation. In all cases we provide optimal a priori error estimates for the lowest-order finite element methods, and we also present a posteriori error estimates for the parametric and trace methods. Our presentation focuses especially on the relationship between the regularity of the surface γ, which is never assumed better than of class C2, the manner in which γ is represented in theory and practice, and the properties of the resulting methods.

Key words and phrases:
Surface partial differential equations, Laplace-Beltrami operator, surface finite element methods, parametric finite element methods, trace finite element methods, narrow band finite element methods, a-priori and a-posteriori error estimates.

RHN is partially supported by NSF grant DMS–1411808.

1. Introduction

Partial differential equations (PDEs) posed on surfaces play an important role in many domains of pure and applied mathematics, including geometry, modeling of materials, fluid flow, and image and shape processing. The numerical approximation of such surface PDEs is both practically important and the source of many mathematically rich problems.

We consider a closed, compact and orientable surface γ in ℝn+1 of co-dimension 1. The Laplace-Beltrami operator −Δγ, which acts as a generalization of the standard Euclidean Laplace operator, plays a central role in both static and time-dependent surface PDE models arising in a wide range of applications. Because of this a wide variety of numerical methods have been developed for the Laplace-Beltrami equation

−Δγ⁢u~=f~,

where f~ is a given forcing function satisfying ∫γf~=0. In this article we first lay out some important notions from differential geometry. We then describe three important classes of finite element methods (FEMs) for the Laplace-Beltrami problem: the parametric method, the trace method, and the narrow band method. In all three cases we focus on the simplest case of piecewise linear finite element spaces and give an in-depth discussion of the effects of geometry on error behavior.

The parametric finite element method was introduced in 1988 by Dziuk [Dzi88], with some important related techniques appearing in earlier works on boundary element methods [Néd76, Ben84]. This method is the simplest of the many FEM that have been developed for solving the Laplace-Beltrami problem. The given PDE is first written in weak form as: Find u~∈H1⁢(γ) such that ∫γu~=0 and

a⁢(u~,\tv~):=∫γ∇γu~⋅∇γ\tv~=∫γf~⁢\tv~∀\tv~∈H1⁢(γ).

Here H1⁢(γ) is the set of functions \tv~ in L2⁢(Ω) whose tangential gradient ∇γ\tv~∈[L2⁢(γ)]n+1. The continuous surface γ is approximated by a polyhedral surface Γ whose faces serve as a finite element mesh, and the finite element space \V is made of continuous piecewise linear functions over Γ. The finite element method then consists of finding U∈\V such that

A⁢(U,V)=∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇ΓV=∫γF⁢V∀V∈\V,

where F is a suitable approximation (lift) of f defined on Γ. In its conception and implementation, the resulting method is very similar to canonical FEM for solving Poisson’s problem on Euclidean domains. To quote Dziuk, “…the numerical scheme is just the same as in a plane-two dimensional problem. The only difference is that in our case the computer has to memorize three-dimensional nodes instead of two-dimensional ones.” [Dzi88, p. 143]. The strategy underlying parametric surface finite element methods –direct translation of FEM on Euclidean spaces to triangulated surfaces– has subsequently been applied to a variety of methods. These include higher-order standard Lagrange methods [Dem09], various types of discontinuous Galerkin methods [ADM+15, DMS13, CD16], and mixed methods in classical, hybridized, and finite element exterior calculus formulations [Ben84, HS12, CD16, FFF16]. A posteriori error estimation and adaptivity have been studied in [DD07, WCH10, BCMN13, DM16, BCM+16, BD19]. Finally, we refer to the survey article [DE13].

In many applications in which surface PDEs are to be solved, a background volume (bulk) mesh is already present. A paradigm example is two-phase fluid flow, in which effects on the interface between the two phases such as surface tension are coupled with standard equations of fluid dynamics on the bulk. In these cases it is advantageous to utilize the background volume mesh to solve surface PDEs instead of independently meshing γ. This is especially the case when γ is evolving, since the meshes needed for the parametric method typically distort as γ changes and periodic remeshing is thus necessary. The trace and narrow band methods both employ background bulk meshes in order to solve surface PDEs.

Trace (or cut) FEMs for the Laplace-Beltrami problem were first introduced in [ORG09]. In this method an approximating surface is constructed as in the parametric method, but using a different approach. An implicit representation of γ as the level set of some function ϕ is used, that is, it is assumed that

γ={x∈ℝn+1:ϕ⁢(x)=0}.

A discrete surface Γ is then defined as the zero level set of an interpolant of ϕ on the background mesh, and the finite element space is taken to be the trace of the bulk finite element space on Γ. The FEM is posed and solved on Γ as in the parametric method. Note that the finite element space in the trace method consists of continuous piecewise linear functions over the faces of Γ. However, because the faces of Γ are arbitrary intersections of n-dimensional hyperplanes with n+1-simplices, they are not shape regular, and in particular may either fail to satisfy a minimum angle condition or be much smaller than the bulk simplices from which they are derived. Counter to natural intuition about the quality of a finite element method posed on such a mesh, the trace method satisfies optimal error bounds and works well in practice. In addition to the basic analysis of piecewise linear methods that we present below, the literature on trace methods for the Laplace-Beltrami problem includes study of matrix properties [OR10], adaptive versions [DO12, CO15], and extensions to higher-order [Reu15, GR16, GLR18], stabilized [BHL15, BHL+16], and discontinuous Galerkin [BHLM17] methods. We refer to the recent survey article [OR17].

Narrow band methods also employ a bulk mesh in order to approximate surface PDEs, but extend a surface PDE to the bulk instead of restricting a bulk finite element space to a surface. This idea appeared first in [BCOS01] and is based on an extension of the PDE into a tubular neighborhood 𝒩⁢(δ) of width 2⁢δ about γ that reads

L⁢(uδ)=−div⁢((I−∇d⊗∇d)⁢∇uδ)+uδ=fδ.

Here fδ is an extension of \wf from γ to 𝒩⁢(δ) and d is the distance function γ. The latter is chosen for simplicity over a generic level set function ϕ to represent γ throughout this article. Because ∇d is the unit outward normal to γ, the coefficient matrix I−∇d⊗∇d is degenerate in the direction normal to γ, and the operator L is thus elliptic but degenerate. We emphasize that in contrast to most previous literature on narrow band FEM we do not include a zero order term in our presentation, thereby adding extra difficulty due to the need to account for the non-trivial kernel of L on closed surfaces. In narrow band FEMs, the Galerkin approximations to uδ are posed over a discrete approximation 𝒩h⁢(δ) to the narrow band 𝒩⁢(δ). Related methods that involve extending surface PDEs to bulk domains include the closest point method [RM08].

Narrow-band unfitted finite element methods have been proposed and analyzed by different authors. In [Bur09], the aforementioned degenerate extension is shown to be well posed and error bounds in the weighted bulk energy norm are derived. Subsequently, error estimates in the H1⁢(γ) norm are obtained in [DDEH10] for the lower order method. An alternate nondegenerate extension L⁢(uδ)=−Δ⁢uδ+uδ is then proposed in [DER14] leading to optimal H1⁢(γ) and also L2⁢(γ) error estimates for the lower order method when fδ is (or is close to) the constant normal extension of f~. Independently, higher order methods are proposed and analyzed in [OS16] using the extension

L⁢(uδ)=−div⁢(μ⁢(I−d⁢D2⁢d)−2⁢∇uδ)+uδ,

with μ:=det(I−d⁢D2⁢d) and fδ the constant normal extension of f~. Note also that the associated FEM requires a sufficiently accurate approximation of D2⁢d (if not known explicitly). For the case of lowest order (piecewise linear) finite element spaces, it is enough to approximate D2⁢d with zero and thereby retrieve the discrete formulation in [DER14].

In the construction of all three FEMs above, we incur on variational crimes (consistency errors) due to the approximation of geometry. In the parametric and trace methods, these errors arise because the finite element method is posed over a discrete approximation Γ to γ, thereby leading to different bilinear forms (a and A) used to compute the continuous and finite element solutions (\wu and U). In the narrow band method the finite element equations are posed over a discrete narrow band 𝒩h⁢(δ) instead of over the domain 𝒩⁢(δ) on which the extended solution uδ is defined. This again entails the use of different bilinear forms in the definitions of the continuous and discrete solutions. A core problem in surface FEMs is understanding and controlling these errors, which are typically called geometric consistency errors or geometric errors. In order to analyze these errors, it is necessary to define a map \bP:Γ→γ and then compare a⁢(\tv~,w~) with A⁢(\tv~∘\bP,w~∘\bP) for given functions \tv~,w~∈H1⁢(γ). This is done via a change of variables argument for the map \bP. There may be several competing demands of both theoretical and practical nature that come into play when choosing the map \bP, and a main focus of this article is to elucidate how this choice affects analysis and implementation of surface FEMs.

The canonical choice of the map \bP is defined via the so-called signed distance function d:𝒩→γ. The distance function is defined on a tubular neighborhood 𝒩 of γ and is of the same regularity class as γ provided that γ is at least C2 and 𝒩 is sufficiently narrow. In such a case, the map (also called distance-lift or orthogonal closest point projection)

\bPd⁢(\bx):=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈𝒩

is well defined and is of class C1. The maps d and \bPd play a crucial role in analyzing and in some cases defining the numerical algorithms presented below. In particular, the distance function is a critical tool in proving error estimates that are of optimal order with respect to geometric consistency errors. When a generic map \bP:Γ→γ is instead used to analyze surface FEMs, the predicted behavior of geometric errors is of one order less than is seen in practice and also than may be proved using the closest point projection. More precisely, when quasi-uniform meshes of size h are used with affine surface approximations in the parametric and trace methods, arguments which use special properties of the closest point projection predict an O⁢(h2) geometric errors, and these are in fact observed in practice. On the other hand, standard proofs employing a generic map \bP instead of the distance function map \bPd predict only order h geometric errors. This increase in convergence order due to the properties of the closest point projection may be viewed as a superconvergence effect.

Reliance on \bPd may however also constitute a serious drawback for several reasons. First, \bPd has a closed form expression only for the sphere and torus, so it is in general not directly available to the user. We thus discuss how to use the distance function only as a theoretical tool for the parametric FEM and yet retain the superconvergence properties of \bPd. On a practical level, the user is still free to choose from a much more general class of lifts to implement an algorithm. Our presentation includes optimal a priori and a posteriori estimates in H1 and optimal a priori estimates in L2 for an algorithm whose implementation only requires access to a generic lift \bP; the latter appear to be new in the literature even for smooth surfaces. Second, if γ is merely C1,α for α<1, then the closest point projection \bPd is not uniquely defined in any neighborhood of γ. We thus also provide an analysis of parametric FEMs for γ of class C1,α that instead makes use of a generic parametric map. The price we pay is a possible order reduction of the method due to the loss of superconvergence properties of \bPd. Finally, previous proofs of optimal-order error estimates employing \bPd have required that \bPd is of class C2 and thus γ of class C3; cf. [Dzi88]. However, the solution u to the Laplace-Beltrami problem already possesses the H2 regularity needed to ensure optimal convergence of piecewise linear finite element methods when γ is of class C2. In this survey we bridge this gap by giving a novel error analysis for the three FEMs which is based exclusively on C2 regularity of d and γ, but which also preserves the superconvergence property in the geometric error. In the case of the trace and narrow band methods we achieve this by a regularization argument.

This article is organized as follows. In section 2 we introduce surface gradient, divergence and Laplace-Beltrami operators along with the signed distance function and its most relevant properties. In section 3 we quantify the geometric effects of perturbing surfaces γ of class C1,α and C2. We also present H2 extensions to a tubular neigborhood \Nd⊂𝒩 of width δ

‖u‖H2⁢(\Nd)≲δ12⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)

of functions \wu∈H2⁢(γ) provided γ is of class C2. This turns out to be essential for our later error analysis of the trace and narrow band methods for C2 surfaces. In section 4 we give a selfcontained exposition of parametric FEMs for surfaces of class C1,α and C2, including a priori and a posteriori error analyses. In section 5 we describe the trace method and conclude in section 6 with the narrow band method. Both discussions assume C2 regularity of γ.

2. Calculus on Surfaces

In this section we discuss basic concepts of differential geometry. We start in section 2.1 by describing the paramatric representaton of γ via charts. This classical point of view is critical to introduce the first fundamental form \bg, the area element q, and the unit normal \bnu of γ. We present in section 2.2 the tangential operators (gradient ∇γ, divergence divγ, and Laplace-Beltrami Δγ) as well as the Weingarten map; we also discuss H2-regularity for Δγ on surfaces γ of class C2. We introduce the distance function d in section 2.3 and derive several important properties of it; this intrinsic approach avoids parametrizations and allows for implicit representions of γ. We devote section 2.4 to the second fundamental form of γ and its principal curvatures using both parametric and intrinsic approaches.

2.1. Parametric Surfaces

We assume that γ is a closed, compact, orientable manifold of class C1,α, 0<α≤1, and co-dimension 1 in ℝn+1. It can be represented parametrically by an atlas {(𝒱i,𝒰i,\bchii)}i∈I, where the individual charts \bchii:𝒱i→𝒰i∩γ⊂ℝn+1 are isomorphisms of class C1,α compatible with the orientation of γ; the open connected sets 𝒱i⊂ℝn are the parametric domains. Unless stated otherwise, it will be often sufficient to consider a single chart and resort to a partition of the unity. We thus drop the index i for convenience. For \bx∈𝒰∩γ, we set \by:=\bchi−1⁢(\bx)∈𝒱.

Let ∂j\bchi⁢(\by) be the column vector of j-th partial derivatives of \bchi⁢(\by) for 1≤j≤n at \by∈𝒱. By definition, the rank of D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)=(∂j\bchi⁢(\by))j=1n∈ℝ(n+1)×n is n (full rank). This implies that {∂j\bchi⁢(\by)}j=1n are linearly independent and span the tangent hyperplane to γ at \bx.

The first fundamental form is the symmetric and positive definite matrix \bg∈ℝn×n defined by

(1) \bg⁢(\by):=D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)t⁢D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱.

If \bg=(gi⁢j)i,j=1n, then the components gi⁢j read

gi⁢j=∂i\bchit⁢∂j\bchi=∂i\bchi⋅∂j\bchi,

which depends on the choice of parametrization. A normal vector \bN⁢(\by) to γ at \bx can be written as \bN⁢(\by)=∑j=1n+1Aj⁢(\by)⁢\bej, where Aj:=det⁢(\bej,D⁢\bchi) and {\bej}j=1n+1 is the canonical basis of ℝn+1. In fact, since

\bN⋅∂i\bchi=∑j=1n+1\bej⋅∂i\bchi⁢det(\bej,D⁢\bchi)=det(∑j=1n+1(\bej⋅∂i\bchi)⁢\bej,D⁢\bchi)=det(∂i\bchi,D⁢\bchi)=0,

and Aj≠0 for at least one j because D⁢\bchi has rank n, we deduce that

(2) \bnu⁢(\by):=\bN⁢(\by)|\bN⁢(\by)|∀\by∈𝒱

is a well-defined unit normal vector to γ. Therefore, the matrix

\bT⁢(\by):=[D⁢\bchi⁢(\by),\bnu⁢(\by)]∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1)∀\by∈𝒱

has rank n+1 and so is invertible. We write its inverse as

\bT−1=[\bB\bvt],\bB∈ℝn×(n+1),\bv∈ℝn,

and note that

\bI(n+1)×(n+1)=\bT−1⁢\bT=[\bB⁢D⁢\bchi\bB⁢\bv\bvt⁢D⁢\bchi\bvt⁢\bnu,]

whence

\bB⁢D⁢\bchi=\bIn×n,\bvt⁢D⁢\bchi=0,\bvt⁢\bnu=1.

The last two equalities imply \bv=\bnu. Reversing the order of multiplication yields

\bI(n+1)×(n+1)=\bT⁢\bT−1=D⁢\bchi⁢\bB+\bnu⁢\bnut,

whence the projection matrix Π∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) on the tangent hyperplane to γ has the form

(3) Π:=\bI−\bnu⊗\bnu=D⁢\bchi⁢\bB.

To obtain an explicit expression for \bB note that

D⁢\bchi=(\bI−\bnu⊗\bnu)t⁢D⁢\bchi=\bBt⁢D⁢\bchit⁢D⁢\bchi=\bBt⁢\bg⇒\bB=\bg−1⁢D⁢\bchit.

This leads to the following useful expression of Π defined in (3):

(4) Π=D⁢\bchi⁢\bg−1⁢D⁢\bchit.

The area element q⁢(\by) is the ratio of the infinitesimal volume at \by∈𝒱 and area of γ at \bx=\bchi⁢(\by), namely the volume of the parallelotope in the tangent plane to γ spanned by the vectors {\bchij}j=1n:

(5) q⁢(\by):=det([\bnu⁢(\by),D⁢χ⁢(\by)])∀\by∈𝒱.

To obtain a more familiar form of q we argue as follows:

(6) q=1|N|⁢det([\bN,D⁢\bchi])=1|N|⁢det([\bN,D⁢\bchi]t⁢[\bN,D⁢\bchi])12=det\bg,

because det([\bN,D⁢\bchi]t⁢[\bN,D⁢\bchi])=|\bN|2⁢det(D⁢\bchit⁢D⁢\bchi)=|\bN|2⁢det\bg. Moreover, exploiting that |N|2=∑j=1n+1Aj⁢det([\bej,D⁢\bchi])=det([\bN,D⁢\bchi]), we deduce

(7) q=|\bN|.

An integrable function \tv:𝒱→ℝ induces an integrable function \tv~:γ→ℝ by composition \tv=\tv~∘\bchi, or equivalently \tv~⁢(\bx)=\tv⁢(\by) for all \by∈𝒱. The area element allows for integration over γ via the formula

(8) ∫γ\tv~=∫𝒱\tv⁢q∀\tv∈L1⁢(𝒱).

This definition does not depend on the parametrization: if \bchi1,\bchi2 are parametrizations of γ, then \bchi1=\bchi2∘(\bchi2−1∘\bchi1) and D⁢\bchi1=D⁢\bchi2⁢D⁢(\bchi2−1∘\bchi1) whence

q1=|det(D⁢(\bchi2−1∘\bchi1))|⁢q2⇒∫𝒱1\tv⁢q1=∫𝒱2\tv⁢q2.

2.2. Differential Operators

If a function \tv:𝒱→ℝ is of class C1, we can define the tangential (or surface) gradient of the corresponding function \tv~:γ→ℝ as a vector tangent to γ that satisfies the chain rule

(9) ∇\tv⁢(\by)=D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)t⁢∇γ\tv~⁢(\bx)∀\by∈𝒱.

Since ∇γ\tv~ is spanned by {∂j\bchi}j=1n, we get ∇γ\tv~=D⁢\bchi⁢w for some w∈ℝn whence w=\bg−1⁢∇\tv and

(10) ∇γ\tv~⁢(\bx)=D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)⁢\bg⁢(\by)−1⁢∇\tv⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱.

If \bv~=(\tv~i)i=1n+1:γ→ℝn+1 is a vector field of class C1, we define its tangential differential Dγ⁢\bv~∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) as a matrix whose i-th row is (∇γ\tv~i)t. If γ is of class C2, then the unit normal vector \bnu is of class C1 and its differential

(11) \bW⁢(\bx)=Dγ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈γ

is called the Weingarten (or shape) map of γ. In addition, the tangential divergence of \bv~ is the trace of Dγ⁢\bv~

(12) divγ⁢\bv~⁢(\bx)=trace⁢(Dγ⁢\bv~⁢(\bx))=∑i,j=1ngi⁢j⁢(\by)⁢∂i\bchi⁢(\by)⋅∂j\bv⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱,

provided \bg−1=(gi⁢j)i,j=1n. If both γ and \tv:γ→ℝ are of class C2, then the Laplace-Beltrami (or surface Laplace) operator is now defined to be

(13) Δγ⁢\tv~=1q⁢(\by)÷q⁢(\by)⁢\bg⁢(\by)−1⁢∇\tv⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱.

The following lemma shows that (13) is designed to allow integration by parts on γ, exactly as it happens in flat domains with the Laplace operator Δ.

{lemma}

[weak form of the Laplace-Beltrami operator] If φ~ is of class C1 with compact support in γ, then

(14) ∫γφ~⁢Δγ⁢\tv~=−∫γ∇γφ~⋅∇γ\tv~.
Proof.

In view of (8), which allows us to switch from γ to 𝒱 back and forth, we can write

∫γφ~⁢Δγ⁢\tv~ =∫𝒱φ÷q⁢\bg−1⁢∇\tv
=−∫𝒱∇φ⋅\bg−1⁢∇\tv⁢q
=−∫𝒱D⁢\bchi⁢\bg−1⁢∇φ⋅D⁢\bchi⁢\bg−1⁢∇\tv⁢q
=−∫γ∇γφ~⋅∇γ\tv~.

This proves (14) as desired. ∎

In view of (14), we are now in the position to introduce the weak formulation for the Laplace-Beltrami operator. We first define the space of square integrable functions on γ with vanishing mean value by

L2,#⁢(γ):={\tv~∈L2⁢(γ)|∫γ\tv~=0}

and its subspace H#1⁢(γ) containing square integrable weak derivatives defined as for example in Section 3 of [JK95] by

H#1⁢(γ):=H1⁢(γ)∩L2,#⁢(γ),H1⁢(γ):={\tv~∈L2⁢(γ)|∇(\tv~∘\bchi)∈[L2⁢(𝒱)]n}.

Our next result shows that the natural norm ‖∇γv~‖L2⁢(γ)+‖v~‖L2⁢(γ) in H#1⁢(γ) is equivalent to the semi-norm ‖∇γv~‖L2⁢(γ). The proof essentially hinges on the Peetre-Tartar Lemma [Pee66, Tar78], but we proceed with a slightly more direct proof as in [Eva98, Section 5.8.1].

{lemma}

[Poincaré-Friedrichs inequality] Let γ be a compact Lipschitz surface. There exists a constant C only depending on γ such that

(15) ‖\tv~‖L2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ)∀\tv~∈H#1⁢(γ).
Proof.

We prove by contradiction the more general estimate

(16) ‖\wv‖L2⁢(γ)≤C⁢(‖∇γ\wv‖L2⁢(γ)+|∫γ\wv|)∀\wv∈H1⁢(γ).

Suppose that there is a sequence \wvk∈H1⁢(γ) such that

‖\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)=1,‖∇γ\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)+|∫γ\wvk|→0

as k→∞. We deduce that {\wvk}k is uniformly bounded in H1⁢(γ). Since the embedding H1⁢(γ)⊂L2⁢(γ) is compact (because H1⁢(𝒱)⊂L2⁢(𝒱) is compact, see the proof of [Aub82, Theorem 2.34]), there is a Cauchy subsequence (with abuse of notation not relabeled) of {\wvk}k in L2⁢(γ). This, together with ‖∇γ\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)→0, implies that {\wvk}k is a Cauchy sequence in H1⁢(γ). Let \wv∈H1⁢(γ) be the limit of \wvk in H1⁢(γ), which yields ∇γ\wv=limk→∞∇γ\wvk=0 whence \wv is constant on γ. Moreover, ∫γ\wv=limk→∞∫γ\wvk=0 whence \tv=0. This gives rise to the contradiction 0=‖\wv‖L2⁢(γ)=limk→∞‖\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)=1, and finishes the proof. ∎

We emphasize that the Poincaré-Friedrichs constant depends on the surface γ. Later we shall consider perturbations Γ of γ and derive Poincaré-Friedrichs type estimates on Γ where the constant depends on γ provided the geometry of γ is minimally approximated by Γ. This is proved in Lemma 3.1 for Lipschitz surfaces and only requires that the L2 and H1 norms on γ and Γ are equivalent.

We will not deal explicitly with functionals in the dual space H#−1⁢(γ) of H#1⁢(γ), but occasionally need its norm for f~∈L2,#⁢(γ)

(17) ‖f~‖H#−1⁢(γ)=sup\tv~∈H#1⁢(γ)∫γf~⁢\tv~‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ).

Lemma 2.2 (Poincaré-Friedrichs inequality) implies that ‖f~‖H#−1⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖f~‖L2,#⁢(γ). The weak formulation of −Δγ⁢u~=f~ reads: for f~∈L2,#⁢(γ), seek u~∈H#1⁢(γ) so that

(18) ∫γ∇γu~⋅∇γ\tv~=∫γf~⁢\tv~∀\tv~∈H#1⁢(γ).

Since the Dirichlet bilinear form in (18) is coercive, according to Lemma 2.2, existence and uniqueness of a solution u~∈H#1⁢(γ) is a consequence of the Lax-Milgram theorem. We observe that thanks to the property f~∈L2,#⁢(γ), the solution u~∈H#1⁢(γ) satisfies

(19) ∫γ∇γu~⋅∇γ\tv~=∫γf~⁢\tv~∀\tv~∈H1⁢(γ).

It turns out that u~ exhibits the usual regularity pick-up provided γ is of class C2. {lemma}[regularity] If γ is of class C2, then there is a constant C only depending on γ such that

(20) ‖u~‖H2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

We use a localization argument to the parametric domain. We assume, without loss of generality, that the atlas {(𝒱i,𝒰i,\bchii)}i=1I satisfies the following property: there exist domains 𝒲i such that 𝒲¯i⊂𝒰i and {𝒲i}i=1I is still a covering of γ. Let now {ψ~i}i=1I be a C2 partition of unity associated with the covering {𝒲i}i=1I. The functions ui=u⁢ψi satisfy

Δγu~i=ψ~if~+2∇γu~⋅∇γψ~i+\wuΔγψ~i=:g~i.

In light of the estimate ‖∇γu~‖L2⁢(γ)≤‖f~‖H#−1⁢(γ) and (15) we deduce that ‖g~i‖L2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ∩𝒰i). Recalling (13) we can rewrite Δγ⁢ui in the parametric domain 𝒱i as

÷qi(\by)\bgi(\by)−1∇u(\by)=qi(y)g~i(\bchi(\by))∀\by∈𝒱i,

and observe that this is a uniformly elliptic problem with C1 coefficients. Applying interior regularity theory [Eva98], we deduce

‖ui‖H2⁢(\bchi−1⁢(𝒲i))≤C⁢‖gi‖L2⁢(𝒰i).

Therefore, adding over i and using the finite overlap property of the sets 𝒰i, we end up with

‖u~‖H2⁢(γ)≤∑i=1I‖u~i‖H2⁢(𝒲i)≤C⁢∑i=1I‖g~i‖L2⁢(𝒰i)≤C⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ),

as asserted. ∎

In view of our discussion below of surfaces of class C1,α with 0<α≤1, it is natural to ask whether the regularity estimate (20) is still valid in this more general context. We now show that this is indeed the case provided the surface γ is of class Wp2 with p>n, or equivalently the parametrizations {\bchii}i=1I and partitions of unity {ψ~i}i=1I subordinate to the covering {𝒲i}i=1I of γ are of class Wp2. In this case a Sobolev embedding implies γ is of class C1,α with 0<α=1−np≤1.

{lemma}

[regularity for Wp2 surfaces] If γ is of class Wp2 with n<p≤∞, then there is a constant C>0 depending on γ,p and n such that

(21) ‖u~‖H2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

We argue with one chart (𝒱,𝒰,\bchi) and thus suppress the index i in g, \bchi, etc. Since \wf∈L2⁢(γ) and \wu∈H1⁢(γ), the right-hand side g=g~∘\bchi in the proof of Lemma 19 (regularity) satisfies

g∈Lr0⁢(𝒱)1r0=12+1p.

On the other hand, the definitions (1) and (5) of the first fundamental form \bg and area element q imply that they are bounded in L∞⁢(𝒱) as well as

\bg,q∈Wp1⁢(𝒱)⇒\bA:=q⁢\bg−1∈Wp1⁢(𝒱).

Therefore, the Laplace-Beltrami equation in the parametric domain 𝒱 can be written in non-divergence form as follows:

(22) \bA:D2u=qg−÷\bA⋅∇u=ℓ∈Lr0(𝒱).

Since \bA is uniformly continuous, the Calderón-Zygmund regularity theory applies (cf. [GT98, Theorem 9.15 and Lemma 9.17]) and gives the interior regularity u∈Wr02⁢(𝒵) with

‖u‖Wr02⁢(𝒵)≲‖ℓ‖Lr0⁢(𝒱)

where 𝒵:=χ−1⁢(𝒲) and 𝒲¯⊂𝒰 as in the proof Lemma 19 (regularity). Invoking Sobolev embedding again, we deduce

u∈Wt11⁢(𝒵),1t1=1r0−1n,

and \wu∈Wt11⁢(γ) upon pasting these local estimates together over γ; hence u∈Wt11⁢(𝒱). We now iterate this argument and prove a recurrence relation by induction. Suppose that a sequence of real numbers {rk,tk} is governed by the relations t0=2 and

1rk=1p+1tk,1tk+1=1rk−1n,

and the right hand side of (22) satisfies ℓ∈Lrk⁢(𝒱); note that this is the case for k=0. Calderón-Zygmund theory thus implies u∈Wrk2⁢(𝒵) with

‖u‖Wrk2⁢(𝒵)≲‖ℓ‖Lrk⁢(𝒵).

Sobolev embedding in turn yields u∈Wtk+11⁢(𝒱) whence ℓ∈Lrk+1⁢(𝒱), which proves the recurrence relation. Iterating these relations we see that for k≥0

1rk=1rk−1+1p−1n=12+1p+k⁢(1p−1n),

and that every step increases the value of rk, because 1p−1n<0. Since \wf∈L2⁢(γ), the iteration stops once rk≥2 or equivalently

k=⌈np−n⌉.

This concludes the proof. ∎

2.3. Signed Distance Function

We now take advantage of the ambient space ℝn+1 and use standard calculus in a suitable tubular neighborhood 𝒩 of γ to derive useful expressions of geometric quantities; we postpone momentarily the precise definition of 𝒩. The surface γ splits ℝn+1 into two disjoint sets, the interior and exterior of γ. The signed distance function d:𝒩→γ is defined for every \bx∈𝒩 to be the distance of \bx to γ, \dist⁢(\bx,γ), if \bx belongs to the exterior of γ and −\dist⁢(\bx,γ) if \bx belongs to the interior of γ, whence

|d⁢(\bx)|=\dist⁢(\bx,γ)∀\bx∈𝒩.

It turns out that d belongs to the same regularity class as γ so long as γ is at least C2, which we henceforth assume in our discussion of d. While the distance function exists for surfaces of regularity less than C1,1, as we explain in Section 2.5 below its properties are drastically different and it is not immediately useful for purposes of defining and analyzing surface FEM. Returning to the setting of C2 surfaces, ∇d⁢(\bx) is well defined for all \bx∈𝒩 and computed on γ gives the unit normal \bnu⁢(\bx) pointing outwards:

\bnu⁢(\bx)=∇d⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈γ.

Since ∇d is defined in 𝒩 it provides a natural extension of \bnu to 𝒩. This neighborhood 𝒩 is sufficiently small that for every \bx∈𝒩 there is a unique closest point projection \bPd⁢(\bx)∈γ defined by

(23) \bPd⁢(\bx)=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈𝒩.

An important property is that ∇d coincides at \bx∈𝒩 and \bPd⁢(\bx)∈γ:

(24) ∇d⁢(\bx)=∇d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=∇d⁢(\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈𝒩.

Since |∇d⁢(\bx)|2=1, we deduce that the Hessian D2⁢d⁢(\bx) satisfies

(25) D2⁢d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)=0∀\bx∈𝒩.

This implies that D2⁢d⁢(\bx) can be regarded as an operator acting on the tangent hyperplane to γ at \bx∈γ and thus gives an alternative representation to the Weingarten map (11):

\bW⁢(\bx)=D2⁢d⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈γ.

This has two important consequences. First it provides a natural extension of \bW to 𝒩 and second shows that \bW is symmetric, which is not apparent from (11).

Given a generic function \tv~:γ→ℝ, the distance function d provides a natural way to extend it to the neighborhood 𝒩 upon writing

(26) \tv⁢(\bx)=\tv~⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=\tv~⁢(\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈𝒩.

Differentiating and using the definition (3) of orthogonal projection, we obtain

(27) ∇\tv⁢(\bx) =(\bI−∇d⁢(\bx)⊗∇d⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx))⁢∇γ\tv~⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))
=(Π⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx))⁢∇γ\tv~⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))
=(\bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx))⁢Π⁢(\bx)⁢∇γ\tv~⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))

where the last equality hinges on (24), which implies Π⁢(\bx)=Π⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) and D2⁢d⁢(\bx)=D2⁢d⁢(\bx)⁢Π⁢(\bx). In particular, ∇\tv⁢(\bx)=∇γ\tv~⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) for \bx∈γ because (26) provides a normal extension of \tv~.

Suppose now that \tv is an extension of \tv~ to 𝒩, but not necessarily in the normal direction. An intrinsic definition of tangential gradient of \tv~ is the orthogonal projection of ∇\tv to the tangent hyperplane of γ:

(28) ∇γ\tv~⁢(\bx)=(\bI−\bnu⁢(\bx)⊗\bnu⁢(\bx))⁢∇\tv⁢(\bx)=Π⁢(\bx)⁢∇\tv⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈γ.

This definition is consistent with (10): ∇γ\tv~⁢(\bx) is orthogonal to \bnu⁢(\bx) and

∇γ\tv~⁢(\bx)⋅∂i\bchi⁢(\by)=∇\tv⁢(\bx)⋅∂i\bchi⁢(\by)=∂i\tv~⁢(\bchi⁢(\by))

obeys the chain rule, whence it must coincide with our previous definition based on these two properties. An important consequence of this property follows. {remark}[parametric independence] The definition (28) is independent of the extension: if \tv1,\tv2 are two extensions of \tv~ then \tv1−\tv2=0 on γ and the only non-vanishing component of ∇(\tv1−\tv2) is in the normal direction \bnu. Since definitions (28) and (10) agree, we deduce that the tangential gradient ∇γ\tv~ is independent of the parametrization \bchi chosen to described γ. The same happens with the tangential divergence (12) as well as the Laplace-Beltrami operator (13), the latter because of (14) and the fact that (8) is independent of \bchi.

Given a vector field \bv~:γ→ℝn+1 and corresponding extension to 𝒩, the tangential divergence can be written as

\divg\bv~(\bx)=\trace∇γ\bv~(\bx)=÷\bv(\bx)−\bnu(\bx)t∇\bv(\bx)\bnu(\bx)∀\bx∈γ,

and gives an alternative expression to (12). Likewise, the Laplace-Beltrami operator Δγ⁢\tv~=\divg⁢∇γ\tv~, written parametrically in (13), can be equivalently written in terms of the extension \tv as follows

Δγ⁢\tv~=\trace⁢(\bI−\bnu⊗\bnu)⁢D2⁢\tv−(∇\tv⋅\bnu)⁢\divg⁢\bnu,

because ∇γ(∇\bnu⋅\bnu)⋅\bnu=0. This implies the expression

Δγ⁢\tv~⁢(\bx)=Δ⁢\tv⁢(\bx)−\bnu⁢(\bx)t⁢D2⁢\tv⁢(\bx)⁢\bnu⁢(\bx)−(∇\tv⋅\bnu)⁢(\bx)⁢\divg⁢\bnu⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈γ.

2.4. Curvatures

We again assume that γ is of class C2. In view of (11), the Weingarten map is symmetric and its n+1 eigenvalues are real. Except for the zero eigenvalue corresponding to the eigenvector \bnu⁢(\bx), according to (25), they are called the principal curvatures of γ at \bx and are denoted by κi⁢(\bx) for 1≤i≤n. The eigenvectors of \bW corresponding to the principal curvatures are called the principal directions.

We stress that κi⁢(\bx) is well defined for all \bx∈𝒩 because so is \bW⁢(\bx). This allows us to make the definition of 𝒩 precise. Given δ>0, first let

(29) 𝒩⁢(δ):={\bx∈ℝn+1:|d⁢(\bx)|<δ}.

Let also

(30) K⁢(\bx):=max1≤i≤n⁡|κi⁢(\bx)|∀\bx∈γ;K∞:=‖K‖L∞⁢(γ).

We may now set

(31) 𝒩:={\bx∈ℝn+1:\dist⁢(\bx,γ)<12⁢K∞}=𝒩⁢(K∞/2).

Note that the distance function, closest point projection, and related properties are defined and hold on the larger set 𝒩⁢(1/K∞). We adopt the more limited definition of 𝒩 in order to avoid degeneration of some quantities such as curvature of parallel surfaces (see below) that occurs near the boundary of the larger set.

Given ε small so that |ε|≤12⁢K∞, we define the parallel surface γε to be

γε:={\bx∈𝒩:d⁢(\bx)=ε}.

The following statement relates the principal curvatures of γε with those of γ.

{lemma}

[curvatures of parallel surface] If γ is of class C2 so are all parallel surfaces γε and their principal curvatures satisfy

(32) κi⁢(\bx)=κi⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))1+ε⁢κi⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈γε,

whereas the principal directions at \bx and \bPd⁢(\bx) coincide.

Proof.

Differentiate (24) to get

D2⁢d⁢(\bx)=D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))⁢(\bI−∇d⁢(\bx)⊗∇d⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx)),

whence, since ∇d⁢(\bx)=∇d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) again from (24),

(\bI+d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)))⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx)=D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))⁢(\bI−∇d⁢(\bx)⊗∇d⁢(\bx))=D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)).

Therefore, for \bx∈γε we see that the eigenvalues of (\bI+ε⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))) are

κi⁢(\bI+ε⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)))=1+ε⁢κi⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))≥12,

according to (31). This implies that \bI+ε⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) is nonsingular and the previous relation reads as follows in terms of the Weingarten map:

\bW⁢(\bx)=(\bI+ε⁢\bW⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)))−1⁢\bW⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)).

This shows that the eigenvectors of \bW⁢(\bx) and \bW⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) coincide and the eigenvalues are related via (32). ∎

The second fundamental form \bh=(hi⁢j)i,j=1n of γ is defined by

hi⁢j⁢(\by):=−∂i\bnu⁢(\by)⋅∂i\bchi⁢(\by)=\bnu⁢(\by)⋅∂i⁢j\bchi⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱,

where the last equality relies on the fact that \bnu and ∂j\bchi are orthogonal for 1≤j≤n. The next result connects \bh with the Weingarten map (11).

{lemma}

[second fundamental form] The symmetric matrix \bW=Dγ⁢\bnu defines a selfadjoint operator on the tangent hyperplane to γ that can be represented in the basis {∂j\bchi}j=1n by the generally non-symmetric matrix

\bs=−\bh⁢\bg−1.

The eigenvalues of \bs are the principal curvatures of γ.

Proof.

Since Dγ⁢\bnu⁢\bnu=0, we can regard Dγ⁢\bnu as an operator acting on the tangent plane to γ and represent its image in terms of {∂k\bchi}k=1n as follows

∂i\bnu⁢(\by)=Dγ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx)⁢∂i\bchi⁢(\by)=∑k=1nsi⁢k⁢(\by)⁢∂k\bchi⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱.

Let \bs⁢(\by):=(si⁢j⁢(\by))i⁢j,=1n and multiply both sides by ∂j\bchi⁢(\by) to see that

hi⁢j⁢(\by)=−∂i\bnu⁢(\by)⋅∂j\bchi⁢(\by)=∑k=1nsi⁢k⁢∂k\bchi⁢(\by)⋅∂j\bchi⁢(\by)=∑k=1nsi⁢k⁢gk⁢j.

This implies \bh=−\bs⁢\bg and thus the assertion. ∎

2.5. Surface regularity and properties of the distance function

In the previous two sections we have seen that when γ is of class C2, the closest point projection is uniquely defined in a tubular neighborhood of γ whose width is related to the principal curvatures of the surface. We shall see below that the closest point projection plays a pivotal role in analyzing finite element methods on C2 surfaces. On the other hand, some applications may require solving PDE on surfaces that are less regular than C2. Thus it is natural to ask which properties of the distance function and closest point projection carry over to less regular surfaces. It turns out that the properties of these maps change drastically and fundamentally when crossing the threshold from C2 to less regular (C1,α with α<1) surfaces.

In order to make this statement precise, we begin by restating for comparison from [GT98, Lemma 14.16] some fundamental properties of the distance function for Ck surfaces (k≥2). {lemma}[properties of distance functions for Ck surfaces] Let γ be a Ck surface, k≥2. Then there exists a positive constant δ depending on γ such that d∈Ck⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)). In addition, the closest point projection \bPd⁢(\bx)=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx) is defined and of class Ck−1 on 𝒩⁢(δ) with δ<1K∞. We now ask whether a similar statement holds for k<2, and in particular for k=1. Note first that the distance function d to any closed set γ⊂ℝn+1 is defined and Lipschitz continuous [Fed59, Theorem 4.8.1], so the first question at hand is whether distance functions for C1,α surfaces (0≤α<1) are more than Lipshitz continuous.

In order to understand the relationship between surface regularity and the distance function map, we first define the reach of a surface γ:

reach⁢(γ):=sup{δ≥0:all \bx∈𝒩⁢(δ)⁢ have a unique closest point \bPd⁢(\bx)∈γ}.

For a C2 surface γ, we have already seen that reach⁢(γ)=1/K∞. We now explore the connection between the reach and properties of the distance function for less regular surfaces. We first define

U⁢(γ):={\bx∈ℝn+1:\bx⁢ has a unique closest point in ⁢γ}.

The following result may be found in [Fed59, Theorem 4.8.3]. {lemma}[properties of differentiable distance functions] If γ is a C1 surface, \bx∈ℝn+1∖γ, and d is differentiable at \bx, then \bx∈U⁢(γ). In particular, if d is differentiable in a neighborhood of γ, then reach⁢(γ)>0.

Next we define several constants from the technical report [Luc57]. Given \bx∈γ and ρ≥0, we first define the closed normal segment

S⁢(\bx,ρ):=[\bx−ρ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx),\bx+ρ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx)].

Let Bρ⁢(\by) denotes the ball in ℝn+1 of center \by and radius ρ>0, and

1r0:=sup\bx,\by∈γ,\bx≠\by|\bnu⁢(\bx)−\bnu⁢(\by)||\bx−\by|,1r0′:=sup{ρ≥0:S⁢(\bx,ρ)∩S⁢(\by,ρ)=∅⁢∀\bx,\by∈γ,\bx≠\by},1r0′′:=sup{ρ≥0:Bρ⁢(\bx±ρ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx))¯ contain respectively no points interior or exterior to γ for all \bx∈γ},1r0′′′:=sup\bx,\by∈γ,\bx≠\by|2⁢(\by−\bx)⋅\bnu⁢(\bx)||\by−\bx|2.

Combining [Luc57, Theorem 1] and noting that r0 bounds the Lipschitz constant of γ (cf. the comment on p. 15 of [Luc57]), we have the following. {lemma}[further properties of C1 surfaces] If the surface γ is of class C1, then the constants r0, r0′, r0′′, and r0′′′ are all equal. In addition, if r0>0 then γ is of class C1,1.

Combining the previous lemmas with the statement in [Fed59, Theorem 4.18] that r0=′′′reach(γ) yields the following result. {theorem}[C1 distance function implies C1,1 surface] If the distance function d associated to a C1 surface γ is continuously differentiable in a tubular neighborhood 𝒩⁢(δ) of γ for some δ>0, then γ is of class C1,1. In addition, any C1 surface with positive reach is of class C1,1.

The preceding results establish that the properties of the distance function and the associated closest point projection for C2 surfaces that we previously discussed are inherently connected with surfaces of bounded curvature. This can be seen both in Theorem 2.5 (since the curvatures are defined and bounded almost everywhere on a C1,1 surface) and in the definition of the constant r0′′ (since for \bx∈γ, the supremum over the radii ρ for which Bρ⁢(\bx±ρ⁢ν⁢(\bx))¯∩γ=∅ is the inverse of the maximum principal curvature at \bx).

For our purposes, Theorem 2.5 is essentially a negative result in that it establishes that the distance function and closest point projection are of limited immediate use for surfaces that are less regular than C1,1. In particular, in this case the closest point projection is not uniquely defined on any tubular neighborhood of γ. In addition, the regularity of the distance function does not vary continuously with that of γ, since for a C1,α surface with α<1 Theorem 2.5 establishes that d is only Lipschitz. Thus we must use different tools when considering surface finite element methods on less regular surfaces than C2.

2.6. Divergence Theorem on Surfaces

We conclude this section with an application of calculus in ℝn+1 to derive an integration by parts formula on not necessarily closed surfaces.

{proposition}

[divergence theorem] Let γ be a compact, oriented surface of class C2 with Lipschitz boundary ∂γ. Let H=∑i=1nκi be the total curvature of γ and \bmu be the unit outward normal to ∂γ lying in the tangent hyperplane to γ. If \tv~:γ→ℝ∈H1⁢(γ), then

∫γ∇γ\tv~=∫γ\tv~⁢H⁢\bnu+∫∂γ\tv~⁢\bmu.
Proof.

Given ε<12⁢K∞ we define the tubular set

Ωε:={\bz=\bx+ρ\bnu(\bx):\bx∈γ,|ρ|<ε};

note that \bPd⁢(\bz)=\bx for all \bz∈Ωε. We decompose the boundary ∂Ωε of Ωε into

γ±ε:={\bx±ε⁢\bnu⁢(\bx):\bx∈γ},λε:=∂Ωε∖(γε∪γ−ε).

The sets γ±ε are parallel surfaces to γ whereas λε is the lateral boundary of size 2⁢ε. We first assume that \tv~ is of class C1, let \tv be an extension of \tv~ to Ωε of class C1⁢(Ωε¯), and apply the divergence theorem in Ωε to obtain

∫Ωε∇\tv=∫∂Ωε\tv⁢\bnuε=∫γε\tv⁢\bnu∘\bPd−∫γ−ε\tv⁢\bnu∘\bPd+∫λε\tv⁢\bmu∘\bPd,

where \bnuε is the unit outward normal of ∂Ωε. We divide both sides of this equality by 2⁢ε, the thickness of Ωε and compute the limits as ε→0. According to (27) we first see that

12⁢ε⁢∫Ωε∇\tv=12⁢ε⁢∫Ωε(\bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx))⁢∇γ\ttv⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))⁢𝑑\bx⁢⟶ε→0∫γ∇γ\ttv.

Likewise

12⁢ε⁢∫λε\tv⁢\bmu∘\bPd⁢⟶ε→0∫∂γ\ttv⁢\bmu.

Moreover, since \bnu∘\bPd=∇d, we infer that

limε→012⁢ε(∫γε\tv\bnu∘\bPd −∫γ−ε\tv\bnu∘\bPd)=dd⁢ρ∫γρ\tv∇d|ρ=0
=dd⁢ρ⁢∫𝒱\tv⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx+ρ⁢∇d⁢(\bx))⁢qρ⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by|ρ=0

with \bx=\bchi⁢(\by)∈γ and qρ⁢(\by) denotes the infinitesimal area associated with the surface γρ:={\bz=\bx+ρ⁢\bnu⁢(\bx):\bx∈γ}. Since dd⁢ρ⁢∇d⁢(\bx+ρ⁢∇d⁢(\bx))=D2⁢d⁢(\bx+ρ⁢∇d⁢(\bx))⁢∇d⁢(\bx)=0, it remains to evaluate dd⁢ρ⁢qρ. We resort to (53) (shown below) with Γ=γρ and use that \bnuρ⋅\bnu=1 as well as (32) to write

qρ⁢(\by)q⁢(\by)=1det(\bI−ρ⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx))=1∏i=1n(1−ρ⁢κi⁢(\bx))=∏i=1n(1+ρ⁢κi⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))).

We finally observe that

dd⁢ρ⁢qρ⁢(\by)|ρ=0=q⁢(\by)⁢∑i=1nκi⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=q⁢(\by)⁢H⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))

to conclude the proof for t~⁢v of class C1. The assertion for \ttv∈H1⁢(γ) follows by density of C1⁢(γ¯) in \ttv∈H1⁢(γ). ∎

Applying Proposition 2.6 (divergence theorem) to a vector field \bv~:γ→ℝn+1 and computing the trace yields the more familiar expression

∫γdivγ⁢\bv~=∫γH⁢\bv~⋅\bnu+∫∂γ\bv~⋅\bmu.
{corollary}

[integration by parts] Let γ be a surface of class C2 with Lipschitz boundary ∂γ. If \ttv,w~:γ→ℝ satisfy \ttv∈H2⁢(γ) and w~∈H1⁢(γ), then

∫γw~⁢Δγ⁢\ttv+∇γw~⋅∇γw~=∫∂γw~⁢∇γ\ttv⋅\bmu.
Proof.

Apply the previous equality to \bv~=w~⁢∇γ\ttv. ∎

3. Perturbation Theory

In most surface finite element methods, the approximate problem is not posed on the continuous surface γ. This may occur either for convenience, or because γ is not known precisely. Examples of only incomplete information being present in simulations include free boundary problems such as two-phase flow and cases where γ is reconstructed from some sort of imaging data.

The purpose of this section is to investigate how geometric quantities change under perturbation of the surface γ. To this end, suppose that Γ is a closed Lipschitz surface (not necessarily C2). We use a subscript Γ to denote geometric quantities associated with Γ: \bchiΓ (parametrization), \bgΓ (first fundamental form), qΓ (area element), \bnuΓ (unit normal), ∇Γ (tangential gradient), and ΠΓ (orthogonal projection onto Γ).

Let u~∈H#1⁢(γ) solve (19) and uΓ∈H#1⁢(Γ) solve

(33) ∫Γ∇ΓuΓ⋅∇Γ\tv=∫ΓfΓ⁢\tv∀\tv∈H#1⁢(Γ),

for a given forcing fΓ∈L2,#⁢(Γ). To examine the error between u and uΓ, we first have to study how the bilinear forms in (19) and (33) change when changing γ. This amounts to deriving expressions for the error matrices \bE,\bEΓ∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) in the error equations

(34) ∫Γ∇Γ\tv⋅∇Γw−∫γ∇γ\tv~⋅∇γw~=∫γ∇γ\tv~⋅\bE⁢∇γw~=∫Γ∇Γ\tv⋅\bEΓ⁢∇Γw,

valid for all \tv,w∈H1⁢(Γ) and \tv~,w~∈H1⁢(γ) the corresponding lifts. We carry out this program below within two scenarios depending on the regularity of γ. We alert the reader about the following abuse of notation: the matrix \bE (resp. \bEΓ) is defined in γ (resp. Γ), but we will often write them in the parametric domain 𝒱 thereby identifying \bE (resp. \bEΓ) with \bE∘\bchi (resp. \bEΓ∘\bchiΓ).

3.1. Perturbation Theory for C1,α Surfaces

Let γ be of class C1,α and \bchi and \bchiΓ be the parametrizations of γ and Γ. They dictate the relation between \tv~ and \tv, the former defined on γ and the latter on Γ,

\tv=\wv∘\bchi∘\bchiΓ−1.

In the sequel, we first establish a relation between ∇γ\tv~ and ∇Γ\tv and next use it to characterize \bE and \bEΓ.

{lemma}

[relation between tangential gradients] If \wv:γ→ℝ is of class H1, then the tangential gradients ∇γ\tv~ and ∇Γ\tv satisfy

(35) ∇Γ\tv=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢D⁢\bchit⁢∇γ\tv~,∇γ\tv~=D⁢\bchi⁢\bg−1⁢D⁢\bchiΓt⁢∇Γ\tv.
Proof.

We concatenate (10) and (9) to write

∇Γ\tv=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢∇(\tv∘\bchiΓ)=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢∇(\wv∘\bchi)=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢D⁢\bchit⁢∇γ\tv~,

which is the first asserted expression provided \wu is of class C1. Using the density of C1⁢(γ) in H1⁢(γ) for a surface γ of class C1,α, the first assertion follows. The second one follows similarly. ∎

{lemma}

[geometric consistency] The error matrices \bE and \bEΓ read on 𝒱

(36) \bE=D⁢\bchi⁢(qΓq⁢\bgΓ−1−\bg−1)⁢D⁢\bchit,
(37) \bEΓ=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢(\bgΓ−1−qqΓ⁢\bg−1)⁢D⁢\bchiΓt.
Proof.

Using (35), together with the definition (1) of \bgΓ=D⁢\bchiΓt⁢D⁢\bchiΓ, yields

∫Γ∇Γ\tv⋅∇Γw=∫γ∇γ\ttv⋅qΓq⁢(D⁢\bchi⁢\bgΓ−1⁢D⁢\bchit)⁢∇γw~.

Since ∇γ\tv~=Π⁢∇γ\tv~=D⁢\bchi⁢\bg−1⁢D⁢\bchit⁢∇γ\tv~, according to (4), the first equality in (34) follows immediately. The proof of the second equality is similar. ∎

Our task now is to relate \bg−\bgΓ and q−qΓ with D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ). We accomplish this next but first we introduce some additional concepts. For any \by∈𝒱, we denote by |D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)| (resp. |D−⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|) the largest (resp. smaller) singular value of D⁢\bchi⁢(\by). Given the relation \bg=D⁢\bchit⁢D⁢\bchi, these quantities are the square roots of the largest and smallest eigenvalues of \bg. We define the stability constant

(38) S\bchi:=sup\by∈𝒱max⁡{|D⁢\bchi⁢(y)|,|D⁢\bchiΓ⁢(y)|}min⁡{|D−⁢\bchi⁢(y)|,|D−⁢\bchiΓ⁢(y)|}

and point out that it is a measure of non-degeneracy of D⁢\bchi and D⁢\bchiΓ. We further define the following relative measure of geometric accuracy

(39) λ∞:=sup\by∈𝒱|D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ)⁢(\by)|min⁡{|D−⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|,|D−⁢\bchiΓ⁢(\by)|}.
{lemma}

[error estimates for \bg and q] The following error estimates are valid

(40) ‖\bI−\bgΓ⁢\bg−1‖L∞⁢(𝒱),‖\bI−\bgΓ−1⁢\bg‖L∞⁢(𝒱)≲S\bchi⁢λ∞,
(41) ‖1−q−1⁢qΓ‖L∞⁢(𝒱),‖1−qΓ−1⁢q‖L∞⁢(𝒱)≲S\bchin⁢λ∞.
Proof.

Since |D⁢\bchi|=|D⁢\bchit|, |\bg−1|≤|D−⁢\bchi|−2 and

(\bg−\bgΓ)⁢(\by)=D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)t⁢D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ)⁢(\by)+D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ)⁢(\by)t⁢D⁢\bchiΓ⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱,

the first assertion in (40) follows; the second one is similar. To prove (41), we write

q⁢(\by)−qΓ⁢(\by)=det\bg⁢(\by)−det\bgΓ⁢(\by)q⁢(\by)+qΓ⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱,

and note that q=det\bg=∏i=1nλi⁢(\bg) where {λi⁢(\bg)}i=1n are the eigenvalues of \bg. Utilizing the definitions of |D⁢\bchi| and |D−⁢\bchi| we end up with

(42) |D−⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|n≤q⁢(\by)≤|D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|n∀\by∈𝒱.

Since det\bg−det\bgΓ is the sum of terms of the form ∂i\bchi⋅∂j\bchi−∂i\bchiΓ⋅∂j\bchiΓ multiplied by n−1 factors bounded by |D⁢\bchi|, we deduce

|q⁢(\by)−1⁢(q−qΓ)⁢(\by)|≲|D−⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|−n⁢|D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ)⁢(\by)|⁢|D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)|n−1∀\by∈𝒱.

This is the first assertion in (41) in disguise. The second one is similar. ∎

{lemma}

[norm equivalence] Let γ and Γ be Lipschitz surfaces which are related via a bi-Lipschitz map \bP=\bchi∘\bchiΓ−1:Γ→γ. Then there is a constant C≥1, depending on the stability constant S\bchi in (38), such that

(43) C−1⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≤‖\ttv‖L2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)∀\ttv∈L2⁢(γ),
(44) C−1⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≤‖∇γ\ttv‖L2⁢(γ)≤C⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)∀\ttv∈H1⁢(γ).
Proof.

Use (9) and (10) in conjunction with (8). ∎

Lemma 2.2 (Poincaré-Friedrichs inequality) holds on the perturbed surface Γ but with a constant depending on Γ. In order to avoid this dependence, and thus obtain a uniform constant in Γ, it is only necessary that Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) be valid. Before stating our result, we first define a class of surfaces. Given a Lipschitz surface γ, we let 𝒮e⁢q be the class of Lipschitz surfaces Γ such that Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) holds with uniform equivalence constant Ce⁢q. Note that implicit in this definition is the existence of a bi-Lipschitz bijection \bP:Γ→γ for each Γ∈𝒮e⁢q, for instance \bP=\bchi∘\bchiΓ−1.

{lemma}

[uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs constant] Given a Lipschitz surface γ, for every \tv∈H#1⁢(Γ) with Γ∈𝒮e⁢q there holds that

(45) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖∇Γu‖L2⁢(Γ)

with the constant hidden in ≲ depending only on γ and Ce⁢q.

Proof.

We argue by contradiction the validity of

‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≤C⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)∀\tv∈H1⁢(Γ)

and all Γ∈𝒮e⁢q with uniform constant C. We thus assume the existence of a sequence of surfaces Γk∈𝒮e⁢q and functions \tvk∈H#1⁢(Γk) such that

‖\tvk‖L2⁢(Γk)=1‖∇Γk\tvk‖L2⁢(Γk)→0

as k→∞. We denote by \bPk:Γk→γ the associated bi-Lipschitz bijections and by \tv~k=\tvk∘\bPk−1 the lifts of the functions \tvk to γ. Since Γk∈𝒮e⁢q, the estimates of Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) hold with uniform constant Ce⁢q for each Γk, whence \wvk∈H1⁢(γ) and

‖\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)≃1,‖∇γ\wvk‖L2⁢(γ)→0

as k→∞. Proceeding as in Lemma 2.2 (Poincaré-Friedrichs inequality), we deduce that a subsequence of {\wvk}k, still denoted {\wvk}k, converges in H1⁢(γ) to a function \wv∈H1⁢(γ) with ∇γ\wv=0; this implies that \wv is constant. To show that \wv=0, let ϵ>0 be arbitrary and k sufficiently large so that ‖\wvk−\wv‖L2⁢(γ)≤ϵ. Exploiting that \tv~ is constant and ∫Γk\tvk=0, we use Lemma 3.1 to compute

|\tv~| =|Γk|−1⁢|∫Γk\tv~|=|Γk|−1⁢|∫Γk\tv~−\tvk|
≤|Γk|−1/2⁢‖\tv~−\tvk‖L2⁢(Γk)≤Ce⁢q⁢|Γk|−1/2⁢‖\tv~−\tv~k‖L2⁢(γ)≤Ce⁢q⁢|Γk|−1/2⁢ϵ.

Applying again Lemma 3.1, now to the function 1, yields |Γk|≃|Γ| with constant depending only on Ce⁢q, so that |\tv~|≲ϵ. Since ϵ is arbitrary, we must thus have \tv~=0. This contradicts ‖\tv~k‖L2⁢(γ)≃1 because ‖\tv~k‖L2⁢(γ)→‖\wv‖L2⁢(γ)=0. Consequently, the desired statement is proved. ∎

{lemma}

[perturbation error estimate for C1,α surfaces] Let \wu∈H#1⁢(γ) solve (19) and uΓ∈H#1⁢(Γ) solve (33). Then, the following error estimate for u−uΓ holds

(46) ‖∇γ(\wu−\wuΓ)‖L2⁢(γ)≲λ∞⁢‖fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ)+‖f⁢q⁢qΓ−1−fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ),

where the hidden constant depends on S\bchi defined in (38).

Proof.

We proceed in several steps.

Step 1: error representation. Let \ttv=\wu−\wuΓ and make use of (34) to write

‖∇γ(\wu−\wuΓ)‖L2⁢(γ)2=∫γ∇γ\wu⋅∇γ\ttv−∫Γ∇ΓuΓ⋅∇Γ\tv+∫γ∇γ\wuΓ⋅\bE⁢∇γ\ttv.

We next employ the equations (19) and (33) satisfied by u~ and uΓ to obtain

‖∇γ(\wu−\wuΓ)‖L2⁢(γ)2=∫Γ(f⁢qqΓ−fΓ)⁢\tv+∫γ∇γ\wuΓ⋅\bE⁢∇γ\wv,

where we have also employed (8) to switch the domain of integration of f.

Step 2: geometric error matrix. To derive a bound for ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ), we rewrite \bE

\bE=D⁢\bchi⁢((q−1⁢qΓ−1)⁢\bgΓ−1−\bg−1⁢(\bI−\bg⁢\bgΓ−1))⁢D⁢\bchit.

Since |\bg−1|=|D−⁢\bchi|−2,|\bgΓ−1|=|D−⁢\bchiΓ|−2, applying (40) and (41) leads to the error estimate

(47) ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ)≲λ∞.

Step 3: final estimates. The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality yields

∫γ∇\wuΓ⋅\bE⁢∇γ\ttv≤‖∇γ\ttv‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\wuΓ‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ).

To derive a bound for ‖∇γ\wuΓ‖L2⁢(γ), we first combine (17) with (33) to obtain ‖∇ΓuΓ‖L2⁢(Γ)≤‖fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ), and next appeal to Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence). On the other hand, we recall that f⁢qqΓ−fΓ has vanishing mean-value on Γ, let \tv¯=|Γ|−1⁢∫Γ\tv be the mean-value of \tv, and use (17) to arrive at

∫Γ(f⁢qqΓ−fΓ)⁢\tv=∫Γ(f⁢qqΓ−fΓ)⁢(\tv−\tv¯)≤‖f⁢q⁢qΓ−1−fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ).

Finally, applying Lemma 3.1 ends the proof. ∎

3.2. Perturbation Theory for C2 Surfaces

Let γ be of class C2 and the tubular neighborhood 𝒩 satisfy (31), namely

(48) 𝒩={\bx∈ℝn+1:|d⁢(\bx)|<12⁢K∞},

so that parallel surfaces to γ within 𝒩 are also C2. We further assume that Γ⊂𝒩 and the distance function projection \bPd=\bI−d⁢∇d:Γ→γ is a bijection. The parametrizations of γ and Γ are given by \bchi:=\bPd∘\bchiΓ so that

\tv=\tv~∘\bPd.
{lemma}

[relation between tangential gradients] If \wv:γ→ℝ is of class H1, then the tangential gradients ∇γ\wv and ∇Γ\tv satisfy for all \bx∈Γ

(49) ∇Γ\tv⁢(\bx)=ΠΓ⁢(\bx)⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢(\bx)⁢Π⁢(\bx)⁢∇γ\wv⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)),

and

(50) ∇γ\wv⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=(\bI−d⁢\bW)−1⁢(\bx)⁢(\bI−\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)⊗\bnu⁢(\bx)\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)⋅\bnu⁢(\bx))⁢∇Γ\tv⁢(\bx).
Proof.

Let us assume that \wv∈C1⁢(γ). Recalling (27) and (28), we readily get

∇Γ\tv⁢(\bx)=ΠΓ⁢(\bx)⁢∇\tv⁢(\bx)=ΠΓ⁢(\bx)⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢(\bx)⁢Π⁢(\bx)⁢∇γ\wv⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)),

hence (49). Since \bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢\bW⁢(\bx) is invertible for all \bx∈𝒩, according to the definition (31) of 𝒩 and shown in Lemma 2.4 (curvature of parallel surfaces), (27) can be rewritten as

∇γ\wv(\bPd(\bx))=(I−d\bW)(\bx))−1∇\tv(\bx)∀\bx∈𝒩.

To prove (50) we must relate ∇\tv and ∇Γ\tv. First note that for \bx∈Γ

∇\tv=(\bI−\bnuΓ⊗\bnuΓ)⁢∇\tv+\bnuΓ⊗\bnuΓ⁢∇\tv=∇Γ\tv+(∇\tv⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnuΓ.

Exploiting next that ∇\tv⁢(\bx)⋅\bnu⁢(\bx)=0, because \tv⁢(\bx) is constant in the normal direction to \bPd⁢(\bx), yields

∇Γ\tv⋅\bnu+(\bnuΓ⋅\bnu)⁢∇\tv⋅\bnuΓ=0⇒∇\tv⋅\bnuΓ=−1\bnuΓ⋅\bnu⁢∇Γ\tv⋅\bnu.

Since ∇\tv=∇Γ\tv+(∇\tv⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnuΓ, we deduce

∇\tv⁢(\bx)=(\bI−\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)⊗\bnu⁢(\bx)\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)⋅\bnu⁢(\bx))⁢∇Γ\tv⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈Γ.

Inserting this into the previous expression for ∇γ\tv⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) leads to (50). Finally, a density argument of C1⁢(γ) in H1⁢(γ) for γ of class C2 concludes the proof. ∎

The following result mimics Lemma 3.1 (geometric consistency) except that now it quantifies the effect of perturbing the surface γ on the bilinear forms written in (34) in terms of \bPd.

{lemma}

[geometric consistency] The error matrices \bE,\bEΓ∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) in (34) are given on Γ by

(51) \bE∘\bPd:=qΓq⁢Π⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢ΠΓ⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢Π−Π,
(52) \bEΓ:=qqΓ⁢(I−\bnu⊗\bnuΓ\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)−2⁢(I−\bnuΓ⊗\bnu\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)−ΠΓ.
Proof.

In view of (8), (49), and the fact that all matrices involved are symmetric and ΠΓ2=ΠΓ, we can write

∫Γ∇Γw⋅∇Γ\tv=∫γ∇γw~⋅(qΓq⁢Π⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢ΠΓ⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢Π)⁢∇γ\tv~

Noticing that ∇γw~=Π⁢∇γw~ the first equality on (34) follows immediately. The second equality proceeds along the same lines but using (50) instead. ∎

It is clear from Lemma 3.2 that the ratio of area elements q/qΓ matters. We next derive a representation for q/qΓ for any dimension n, proved originally for n=2,3 in [DD07, Dem09]. We stress that, in view of Remark 2.3 (parametric independence), the solution u of the Laplace-Beltrami equation (18) is independent of the parametrization of γ. This allows us to consider a convenient parametrization \bchi for theory because it does not change the geometric objects under consideration. We exploit this flexibility next.

{lemma}

[relation between q and qΓ] Given any parametrization \bchiΓ of Γ, let \bchi:=\bPd∘\bchiΓ be the parametrization of γ. If \bnu⁢(\bx)⋅\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)≥0 for all \bx∈Γ, then the ratio of area elements q⁢(\by)/qΓ⁢(\by) with \by=\bchiΓ−1⁢(\bx) satisfies

(53) q⁢(\by)qΓ⁢(\by)=det(\bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢\bW⁢(\bx))⁢(\bnu⁢(\bx)⋅\bnuΓ⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈Γ.
Proof.

We start with the formula (5) for the area elements q and qΓ to get

qqΓ=det([\bnu,D⁢\exactparam]⁢[\bnuΓ,D⁢\bchiΓ]−1).

We write [\bnuΓ,D⁢\bchiΓ]−1=[\bv,\bA]t for some \bv∈ℝn+1 and \bA∈ℝ(n+1)×n to be found. The identity [\bv,\bA]t⁢[\bnuΓ,D⁢\bchiΓ]=\bI yields \bv=\bnuΓ while [\bnuΓ,D⁢\bchiΓ]⁢[\bv,\bA]t=\bI gives D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bAt=\bI−\bnuΓ⊗\bnuΓ=ΠΓ and

[\bnu,D⁢\exactparam]⁢[\bnuΓ,D⁢\bchiΓ]−1=\bnu⊗\bnuΓ+D⁢\bchi⁢\bAt.

To obtain an expression for D⁢\bchi, let \bx=\bchiΓ⁢(\by)∈Γ and \bchi⁢(\by)=\bPd⁢(\bx)=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)∈γ, and utilize the chain rule

D⁢\bchi⁢(\by)=(\bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢\bW⁢(\bx))⁢Π⁢(\bx)⁢D⁢\bchiΓ⁢(\by)∀\by∈𝒱,

where we have argued as in (27). Compute now D⁢\bchi⁢\bAt and use that D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bAt=ΠΓ together with \bW⁢\bnu=0 to arrive at

qqΓ =det(\bnu⊗\bnuΓ+(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢Π⁢ΠΓ)
=det((\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢(\bnu⊗\bnuΓ+Π⁢ΠΓ))=det((\bI−d⁢\bW))⁢det\bB.

where \bB:=\bnu⊗\bnuΓ+Π⁢ΠΓ. It thus remains to show that det\bB=\bnu⋅\bnuΓ.

We now embark on a spectral analysis of \bB. We first note that the statement is trivial if \bnu=\bnuΓ. We thus assume that {\bnu,\bnuΓ} are linearly independent and that the space 𝕏=span⁢{\bnu,\bnuΓ} is generated by two orthonormal vectors \bnu and \be. We consider the orthogonal decomposition ℝn+1=𝕏⊕𝕏⟂ and a rotation \bR∈ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) on 𝕏 that maps \bnu into \bnuΓ, namely

\bR⁢\bnu=\bnuΓ=cos⁡θ⁢\bnu+sin⁡θ⁢\be,\bR⁢\be=−sin⁡θ⁢\bnu+cos⁡θ⁢\be;

thus the rotation angle θ satisfies cos⁡θ=\bnu⋅\bnuΓ and det\bR=1. Consequently,

\bB=(\bnu⊗\bnu+Π⁢\bR⁢Π)⁢\bRt⇒det\bB=det(\bnu⊗\bnu+Π⁢\bR⁢Π).

The proof concludes upon realizing that \bnu and \be are eigenvectors of \bnu⊗\bnu+Π⁢\bR⁢Π with eigenvalues 1 and cos⁡θ, and the remaining eigenvalues are 1 with eigenspace 𝕏⟂. ∎

We are now ready to compare solutions u and uΓ of (19) on two nearby surfaces γ and Γ. In essence, weak solutions u and uΓ are close in H1 provided γ and Γ are close in a Lipschitz sense. Therefore, to make this statement quantitative we introduce the following geometric quantities

(54) d∞:=‖d‖L∞⁢(Γ),ν∞:=‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(Γ),K∞:=‖K‖L∞⁢(γ),

where Γ⊂𝒩 is a Lipschitz surface. Our goal is to bound ‖u−uΓ‖H#1⁢(Γ) in terms of the forcing functions f,fΓ, and d∞,ν∞,K∞ in (54). {lemma}[perturbation error estimate for C2 surfaces] Let u solve (19) and uΓ solve (33) with Γ⊂𝒩. Let \bchiΓ and \bchi:=\bPd∘\bchiΓ be the parametrizations of Γ and γ that give rise to the area elements qΓ and q. If the normal vectors satisfy \bnu⋅\bnuΓ≥c>0, then

(55) ‖∇γ(u−uΓ)‖L2⁢(γ)≲(d∞⁢K∞+ν∞2)⁢‖fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ)+‖f⁢q⁢qΓ−1−fΓ‖H#−1⁢(Γ).
Proof.

We proceed along the lines of Lemma 3.1 (perturbation error estimate for C1,α surfaces) and realize that Steps 1 and 3 are exactly the same. Therefore, we only deal with the estimate of the geometric error matrix \bE. If we prove

(56) ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ)≲ν∞2+d∞⁢K∞,

then the assertion will readily follow. We first write \bE∘\bPd=\bI1+\bI2+\bI3 with

\bI1 :=(qΓq−1)⁢Π⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢ΠΓ⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢Π,
\bI2 :=(Π⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢ΠΓ⁢(\bI−d⁢\bW)⁢Π−Π⁢ΠΓ⁢Π),
\bI3 :=(Π⁢ΠΓ⁢Π−Π).

We now estimate these three terms separately. In view of (53) we deduce

q⁢(\by)qΓ⁢(\by)−1=((\bnu⁢(\bx)⋅\bnuΓ⁢(\bx)−1)⁢∏i=1n(1−d⁢(\bx)⁢κi⁢(\bx)))+(∏i=1n(1−d⁢(\bx)⁢κi⁢(\bx))−1),

where \bx=\bchiΓ⁢(\by)∈Γ. Since 1−\bnu⋅\bnuΓ=12⁢|\bnu−\bnuΓ|2≤12⁢ν∞2 and Γ⊂𝒩, we readily obtain

(57) |q⁢(\by)qΓ⁢(\by)−1|≲ν∞2+d∞⁢K∞∀\by∈𝒱,

and a similar bound for qΓq because qΓq is bounded in 𝒱 thanks to the assumption \bnu⋅\bnuΓ≥c>0. The desired estimate for ‖\bI1‖L∞⁢(γ) follows from the fact that Π,ΠΓ and \bW are bounded. This property again, now combined with

\bI2=−Π⁢ΠΓ⁢d⁢\bW⁢Π−Π⁢d⁢\bW⁢ΠΓ⁢Π+Π⁢d⁢\bW⁢ΠΓ⁢d⁢\bW⁢Π,

yields ‖\bI2‖L∞⁢(γ)≲d∞⁢K∞. Finally, term \bI3 reads

\bI3=−Π⁢\bnuΓ⊗Π⁢\bnuΓ=−(\bnuΓ−(\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnu)⊗(\bnuΓ−(\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnu)

Since \bnuΓ−(\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnu=(\bnuΓ−\bnu)+(1−\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnu we infer that ‖\bI3‖L∞⁢(γ)≲ν∞2. This ends the proof. ∎

It is worth comparing Lemmas 3.1 and 54 (perturbation error estimates). To do so, we next give an estimate for ν∞ in terms of λ∞.

{lemma}

[error estimate for normals] The errors ν∞ and λ∞ defined in (54) and (39) satisfy

(58) ν∞≲λ∞,

where the hidden constant depends on S\bchi defined in (38).

Proof.

In view of the definition (2) of \bnu, we realize that

\bnu−\bnuΓ=\bN−\bNΓ|\bN|+|\bNΓ|−|\bN||\bN|⁢\bNΓ|\bNΓ|⇒|\bnu−\bnuΓ|≤2⁢|\bN−\bNΓ||\bN|.

Since \bN=∑i=1n+1det([\bei,D⁢\bchi])⁢\bei and det([\bei,D⁢\bchi])−det([\bei,D⁢\bchiΓ]) is a sum of products of ∂j(\bchi−\bchiΓ)⋅\bek with k≠i times n−1 factors ∂ℓ\bchim, we have

|det([\bei,D⁢\bchi])−det([\bei,D⁢\bchiΓ])|≲|D⁢(\bchi−\bchiΓ)|⁢|D⁢\bchi|n−1.

We finally resort to |\bN|=q, proved in (7), as well as q≈|D⁢\bchi|n, showed in the proof of Lemma 3.1, to conclude (58). ∎

We now stress the advantage of using the distance function lift \bPd to represent the error u−uγ whenever the surface γ is of class C2. Comparing (46) and (55) we see that the geometric error becomes of order ‖d‖L∞⁢(Γ) plus a quadratic term in λ∞ rather than linear. In the context of finite element methods, Γ is often a polyhedral approximation to γ having faces of diameter h. In this case ‖d‖L∞⁢(Γ) essentially becomes a Lagrange interpolation error measured in L∞ and λ∞ a Lagrange interpolation error measured in W∞1. The former error is of order h2 and the latter of order h. Consequently, the perturbation error for C2 surfaces is of order h2, whereas for C1,α surfaces with α<1 it is of order hα from the analysis of the previous subsection. The increased approximation order for C2 surfaces is a superconvergence effect. We also recall from Theorem 2.5 (C1 distance function implies C1,1 surfaces) that the elegant properties of the distance function and closest point projection that lead to this superconvergence effect are not available when γ is not of class C2, thus the necessity of developing a separate perturbation theory for less regular surfaces as in the previous subsection. It is not clear whether the order of the perturbation error actually jumps in this manner when crossing from C1,α to C2 surfaces, or if this jump is an artifact of proof.

3.3. H2 extensions from C2 surfaces

The analysis of the trace and narrow band methods that we carry out in later sections requires us to extend the solution \wu∈H2⁢(γ) of (19) to tubular neighborhoods 𝒩⁢(δ) with the property

(59) ‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ12⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ);

we recall that \Nd is defined in (29). The distance function lift \bPd provides a natural way to achieve this upon setting u=\wu∘\bPd, namely

u⁢(\bx)=\wu⁢(\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈𝒩⁢(δ).

However, this is problematic because it requires \bPd to be of class C2, and thus γ of class C3, for (59) to hold. We now construct an extension that satisfies (59) for γ of class C2. Our approach employs a regularization \de of the signed distance function d and construction of a regularized surface \gae close to γ, with the regularization parameter ε appropriately related to the desired value of δ above. We begin by describing properties of this regularization.

Regularization. Recall that given γ of class C2 there exists a sufficiently thin tubular neighborhood 𝒩 so that the signed distance function d to γ satisfies d∈C2⁢(𝒩). Let δ>0 and ε=c⁢δ≤δ2 be sufficiently small so that the tubular neighborhood 𝒩⁢(δ) of width δ satisfies the property

𝒩⁢(δ+2⁢ε)⊂𝒩.

Let \Be:=B⁢(0,ε) be the ball of center 0 and radius ε, \re be a smooth and radially symmetric mollifier with support in \Be and

\de⁢(\bx):=d⋆\re⁢(\bx)=∫\Bed⁢(\bx−\by)⁢\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by∀\bx∈𝒩⁢(δ)

be a regularized distance function. This function \de induces the smooth surface

\gae:={\bx∈𝒩:\de(\bx)=0},

but is not the signed distance function to \gae, which we denote \wde. The following properties are immediate from the previous definitions.

{lemma}

[properties of \de] If d∈C2⁢(𝒩¯), then \de satisfies

‖d−\de‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))+ε⁢‖∇(d−\de)‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)

and ‖D2⁢\de‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯). Moreover, the surface \gae is smooth and the Hausdorff distance \distH⁢(γ,\gae) between γ and \gae satisfies

\distH⁢(γ,\gae)≲ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)

provided ε is small enough so that C⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)≤12 for a suitable constant C.

Proof.

Since \re is radially symmetric, we have that

(d−\de)⁢(\bx)=∫\Be(d⁢(\bx)−∇d⁢(\bx)⋅\by−d⁢(\bx−\by))⁢\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by

and

∇(d−\de)⁡(\bx)=∫\Be(∇d⁢(\bx)−∇d⁢(\bx−\by))⁢\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by.

These relationships imply the first assertion upon employing a Taylor expansion of d and the Lipschitz nature of ∇d, respectively. We also note that

D2⁢\de⁢(\bx)=∫\Be∇d⁢(\bx−\by)⊗∇\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by=∫\Be∇(d⁢(\bx−\by)−d⁢(\bx))⊗∇\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by

because ∫\Be∇\re⁢(\by)⁢𝑑\by=0 in view of the radial symmetry of \re. The second relationship bounding D2⁢\de then follows from the Lipschitz nature of ∇d (i.e. |∇(d⁢(\bx−\by)−d⁢(\bx))|≲ε, \by∈Bε) and the standard property ‖∇ρε‖L1⁢(Bε)≲ε−1 of the mollifier.

To establish the smoothness of γε, note that the closeness of ∇d and ∇\de implies that ∇\de is nondegenerate for C⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)≤1/2. The smoothness of γε then follows from the implicit function theorem.

The last assertion is a consequence of the nondegeneracy of the distance function: Given \by∈\gae let \bx=\bPd⁢(\by)=\by−d⁢(\by)⁢∇d⁢(\by)∈γ be the closest point to \by and note that

|\by−\bx|=|d⁢(\by)|=|d⁢(\by)−\de⁢(\by)|≲ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯).

Likewise, given \bx∈γ let \by⁢(s)=\bx+s⁢∇d⁢(\bx). There is s∈(−ε,ε) such that \de⁢(\by⁢(s))=0. To see this, note that d⁢(\by⁢(s))=±ε for s=±ε and

\de⁢(\by⁢(ε))≥d⁢(\by⁢(ε))−C⁢ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)=ε⁢(1−ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯))>0

provided C⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)≤12; similarly \de⁢(\by⁢(−ε))<0. Letting \by=\by⁢(s) be such that \de⁢(\by⁢(s))=0, we note that \bx=\bPd⁢(\by), and so arguing as before we have that

|\by−\bx|=|d⁢(\by)|=|d⁢(\by)−\de⁢(\by)|≲ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯),

which concludes the proof. ∎

We recall that \wde is the signed distance function to the zero level set \gae of \de. Consider the C∞ lift

(60) \bPe⁢(\bx):=\bx−\wde⁢(\bx)⁢∇\wde⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈𝒩⁢(δ).

It is natural and useful for later considerations to compare tubular neighborhoods dictated by d and \wde. Let

𝒩ε⁢(δε):={\bx∈ℝn+1:|\wde⁢(\bx)|≤δε},

where we choose δε as follows depending on δ and ε. Given \bx∈𝒩⁢(δ) let \wx∈γ be the point at shortest distance, whence |\bx−\wx|≤δ, and let \bxe∈\gae be a point such that |\wx−\bxe|≤C⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢ε2 which is guaranteed to exist because distH⁢(γ,γε)≤C⁢ε2⁢|d|≤ε in view of Lemma 3.3 (properties of \de). Therefore

|\wde(\bx)|=\dist(\bx,\gae)≤|\bx−\bxe|≤|\bx−\wx|+|\wx−\bxe|≤δ+C|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)ε2≤δ+ε=:δε,

provided C⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≤1; note that δε≤32⁢δ. This implies

(61) 𝒩⁢(δ)⊂𝒩ε⁢(δε).

Similarly, using again C⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)≤1 in conjunction with Lemma 3.3 yields

𝒩ε⁢(δε)⊂𝒩⁢(δε+ε)=𝒩⁢(δ+2⁢ε)⊂𝒩.

The next lemma and corollary study important properties of \wde and \bPe, in particular how derivatives degenerate with ε.

{lemma}

[properties of \wde] The function \wde∈C∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) and satisfies

‖\wde‖W∞2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))+ε⁢‖\wde‖W∞3⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).

Moreover, the following error estimates hold

‖∇(d−\wde)‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩),‖1−∇d⋅∇\wde‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2.
Proof.

Since \de⁢(\bx)=0 and |∇\de⁢(\bx)|≥12 for all \bx∈\gae, fix \bx0∈\gae and a system of coordinates such that \bx=(\bx′,xn+1) is a generic point and ∇\de⁢(\bx0) points in the (n+1)-th coordinate direction. The Implicit Function Theorem guarantees the existence of a ball B in ℝn centered at \bx0′ and a C∞ function ψ:B→ℝ such that

\de⁢(\bx′,ψ⁢(\bx′))=0∀\bx′∈B.

In other words, \gae is locally described in B as a graph xn+1=ψ⁢(\bx′) for \bx′∈B. It is not difficult but tedious to see that

‖ψ‖W∞2⁢(B) ≲‖\de‖W∞2⁢(\Nd)≲‖d‖W∞2⁢(𝒩),
‖ψ‖W∞3⁢(B) ≲‖\de‖W∞3⁢(\Nd)≲1ε⁢‖d‖W∞2⁢(𝒩),

which translates into the first estimates for \wde

‖\wde‖W∞2⁢(\Nd)≲‖d‖W∞2⁢(𝒩),‖\wde‖W∞3⁢(\Nd)≲1ε⁢‖d‖W∞2⁢(𝒩).

To prove the error estimates, let \bx∈\Nd⊂𝒩 and note that

∇\wde⁢(\bx)=∇\wde⁢(\by)=∇\de⁢(\by)|∇\de⁢(\by)|,∇d⁢(\bx)=∇d⁢(\bw)

with \by=\bx−\wde⁢(\bx)⁢∇\wde⁢(\bx)∈\gae and \bw=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)∈γ. Hence,

|\bw−\by|≤|\bw−\bx|+|\by−\bx|≤δ+δε≤52⁢δ

because of (61). Since |∇d⁢(\by)|=1, we now write

∇d⁢(\bx)−∇\wde⁢(\bx)=∇d⁢(\bw)−∇d⁢(\by)+∇d⁢(\by)−∇\de⁢(\by)+∇\de⁢(\by)|∇\de⁢(\by)|⁢(|∇\de⁢(\by)|−|∇d⁢(\by)|)

and estimate pairs of terms on the right hand side separately. Since d∈W∞2⁢(𝒩), we get

|∇d⁢(\bw)−∇d⁢(\by)|≤|\bw−\by|⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩),

and using Lemma 3.3 (properties of \de) we also obtain

||∇d⁢(\by)|−|∇\de⁢(\by)||≤|∇d⁢(\by)−∇\de⁢(\by)|≤ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢<δ|⁢d|W∞2⁢(𝒩),

whence the first error estimate follows

|∇d⁢(\bx)−∇\wde⁢(\bx)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)∀\bx∈\Nd.

To show the desired second error estimate we observe that |1−∇d⁢(\bx)⋅∇\wde⁢(\bx)|=12⁢|∇d⁢(\bx)−∇\wde⁢(\bx)|2. This concludes the proof. ∎

{corollary}

[property of \bPε] The lift \bPe belongs to C∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) and satisfies

|\bPe|W∞2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

for suitable constants C1,C2 so that C1⁢δ≤ε≤δ2 and C2⁢ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≤1.

Proof.

Differentiate the k-th component of \bPe with respect to xi and xj to obtain

∂i⁢j\bPε,k=−∂i⁢j2\wde⁢∂k\wde−∂i\wde⁢∂j⁢k2\wde−∂j\wde⁢∂i⁢k2\wde−\wde⁢∂i⁢j⁢k3\wde,

whence invoking Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) yields

‖D2⁢\bPe‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)+δε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

because of |∇\wde|=1 and (61). This completes the proof. ∎

Given a function \wu∈H2⁢(γ) we are now ready to introduce an H2 extension to 𝒩⁢(δ). For this, we assume that δ is sufficiently small so that (61) is valid. We first define the auxiliary function \ue=\wu∘\bQe:\gae→ℝ, where \bQe=\bPe−1:\gae→γ, and then the extension u=\ue∘\bPe:𝒩⁢(δ)→ℝ, namely

(62) u⁢(\bx):=\ue⁢(\bx−\wde⁢(\bx)⁢∇\wde⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈𝒩⁢(δ).

Consequently, we realize that u=\wu∘\bQe∘\bPe. We introduce the notation \bQe to avoid confusion between \bQe∘\bPe:𝒩⁢(δ)→γ and the identity. We recall that the coarea formula

(63) ∫𝒩⁢(δ)g=∫𝒩⁢(δ)g⁢|∇d|=∫−δδ∫{d−1⁢(s)}g⁢𝑑σs,

is valid for any integrable function g:𝒩⁢(δ)→ℝ [Theorem 3.14, Evans and Gariepy]. We will use this formula next and later in this chapter.

{proposition}

[H2 extension] Let ε and δ be as in Corollary 3.3 (property of \bPe), and assume that ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≤c for a sufficiently small constant c. If \wu∈H2⁢(γ), then u∈H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) and

‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ12⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).

Moreover, the trace of u on γ coincides with \wu, that is u an H2 extension of \wu.

Proof.

In view of (27), the i-partial derivative of u reads

∂iu=∑j=1n+1(δi⁢j−\wde⁢∂i⁢j2\wde)⁢∂¯j⁢\ue∘\bPe

where ∂¯j⁢\ue stands for the j-component of ∇\gae\ue. We use again (27) to obtain

∇⁢∂ju= −∑j=1n+1(∇\wde⁢∂i⁢j2\wde+\wde⁢∂i⁢j2∇\wde)⁢∂¯j⁢\ue∘\bPe
+∑j=1n+1(δi⁢j−\wde⁢∂i⁢j2\wde)⁢(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢∇\gae∂¯j⁢\ue∘\bPe.

Setting Λ:=1+|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) and applying Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) yields

|D2⁢u|≲Λ⁢(|∇\gae\ue∘\bPe|+|∇\gae2\ue∘\bPe|).

We reduce the computation of integrals in the bulk 𝒩⁢(δ) to integrals on parallel surfaces \gae⁢(s):={\bx∈ℝn+1:\wde⁢(\bx)=s} via the coarea formula (63). Since |∇\wde|=1 in view of (61) the co-area formula implies

∫𝒩⁢(δ)|D2⁢u⁢(\bx)|2⁢𝑑\bx ≲Λ2⁢∫𝒩⁢(δ)∑k=12|∇\gaek\ue⁢(\bPe⁢(\bx))|2⁢|∇\wde⁢(\bx)|⁢d⁢\bx
≤Λ2⁢∫−δεδε∫\gae⁢(s)∑k=12|∇\gaek\ue⁢(\bPe⁢(\bx))|2⁢d⁢σε,s⁢(\bx)⁢d⁢s
≲δ⁢Λ2⁢∫\gae∑k=12|∇\gaek\ue⁢(\bx)|2⁢d⁢σε⁢(\bx),

Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) immediately yields

∫γε|∇γεuε⁢(\bPε⁢(\bx))|2⁢𝑑σε⁢(\bx)≲∫γ|∇γ\wu⁢(\bx)|2⁢𝑑σ⁢(\bx).

In order to relate second derivatives of uε on γε to those of \wu on γ, we apply (50) with γε playing the role of γ and Γ=γ. Then

∇γεuε⁢(\bPε⁢(\bx))=(𝐈−\wde⁢\bWε)−1⁢(\bx)⁢(\bI−\bnuγ⁢(\bx)⊗\bnuε⁢(\bx)\bnuγ⁢(\bx)⋅\bnuε⁢(\bx))⁢∇γ\wu⁢(\bx)\bx∈γ,

and after applying this formula again to ∇γεuε⁢(\bPε⁢(\bx)) we obtain

|Dγε2⁢uε⁢(\bPε⁢(\bx))|≤|Dγ⁢𝐌⁢(\bx)|⁢|∇γ\wu⁢(\bx)|+|𝐌⁢(\bx)|⁢|Dγ2⁢\wu⁢(\bx)|,

where 𝐌⁢(\bx)=(𝐈−\wde⁢\bWε)−1⁢(\bx)⁢(\bI−\bnuγ⁢(\bx)⊗\bnuε⁢(\bx)\bnuγ⁢(\bx)⋅\bnuε⁢(\bx)). We thus wish to bound ‖M‖W∞1⁢(γ). First we note that combining the bound on the Hausdorff distance between γ and γε from Lemma 3.3 (properties of \de) with ‖\wde‖W∞2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) from Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) yields for \bx∈γ that the eigenvalues of \wde⁢(\bx)⁢\bWε⁢(\bx) are bounded by C⁢ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩¯)2, which is less than 12 under the assumption that ε⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) is sufficiently small; thus ‖(\bI−\wde⁢\bWε)−1‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≤2. In addition, combining the same assumption with ε≃δ and Lemma 3.3 yields

‖1−\bnuγ⋅\bnuε‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2≲ε2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2≤12,

so that \bnuγ⋅\bnuε≥1/2 and

‖\bI−\bnuγ⊗\bnuε\bnuγ⋅\bnuε‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≲1;

thus ‖𝐌‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≲1. In order to bound the derivatives of 𝐌, we note that for a matrix 𝐀 there holds ∂i𝐀−1=−𝐀−1⁢(∂i𝐀)⁢𝐀−1. For 𝐀=\bI−\wde⁢\bWε, we use Lemmas 3.3 and 3.3, |∇\wde|=1, and the assumption C1⁢δ≤ε to deduce in \Nd

|∂i𝐀| =|(∂i\wde)⁢\bWε+\wde⁢∂i\bWε|
≲‖\wde‖W∞2(𝒩(δ)+δ⁢‖\wde‖W∞3⁢(𝒩)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).

Since we have already established that ‖𝐀−𝟏‖𝐋∞⁢(\Nd)≲𝟏, we infer that |(\bI−\wde⁢\bWε)−1|W∞1(\Nd≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩). A similar calculation for \bI−\bnuγ⊗\bnuε\bnuγ⋅\bnuε, while recalling that \bnuγ⋅\bnuε≥1/2, yields |𝐌|W∞1⁢(γ)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) and, after applying Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence), gives

‖Dγε2⁢uε‖L2⁢(γε)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢(‖∇γ\wu‖L2⁢(γ)+‖Dγ2⁢\wu‖L2⁢(γ)).

The asserted estimate follows from applying again the co-area formula (63), which leads to

∫𝒩⁢(δ)|u|2+|∇u|2+|D2⁢u|2≲δ⁢Λ2⁢∫γ|\wu|2+|∇γ\wu|2+|D2⁢\wu|2.

Finally, we take \bx∈γ, note that \bQe⁢(\bPe⁢(\bx))=\bx, and compute

u⁢(\bx)=\wu∘\bQe∘\bPe⁢(\bx)=\wu⁢(\bx)

to realize that u is indeed an extension of \wu to 𝒩⁢(δ). ∎

We now derive the elliptic PDE’s satisfied by \ue on \gae and u in 𝒩⁢(δ). For \wu∈H2⁢(γ), let \wf=−Δγ⁢\wu∈L2,#⁢(γ) and consider the extension \wfe to \gae

\wfe:=\wf∘\bQe.
{lemma}

[PDE satisfied by \ue] If γ is closed and of class C2, then \gae is also closed and of class C∞, and the extension \ue=\wu∘\bQe satisfies on \gae

−\wmue⁢div\gae⁢(1\wmue⁢\wbAe⁢∇\gae\ue)=\wfe,

where \wbAe:=(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢Π⁢(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)∘\bQe, Π stands for the orthogonal projection Π=(\bI−∇d⊗∇d) on γ and \wmue:=\qeq∘\bQe reads

\wmue=det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢(∇d⋅∇\wde)∘\bQe.
Proof.

Given \wv∈H1⁢(γ), let \tv=\ttv∘\bQe∈H1⁢(\gae). We resort to (49) to write

∇γ\wu=Π⁢(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢∇\gae\ue∘\bPeon ⁢γ,

because ∇\gae\ue∘\bPe=Πε⁢∇\gae\ue∘\bPe. This combined with (8) and Corollary 2.6 (integration by parts) on the closed surface \gae yields

∫γ∇γ\wu⋅∇γ\ttv=∫\gae1\wmue⁢\wbAe⁢∇\gae\ue⋅∇\gae\tv=−∫\gaediv\gae⁢(1\wmue⁢\wbAe⁢∇\gae\ue)⁢\tv

with \wmue=\qeq∘\bQe given by (53). Likewise,

∫γ\wf⁢\ttv=∫\gae1\wmue⁢\wfe⁢\tv.

Since the last two equalities hold for all \tv∈H1⁢(\gae), the assertion follows. ∎

We extend the function \wfe to 𝒩ε⁢(δε) as follows:

\fe:=\wfe∘\bPe=\wf∘\bQe∘\bPe.

Equivalently, given \bx∈𝒩ε⁢(δε) let \wx∈γ be the unique point such that for some s

\wx=\bx+s⁢∇\wde⁢(\bx)⇒\fe⁢(\bx)=\wf⁢(\wx).
{proposition}

[PDE satisfied by u] Let ε and δ be as in Corollary 3.3 (property of \bPe). The extension u∈H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) of \wu of Proposition 3.3 satisfies the PDE

−1\mue÷\mue⁢\bBe⁢∇u=\fe in 𝒩⁢(δ),

where

\bBe:=(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1⁢Πε⁢\bAe⁢Πε⁢(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1,

\bAe:=\wbAe∘\bPe with \wbAe given in Lemma 3.3, Πε=\bI−∇\wde⊗∇\wde, \mue is given by

\mue:=1\wmue∘\bPe⁢det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde),

and \wmue is defined in Lemma 3.3.

Proof.

We proceed as in Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension). Let γε⁢(s) be a parallel surface to \gae at distance s, and let |s|≤δε with δε=32⁢δ so that (61) holds. We first employ (50) to obtain the bilinear form for u on γε⁢(s). For δ sufficiently small Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) guarantees that (\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde) is invertible in 𝒩ε⁢(δε). Hence, if \bDe=(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1⁢Πε and \tv∈C0∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)), we restrict \tv to γε⁢(s), define the auxiliary function \ttv:=\tv∘\bPe−1∈C∞⁢(\gae) and observe that (50) reads on γε⁢(s)

∇\gae\ttv∘\bPe=\bDe⁢∇\tv,

where ∇\tv is the full gradient of \tv; this is because of the presence of the projection matrix Πε on the tangent hyperplane to γε⁢(s) in the definition of \bDe. We get

∫\gae1\wmue⁢\wbAe⁢∇\gae\ue⋅∇\gae\ttv=∫γε⁢(s)\mue⁢\bAe⁢\bDe⁢∇u⋅\bDe⁢∇\tv

where \wmue is given in Lemma 3.3 (PDE satisfied by \ue) and \mue is the surface measure density on \gae⁢(s) due to the change of variables, namely

\mue=1\wmue∘\bPe⁢\qeqε,s=1\wmue∘\bPe⁢det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)

according to (53). Similarly, the linear form for the forcing reads

∫\gae1\wmue⁢\wfe⁢\ttv=∫γε⁢(s)\mue⁢\fe⁢\tv.

Since the left hand sides of the previous integral expressions coincide, in view of Lemma 3.3, we now integrate over s∈(−δε,δε) and use the co-area formula (63) to convert the resulting integrals into bulk integrals

∫𝒩ε⁢(δε)\mue⁢\bAe⁢\bDe⁢∇u⋅\bDe⁢∇\tv =∫𝒩ε⁢(δε)\mue⁢\bAe⁢\bDe⁢∇u⋅\bDe⁢∇\tv⁢|∇\wde|
=∫−δεδε∫γε⁢(s)\mue⁢\bAe⁢\bDe⁢∇u⋅\bDe⁢∇\tv⁢d⁢σε,s⁢d⁢s
=∫−δεδε∫γε⁢(s)\fe⁢\tv⁢\mue⁢𝑑σε,s⁢𝑑s
=∫𝒩ε⁢(δε)\fe⁢\tv⁢\mue⁢|∇\wde|=∫𝒩ε⁢(δε)\fe⁢\tv⁢\mue,

because |∇\wde|=1 in 𝒩ε⁢(δε). Since 𝒩⁢(δ)⊂𝒩ε⁢(δε) according to (61), integration by parts gives

−∫𝒩⁢(δ)div⁢(\mue⁢\bDe⁢\bAe⁢\bDe⁢∇u)⁢\tv=∫𝒩⁢(δ)\fe⁢\tv⁢\mue∀v∈C0∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)),

whence the desired PDE follows after noticing that (\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1 and Πε commute. This completes the proof. ∎

4. Parametric Finite Element Method

The parametric method hinges on a surface approximation Γ “interpolating” the exact surface γ. Recall that the latter is assumed to be a closed, compact, orientable hypersurface in ℝn+1. In the lowest order case of piecewise linear polynomials, this corresponds to a polyhedral surface Γ whose vertices lie on γ or, more generally, sufficiently close to γ. The finite element space is then obtained in a classical way by mapping a finite element triplet defined on a reference element in ℝn to a facet of Γ in ℝn+1. The FEM requires a bi-Lipschitz map \bP:Γ→γ which is not necessarily the distance function lift \bPd. The latter is used for numerical analysis purposes only even for smooth surfaces.

There are two sources of error: the approximation of the exact surface γ by the polyhedral surface Γ, the so-called geometric consistency error, and the Galerkin error arising from the actual finite element approximation on Γ. In this section we quantify these two errors depending on the regularity of γ. For the former we rely on the discussion of section 3 that addresses the effect of perturbing γ. For γ of class C1,α we deal with a generic lift \bP:Γ→γ and obtain a suboptimal geometric consistency error. For C2 surfaces, instead, we resort to \bPd for error analysis and restore geometric optimality.

4.1. FEM on Lipschitz Parametric Surfaces.

Lipschitz Parametric Surfaces. We adopt the viewpoint that the surface γ is described as the deformation of an n-dimensional polyhedral surface \lingamma by a globally bi-Lipschitz homeomorphism \bP:\lingamma→γ⊂ℝn+1. Thus there exists L>0 such that for all \bx1,\bx2∈\lingamma

(64) L−1⁢|\bx1−\bx2|≤|\bx~1−\bx~2|≤L⁢|\bx1−\bx2|,\bx~i=\bP⁢(\bxi),i=1,2.

If γ is C2, we may take \bP=\bPd, but our current definition allows for much more flexibility in the choice of \bP. For example, if γ has nonempty boundary and is given as the graph of a function ψ:Ω→ℝn+1 with Ω⊂ℝn, then the map between \bx=(x,z)∈Γ with x∈Ω and z∈ℝ could be given by \bP⁢(x,z)=(x,ψ⁢(x))∈γ, i.e., the “vertical” graph map.

The (closed) facets of \lingamma are denoted by T, and form the collection \T={T}. We assume that these facets are all simplices and denote by S\T the set of interior faces of \T. Extension to other element shapes such as n-quadrilaterals and to nonconforming discretizations is possible under reasonable assumptions with minor modifications, but we do not elaborate them further. We let \bPT:T→ℝn+1 be the restriction of \bP to T. The partition \T of \lingamma induces the partition \T~={T~}T∈\T of γ upon setting

T~:=\bPT⁢(T)∀T∈\T.

Note that this non-overlapping parametrization of γ allows for Lipschitz surfaces rougher than globally C2. We additionally define macro patches

(65) \linpatchT=∪{T′:T′∩T≠∅},ω~T=\bP⁢(\linpatchT).

Let hT:=|T|1n and σ<∞ be the triangulation shape-regularity constant, i.e.

(66) σ:=sup\TmaxT∈\T⁡diam⁢(T)hT.

We further assume that the number of elements in each patch ωT is uniformly bounded. This assumption automatically follows from shape regularity for triangulations of Euclidean domains, but the situation is more subtle for surface triangulations as illustrated in Figure 1. Such a bound does for example hold if \lingamma is obtained by systematic refinement of an initial surface mesh with a uniform bound on the number of elements in a patch [DD07], or more generally using adaptive refinement strategies [BCM+16, BCMN13]. In addition, this implies that all elements in \linpatchT have uniformly equivalent diameters, as it happens for shape regular triangulations on Euclidean domains.
