To provide a parametric description, let T^ be the unit reference simplex, sometimes called the universal parametric domain. We denote by \linparamT:ℝn→ℝn+1 the affine map such that T=\linparamT⁢(T^) and note that (66) implies

(67) hT⁢|\bw|≲|D⁢\linparamT⁢\bw|≲hT⁢|\bw|,∀\bw∈ℝn.

Hereafter we omit to specify when the constants (possibly hidden in ≲ signs) depend on σ. As pointed out in [BP12], even if the initial surface approximation satisfies (67), this property might not hold for refinements unless the initial polyhedral surface approximates the exact surface well. We refer to [BCM+16, BCMN13] for a discussion on how to circumvent this in an adaptive strategy. However, since this work focusses on a-priori and a-posteriori error estimation rather that adaptivity, we assume (67) directly.

We are now ready to introduce the local non-overlapping parametrization \bchi of γ. Let \exactparamT:=\bP∘\linparamT:T^→T~ be the corresponding local parametrization of T~ and \bchi:={\bchiT}T∈\T; see Figure 2. We record for latter use that thanks to the Lipschitz properties (64) and (67), \exactparamT also satisfies

(68) hT⁢|\bw|≲|D⁢\exactparamT⁢(\by)⁢\bw|≲hT⁢|\bw|∀\bw∈ℝn,\by∈T^.

It turns out that it will be convenient to consider \bchiT to be defined on a larger domain than T, say ω^T⊂ℝn, so that \exactparamT=\bP∘\linparamT:ω^T→ω~T is a bi-Lipschitz local parametrization of γ: there exists a universal constant L≥1 such that for each fixed T∈\T and for all \bx~1=\exactparamT⁢(\by1),\bx~2=\exactparamT⁢(\by2)∈ω~T,

(69) L−1⁢hT⁢|\by1−\by2|≤|\bx~1−\bx~2|≤L⁢hT⁢|\by1−\by2|;

in this case \bchi:={\bchiT}T∈\T is an overlapping parametrization of γ. We further assume that \bP⁢(𝐯)=𝐯 for all vertices 𝐯 of \lingamma, so that \linparamT is the nodal Lagrange interpolant of \exactparamT into linears.

We finally note that a function \tv~T:T~→ℝ defines uniquely two functions \tv^T:T^→ℝ and \tvT:T→ℝ via the maps \bXiT and \bP, namely

(70) \tv^T⁢(\by):=\tv~T⁢(\exactparamT⁢(\by))∀\bx^∈T^ and \tvT⁢(\bx):=\tv~T⁢(\bP⁢(\bx))∀\bx∈T.

Moreover, each one of these functions induces the other two uniquely. Accordingly, we will use the symbol \tv for all three functions if no confusion arises.

Differential Geometry on Polyhedral Surfaces. We use the atlas {T^,T~,\bchiT}T∈\T, induced by the non-overlapping parametrization \bchi:={\bchiT}T∈\T, to describe γ in the spirit of Section 2. Likewise, we employ the atlas {T^,T,\bXT}T∈\T to describe the polyhedral surface Γ. In view of (68), the discrete first fundamental form \bgT and area element qT of Γ are given elementwise by

(71) \bgT:=(D⁢\bXT)t⁢D⁢\bXT,qT:=det\bgT,∀T∈\T.

and satisfy

(72) eigen⁢(\bgT)≈hT2,qT≈hTn,∀T∈\T.

They give rise to the piecewise constant functions \bgΓ:={\bgT}T∈\T and qΓ:={qT}T∈\T. Similar properties are enjoyed by \bchi, which imply that the stability constant S\bchi defined in (38) is purely geometric and independent of meshsize:

(73) S\bchi≈1.

In addition, notice that (68) and (69) imply that

(74) C1≤qqΓ≤C2

for constants C1, C2 independent of discretization parameters. Moreover, the vector \bNT:=∑i=1n+1det([\bej,D\bXT)])\bej is perpendicular to T∈\T provided {\bej}j=1n+1 are the canonical unit vectors of ℝn+1. This vector satisfies |\bNT|=qT and yields the unit normal to T

\bnuT:=\bNT|\bNT|∀T∈\T,

and corresponding piecewise constant unit normal vector \bnuΓ:={\bnuT}T∈\T to Γ.

Given a function \tv:Γ→ℝ, its tangential gradient ∇Γ\tv and Laplace-Beltrami operator ΔΓ⁢\tv over Γ obey the formulas

(75) ∇\tv^=(D⁢\bX)t⁢∇Γ\tv,∇Γ\tv=(D⁢\bX)⁢\bgΓ−1⁢∇\tv^,

and

(76) ΔΓ⁢\tv=1qΓ⁢div⁢(qΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢∇\tv^),

where \tv^:T^→ℝ is defined in (70). The strong form of ΔΓ⁢\tv is well defined only elementwise because qΓ⁢\bgΓ−1 is piecewise constant and so discontinuous over \T. To find the correct strong form we start from the weak form (19), split the integral over elements and use Corollary 2.6 (integration by parts) to obtain

∫Γ∇Γ\tv⋅∇Γw =∑T∈\T−∫Tw⁢ΔΓ⁢\tv+∫∂Tw⁢∇Γ\tv⋅\bmuT
=∑T∈\T−∫Tw⁢ΔΓ⁢\tv+∑S∈𝒮∫Sw⁢[∇Γ\tv],

where the jump residual is computed over each face S∈𝒮 of elements of \T via

(77) [∇Γv]:=∇Γ\tv+⋅\bmu++∇Γ\tv−⋅\bmu−

and T±∈\T are such that S=T+∩T− and \tv±,\bmu± are the restrictions of \tv and the outer unit normal to ∂T± which is parallel to T±. We then see that ΔΓ⁢\tv consists of the absolutely continuous part (76) with respect to surface measure defined elementwise and the singular part (77) supported on the skeleton of \T. This formula makes sense for functions which are piecewise H2 and globally H1, such as continuous piecewise polynomials.

Parametric Finite Element Method. In this work, we focus on continuous piecewise linear finite elements and polyhedral surface approximations. Let 𝒫 be the space of linear polynomials and let \V⁢(\T) be the space of continuous piecewise linear polynomial functions over Γ, namely

\V⁢(\T):={V∈C0⁢(Γ)|V|T=V^∘\bX−1⁢ for some ⁢V^∈𝒫,T∈\T}.

The finite element space associated with the Laplace-Beltrami equation over Γ is the restriction of \V⁢(\T) to functions with vanishing mean

\V#⁢(\T):=\V⁢(\T)∩L2,#⁢(Γ).

We define \interp:C0⁢(Γ)→\V⁢(\T) to be the Lagrange interpolation operator and use the same notation for vector-valued functions.

We are now ready to introduce the parametric FEM: seek U:=U\T∈\V#⁢(\T) that solves

(78) ∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇ΓV=∫ΓF⁢V∀V∈\V#⁢(\T),

where F∈L2,#⁢(Γ) is an approximation of f∈L2,#⁢(γ) to be specified later. Lax-Milgram theory guarantees that U∈\V#⁢(\T) is well defined. Observe that because F∈L2,#⁢(Γ), we also have

(79) ∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇ΓV=∫ΓF⁢V∀V∈\V⁢(\T).

Since the exact problem (19) and discrete problem (79) are defined on different domains γ and Γ, the error u−U does not satisfy Galerkin orthogonality in either one. The next statement accounts for geometric inconsistency and uses the convention (70) for the generic lift \bP.

{lemma}

[Galerkin quasi-orthogonality] Let \bE and \bEΓ be defined in (36) and (37) via the parametrizations \bchi=\bP∘\bX and χΓ=\bX. Then, for all V∈\V⁢(\T), there holds

(80) ∫Γ∇Γ(u−U)⋅∇ΓV=∫Γ(f⁢qqΓ−F)⁢V+∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓV,

and

(81) ∫γ∇γ(\wu−\wU)⋅∇γ\wV=∫γ(f~−\wF⁢qΓq)⁢\wV+∫γ∇γ\wU⋅\bE⁢∇γ\wV.
Proof.

We only prove (80) as (81) follows similarly. Using the equation (79) satisfied by U and the consistency relation (34), we obtain

∫Γ∇Γ(u−U)⋅∇ΓV=∫γ∇γ\wu⋅∇γ\wV+∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓV−∫ΓF⁢V.

The first term on the right-hand side equals ∫γf~⁢V=∫Γf⁢qqΓ⁢V, in view of (19) and (8), and thus yields (80). ∎

4.2. Geometric Consistency

In this section we study the error inherent to approximating γ with Γ. The polyhedral surface Γ is always represented by a lift \bP whose regularity depends on that of γ. We present two scenarios depending on such regularity. We first assume that γ is piecewise C1,α and globally Lipschitz, and later assume that γ is C2 and exploit the distance function lift \bPd to improve the error estimates.

Uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs estimate on Γ. The analysis below takes advantage of the uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs estimate on Γ

(82) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)∀\tv∈H#1⁢(Γ),

where the constant hidden in the above inequality is independent of Γ. Note that when γ is of class C1,α, 0<α≤1, Lemma 3.1 (uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs constant) implies that (82) follows from (73) and (74), which in turn are consequences of assumption (64). Furthermore, when γ is of class C2 and \bP=\bPd, the discussion in Section 3.2 yields conditions which are also easy to verify: Γ⊂𝒩⁢(1/2⁢K∞) and \bnu⋅\bnuΓ≥c>0 on Γ.

Geometric Estimators. Since γ is described by \bchi and Γ by \bX it is natural to consider the difference D⁢\bchi−D⁢\bX as a measure of geometric mismatch [BCM+16]. We thus start with the geometric element indicator

(83) λT:=‖D⁢(\bP−\interp⁢\bP)‖L∞⁢(T)=‖D⁢\bP−\bI‖L∞⁢(T)∀T∈\T

and the corresponding geometric estimator

(84) λ\T⁢(Γ):=maxT∈\T⁡λT.

We have seen that the relative measure of accuracy (39) controls the geometric error. In this vein, we observe that D⁢\bchiT=D⁢\bP⁢D⁢\bXT because \exactparamT=\bP∘\linparamT, whence such measure satisfies

(85) max\by∈T^⁡|D⁢(\exactparamT−\linparamT)⁢(\by)|min⁡{|D−⁢\exactparamT⁢(\by)|,|D−⁢\linparamT⁢(\by)|}≤S\bchi⁢λT∀T∈\T,

with a stability constant S\bchi≈1 according to (38). Therefore λ\T⁢(Γ) is expected to dominate the geometric error for surfaces of class C1,α with 0<α<1. This is consistent with Lemma 3.1 (perturbation error estimate for C1,α surfaces).

For C2 surfaces, however, λ\T⁢(Γ) is suboptimal in that it overestimates the influence of geometry [BD19]. According to Lemma 54 (perturbation error estimate for C2 surfaces) and Lemma 3.2 (error estimates for normals), the following quantities should play a crucial role in dealing with geometry via the auxiliary lift \bPd

(86) βT:=‖\bP−\interp⁢\bP‖L∞⁢(T),β\T⁢(Γ):=maxT∈\T⁡βT,

and

(87) μT:=βT+λT2,μ\T⁢(Γ):=maxT∈\T⁡μT;

we stress that μ\T⁢(Γ) is formally of higher order than λ\T⁢(Γ). We will show below that μ\T⁢(Γ) indeed controls the geometric error and accounts for the “superconvergence” property associated with the projection \bPd along the normal direction to γ alluded to at the end of section 3.2.

Geometric Consistency Error for C1,α Surfaces. We now quantify the geometric error incurred when replacing γ by its polygonal approximation Γ.

{corollary}

[geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces] If \bX and \bchi satisfy (67) and (68), then for all T∈\T we have

(88) ‖1−q−1⁢qΓ‖L∞⁢(T^),‖\bI−\bgΓ⁢\bg−1‖L∞⁢(T^),‖\bnuΓ−\bnu‖L∞⁢(T)≲λT,

where the hidden constants depend on S\bchi≈1 defined in (38). Moreover,

(89) ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(T^)+‖\bEΓ‖L∞⁢(T^)≲λT∀T∈\T.
Proof.

We first point out that (67) and (68) yield S\bchi≈1 according to (73). The asserted estimates follow from Lemma 3.1 (error estimates for \bg and q) and Lemma 3.2 (error estimate for normals) in conjunction with (47) and (85). ∎

Geometric Consistency Error for C2 Surfaces. We now take advantage of the lift \bPd for error representation. We recall that, as in section 3.2, the parametrizations of γ and Γ are given by \bchi=\bPd∘\bX and \bX. In particular, the infinitesimal area element q of γ is defined using \bPd and so are the consistency matrices \bE, \bEΓ; see (51), (52). To improve upon Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces) we need more stringent geometric assumptions than simply Γ⊂𝒩. These assumptions are somewhat technical but are checkable computationally with information extracted from \bP but without access to \bPd [BD19]. We list them now.

  • •

    Distance between γ and Γ. Invoking the closest point property of the distance function projection \bPd and the definition (86) of β\T⁢(Γ), we see that |\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|≤|\bx−\bP⁢(\bx)|≤β\T⁢(Γ) for all \bx∈Γ. We thus assume that Γ is sufficiently close to γ in the sense that

    (90) β\T⁢(Γ)<12⁢K∞⇒Γ⊂𝒩,

    according to (48). Therefore, the estimates of section 3.2 are valid. Moreover, the discrepancy between the two lifts satisfies for all T∈\T

    |\bP⁢(\bx)−\bPd⁢(\bx)|≤|\bP⁢(\bx)−\bx|+|\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|≤2⁢|\bx−\bP⁢(\bx)|≤2⁢βT∀\bx∈T.
  • •

    Mismatch between \bP and \bPd. We assume that

    (91) \bPd∘\bP−1⁢(T~)⊂ω~T∀T∈\T,

    where ω~T is the patch around T~ within γ. If \bx~=\bP⁢(\bx)∈γ for \bx∈Γ, then

    (92) |\bx~−\bPd∘\bP−1⁢(\bx~)|=|\bP⁢(\bx)−\bPd⁢(\bx)|≤2⁢βT∀\bx∈T.

    and all T∈\T. Since γ is of class C2, we expect βThT→0 as hT→0 and realize that (91) is always valid asymptotically. We emphasize that it is possible to check (91) computationally without accessing \bPd [BD19].

{corollary}

[geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces] If (90) and (74) hold, then so do the following estimates for all T∈\T

(93) ‖d‖L∞⁢(T)≲βT,‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(T)≲λT,‖1−q−1⁢qΓ‖L∞⁢(T)≲μT,

where all the geometric quantities are defined using the parametrizations \bchi=\bPd∘\bX and \bX. Moreover,

(94) ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(T),‖\bEΓ‖L∞⁢(T)≲μT∀T∈\T.
Proof.

The first estimate in (93) is trivial from the definition (86) of βT, whereas the second estimate in (93) is a consequence of (58). The third estimate in (93) results from (57) and (58). With these estimates at hand, the estimate for \bE in (94) comes from (56) and that for \bEΓ is similar. ∎

We conclude with a technical result assessing the mismatch between \bP and \bPd. We motivate it with the following simpler L∞-estimate valid for all T∈\T

‖w~−w~∘\bPd∘\bP−1‖L∞⁢(T~)≲‖∇γw~‖L∞⁢(ω~T)⁢βT∀\bx∈T.

This is a trivial consequence of the property (92) for \bx~∈T~

|w~⁢(\bx~)−w~⁢(\bPd∘\bP−1⁢(\bx~))|≤‖∇γw~‖L∞⁢(ω~T)⁢|\bx~−\bPd∘\bP−1⁢(\bx~)|≤2⁢‖∇γw~‖L∞⁢(ω~T)⁢βT.

The estimate below is L2-based and its proof entails regularization by convolution [BD19, Lemma 3.4].

{proposition}

[mismatch between \bP and \bPd] Assume that (67) as well as the assumptions (74), (90) and (91) hold. Then there exists λ∗>0 such for w~∈H1⁢(γ) and T∈\T we have

‖w~−w~∘\bPd∘\bP−1‖L2⁢(T~)≲βT⁢‖w~‖H1⁢(ω~T)

provided λT≤λ∗ and ω~T is a patch in γ around T~.

Proof.

We proceed in several steps.

Step 1: Reduction to ℝn. Fix T∈\T and recall that \bchiT=\bP∘\bXT satisfies (68) and maps the reference patch ω^T into ω~T. For notational ease, let

ψ=\bPd∘\bP−1:γ→γ,ψ^=\bchiT−1∘ψ∘\bchiT:ω^T→ω^T.

Given w~∈H1⁢(γ), let w^=w~∘\bchiT:ω^T→ℝ, and note that w^∈H1⁢(ω^T) because \bchiT is Lipschitz. We change variables via \bchiT to T^ and invoke the non-degeneracy property (42) to obtain

‖w~−w~∘ψ‖L2⁢(T~)≲hTn/2⁢‖w^−w^∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^).

The assumption \bPd∘\bP−1⁢(T~)⊂ω~T given in (91) is equivalent to ψ^⁢(T^)⊂ω^T and is sufficient to ensure that the quantity on the right hand side is well-defined.

Since w^ is defined on ω^T⊂ℝn, and its boundary is Lipschitz, there is a universal extension operator E:H1⁢(ω^T)→H1⁢(ℝn) which is bounded both in L2 and in the H1-seminorm [Ste70]; this is the so-called Calderón operator. We relabel E⁢w^ to be w^, and thus assume it is bounded in H1⁢(ℝn) while satisfying

|w^|H1⁢(ℝn)≲|w^|H1⁢(ω^T).

Step 2: Mollification. We now regularize w^ by convolution with a standard smooth mollifier supported in the ball B⁢(0,ε) centered at 0 with radius ε>0 to be determined. If Ω⊂ℝn is an arbitrary domain, it is well known that

‖w^−w^ε‖L2⁢(Ω)≲ε⁢|w^|H1⁢(Ω+B⁢(0,ε)),
|w^ε|W∞1⁢(Ω)≲ε−n/2⁢|w^|H1⁢(Ω+B⁢(0,ε)).

We may now write, without restriction on ε, that

‖w^−w^∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^)≲‖w^−w^ε‖L2⁢(T^)+‖w^ε−w^ε∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^)+‖w^ε∘ψ^−w^∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^).

We estimate the first term using the first formula above for the mollifier

‖w^−w^ε‖L2⁢(T^)≲ε⁢|w^|H1⁢(ℝn)≲ε⁢|w^|H1⁢(ω^T).

Similarly, changing variables via the map ψ^, which turns out to be Lipschitz in view of (42) and (68), and applying the restriction ψ^⁢(T^)⊂ω^T stated in (91), we find that

‖(w^ε−w^)∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^)≲‖w^ε−w^‖L2⁢(ω^T)≲ε⁢|w^|H1⁢(ω^T).

Step 3: Estimate for ‖w^ε−w^ε∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^). Let {\byi} be a lattice on ℝn with minimum distance between \byi and \byj (i≠j) proportional to ε and such that {B⁢(\byi,ε)} covers ℝn. The set {B⁢(\byi,M⁢ε)} then has finite overlap for any M≥1, with the maximum cardinality of the overlap depending on M. We choose

ε=sup\by∈T^|\by−ψ^⁢(\by)|⇒‖w^ε−w^ε∘ψ^‖L∞⁢(B⁢(\byi,ε)∩T^)≲ε⁢|w^ε|W∞1⁢(B⁢(\byi,2⁢ε))

Applying the second property of mollifiers given above yields

|w^ε|W∞1⁢(B⁢(\byi,2⁢ε))≲ε−n/2⁢|w^|H1⁢(B⁢(\byi,3⁢ε)),

whence

‖w^ε−w^ε∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^)2 ≲εn⁢∑i‖w^ε−w^ε∘ψ^‖L∞⁢(B⁢(\byi,ε)∩T^)2
≲ε2⁢∑i|w^|H1⁢(B⁢(\byi,3⁢ε))2≲ε2⁢|w^|H1⁢(ℝn)2≲ε2⁢|w^|H1⁢(ω^T)2.

Step 4: Bound on ε. Making use of the bi-Lipschitz character (68), we get

|\by−ψ^⁢(\by)| =|\bchiT−1⁢(\bchiT⁢(\by))−\bchiT−1⁢(ψ⁢(\bchi⁢(\by)))|
≤L⁢hT−1⁢|\bchiT⁢(\by)−ψ⁢(\bchi⁢(\by))|=L⁢hT−1⁢|\bx~−\bPd∘\bP−1⁢(\bx~)|,

where \bx~=\bchiT⁢(\by). Recalling (92) and the definition of ε, we thus obtain

ε≤2⁢L⁢hT−1⁢βT.

We now gather the estimates of Steps 2 and 3. Mapping from T^ to T~ and back via \bchiT, and utilizing (42) and (68), yields

‖w~−w~∘ψ‖L2⁢(T~)2 ≲hTn⁢‖w^−w^∘ψ^‖L2⁢(T^)2≲hTn⁢ε2⁢|w^|H1⁢(ω^T)2
≲hTn⁢hT−2⁢βT2⁢hT2−n⁢|w~|H1⁢(ω~T)2=βT2⁢|w~|H1⁢(ω~T)2.

This completes the proof. ∎

We conclude this section with a variant of Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd) which turns out to be instrumental for the study of the Narrow Band method discussed later in Section 6. {proposition}[Lipschitz perturbation] Let Ω1,Ω2⊂⊂Ω⊂ℝn+1 be Lipschitz bounded domains and \bL:Ω1→Ω2 be a bi-Lipschitz isomorphism. If

r:=max\bx∈Ω1⁡|\bL⁢(\bx)−\bx|

is sufficiently small so that (Ω1∪Ω2)+B⁢(0,r)⊂Ω then for all g∈H1⁢(Ω) we have

‖g−g∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1)≲r⁢‖g‖H1⁢(Ω).
Proof.

We now proceed as in Proposition 4.2: let \eps=r>0 and g\eps be a regularization of g by convolution with a standard smooth mollifier supported in the ball B⁢(0,\eps). We write

‖g−g∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1)≤‖g−g\eps‖L2⁢(Ω1)+‖g\eps−g\eps∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1)+‖g\eps∘\bL−g∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1)

and note that

‖g−g\eps‖L2⁢(Ω1)≲\eps⁢‖g‖H1⁢(Ω),‖g\eps∘\bL−g∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1)≲\eps⁢‖g‖H1⁢(Ω)

because \bL−1 is Lipschitz. To estimate ‖g\eps−g\eps∘\bL‖L2⁢(Ω1), we argue as in Step 3 of Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd). This completes the proof. ∎

4.3. A-Priori Error Analysis

In this section we derive a-priori error estimates in H1 and L2, namely estimates expressed in terms of regularity of the exact solution \wu of (18). Compared to the existing literature these estimates involve two lifts: \bPd and \bP. The former, based on the distance function d, is only used theoretically or to define a notion of error when comparing U with u~. The latter is generic and used in practice to define the finite element method, i.e., by setting F=f~∘\bP⁢qqΓ and the discrete parametrization \bX to be the interpolant of the continuous one χ=\bP∘\bX. Optimal orders of convergence are derived without the need to access the distance function.

We also address a gap in the literature. Existing proofs of optimal a priori estimates for surface FEMs employ the distance function lift \bPd=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx). However, when γ is C2, this map is only C1 because of the presence of ∇d in its definition. Thus given \wv∈H2⁢(γ), its extension \tv=\wv∘\bPd to Γ is only in H1 and not piecewise in H2 as is needed to prove optimal approximation order. Thus existing proofs that only employ the distance function lift require the assumption that γ be of class C3 in order to obtain optimal order error estimates in the standard way; cf. the work of Dziuk in [Dzi88] in which such error estimates were originally obtained.

As pointed out already in Theorem 2.5 (C1 distance function implies C1,1 surface), the distance function d to a C1,α surface is no better than Lipschitz in general. Therefore, the aforementioned strategy does not extend to C1,α surfaces. However, the best approximation property of the Galerkin method together with the geometric consistency estimates of Section 4.2 yields a-priori error estimates in H1. We present this discussion after that for C2 surfaces.

A-Priori Error Estimates for C2 Surfaces. The following lemma will be instrumental to prove optimal a priori error estimates for γ of class C2. It states that a function ∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd) can be approximated in H1⁢(Γ) to first order for a function \wu∈H2⁢(γ). The difficulty is that the composite function \wu∘\bPd∉H2⁢(Γ) whereas ∇γ\wu∘\bPd∈H1⁢(Γ). The proof exploits this property to restore optimal approximability of ∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd) in H1⁢(Γ).

{lemma}

[approximability in H1⁢(Γ)] Let γ be a surface of class C2 and \wu∈H2⁢(γ). Let K∞ be defined in (30) and β\T⁢(Γ) be given in (86). Then we have

(95) inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tV)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\T⁢|\wu|H2⁢(γ)+β\T⁢(Γ)⁢K∞⁢‖∇γ\wu‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

We know from Veeser [Vee16] that continuous and discontinuous piecewise polynomial approximations in H1 are equivalent. Even though this crucial result was originally proved for Euclidean domains, it proofs carries over with essentially no changes to the case of surface meshes

(96) inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tV)‖L2⁢(Γ)2≲∑T∈\Tinf\tVT∈\V⁢(T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tVT)‖L2⁢(T)2.

We refer to [CD15] for related results on surfaces. We thus fix T∈\T and argue over this element hereafter; recall that T~=\bPd⁢(T).

Applying the triangle inequality yields

|∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tVT)|≤|∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd)−ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)|+|ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)−∇Γ\tVT|.

Using (49), we next find that

|∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd)−ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)|=|ΠΓ⁢[d⁢\bW⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)]|≤K∞⁢|d|⁢|(∇γ\wu)∘\bPd|,

which along with (44) yields

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd)−ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)‖L2⁢(T)≲βT⁢K∞⁢‖∇γ\wu‖L2⁢(T~).

Next note that ΠΓ=\bI−\bnuΓ⊗\bnuΓ is constant over T. Therefore, ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)∈[H1⁢(T)]n+1 in T because \wu∈H2⁢(γ) implies ∇γ\wu∈[H1⁢(γ)]n+1 and \bPd is C1. In addition, ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd) is a tangent vector field on Γ. On the other hand, ∇Γ maps the affine functions ℙ1 onto the subspace of [ℙ0]n+1 tangent to Γ, so standard approximation theory leads to

inf\tVT∈\V⁢(T)‖𝐰−∇Γ\tVT‖L2⁢(T)≲hT⁢|𝐰|H1⁢(T)

for any tangent vector field 𝐰∈[H1⁢(T)]n+1 to Γ. Using that ∇\bPd=Π−d⁢\bW and \bW is bounded because γ is of class C2, together with the fact that ΠΓ is constant in T, we deduce

inf\tVT∈\V⁢(T)∥ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd) −∇Γ\tVT∥L2⁢(T)≲hT⁢|ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)|H1⁢(T)
≲hT⁢‖Π−d⁢\bW‖L∞⁢(T)⁢‖Dγ2⁢\wu∘\bPd‖L2⁢(T)≲hT⁢|\wu|H2⁢(T~),

where we used the notation Dγ2⁢\wu:=∇γ∇γ⁡\wu. This completes the proof. ∎

This proof reveals that (95) can in fact be written locally:

inf\tV∈\V⁢(T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tV)‖L2⁢(T)2 ≲βT2⁢K∞2⁢‖∇γ\wu‖L2⁢(T~)2
+inf\bV∈ℙ0⁢(T)‖ΠΓ⁢(∇γ\wu∘\bPd)−\bV‖L2⁢(T)2.

We now apply Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)) to derive an a-priori error estimate. We present two proofs. The first one is very compact and relies on Lemmas 3.1 and 54 (perturbation error estimate). The second proof is selfcontained and paves the way to the L2 error estimate that follows. In both cases we rely on Lemma 19 (regularity) for γ of class C2 and \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ):

‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).
{theorem}

[H1 a-priori error estimate for C2 surfaces] Let γ be of class C2, \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and \wu∈H2⁢(γ) be the solution of (18). Let U∈\V#⁢(\T) be the solution to (78) with F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ defined via the lift \bP. If the geometric assumptions (69), (90), and (91) are valid, then

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bP−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲(h\T+λ\T⁢(Γ))⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)

as well as

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲(h\T+μ\T⁢(Γ))⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

Proof 1. We prove the second estimate. Let fΓ=F and uΓ∈H#1⁢(Γ) solve (33)

∫Γ∇ΓuΓ⁢∇Γ\tv=∫ΓfΓ⁢\tv∀\tv∈H#1⁢(Γ).

Since U∈\V#⁢(\T) is the Galerkin approximation to uΓ on Γ, we infer that

‖∇Γ(uΓ−U)‖=inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(uΓ−\tV)‖.

This combined with the triangle inequality yields

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)≤2⁢‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−uΓ)‖L2⁢(Γ)+inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tV)‖L2⁢(Γ).

Applying Lemma 4.3 (approximability of H1⁢(Γ)), together with ‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ), readily gives

inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−\tV)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲(h\T+β\T⁢(Γ))⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

To estimate the remaining term, we resort to Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence), Lemma 54 (perturbation error estimate) along with Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) to obtain

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−uΓ)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲μ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖F‖H#−1⁢(Γ)+‖f⁢qd⁢qΓ−1−F‖H#−1⁢(Γ),

where qd denotes the area element induced by the parametrization \bchi=\bPd∘\bX of γ. We denote by \bPd−1 the inverse of \bPd restricted to Γ, and use Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd), with w~=\tv∘\bPd−1 and \tv∈H#1⁢(Γ), to get

‖f⁢qd⁢qΓ−1−F‖H−1⁢(Γ) =sup‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)=1∫Γ(\wf∘\bPd⁢qdqΓ−\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ)⁢\tv
=sup‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)=1∫γ\wf⁢(\tv∘\bPd−1−\tv∘\bP−1)≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

Combining the previous inequalities with ‖F‖H−1⁢(Γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ) completes the proof of the second assertion. The proof of the first one proceeds along the same lines but using Lemma 3.1 (perturbation error estimate for C1,α surfaces) and Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency for C1,α surfaces) instead. ∎

Proof 2. We closely mimic the proof of Lemmas 3.1 and 54 (perturbation error estimate) for the solution to the Laplace-Beltrami problem on nearby surfaces, with an additional step needed due to the Galerkin approximation. In addition, the fact that F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ is defined using the map \bP while all other quantities are lifted using the closest point projection \bPd adds a twist to our proof as compared with standard proofs of such error estimates. We let u=\wu∘\bPd⁢(\bx) for all \bx∈Γ for notational convenience, and focus on the second assertion.

Step 1: Error representation. For V∈\V⁢(\T) arbitrary, we let W=V−U to arrive at

‖∇Γ(V−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)2=∫Γ∇Γ(u−U)⋅∇ΓW+∫Γ∇Γ(V−u)⋅∇ΓW.

We now invoke Lemma 2 (Galerkin quasi-orthogonality) to rewrite the first term as follows:

∫Γ∇Γ(u−U)⋅∇ΓW=∫Γ(\wf∘\bPd⁢qdqΓ−F)⁢W+∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓW,

where the area element qd over γ is induced by the parametrization \bchi=\bPd∘\bX. We thus have the error representation formula

‖∇Γ(V−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)2 =∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓW+∫Γ∇Γ(V−u)⋅∇ΓW
+∫Γ(\wf∘\bPd⁢qdqΓ−F)⁢W:=I+I⁢I+I⁢I⁢I,

and estimate the three terms on the right hand side separately.

Step 2: Geometric and interpolation errors. According to Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces), the error matrix satisfies ‖\bEΓ‖L∞⁢(Γ)≲μ\T⁢(Γ). This, together with Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) and the a priori bound ‖∇γ\wu‖L2⁢(γ)≤‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ), yields

I≲μ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ).

On the other hand, we can choose V∈\V⁢(\T) so that Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)) holds, whence

I⁢I≲(h\T+β\T⁢(Γ))⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ).

Step 3: Final estimates. We recall that the discrete forcing is given by F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ, where q is the area element in γ induced by the parametrization \bchi=\bP∘\bX. Changing variables to γ via the lifts \bPd and \bP for each integral in I⁢I⁢I gives

I⁢I⁢I=∫Γ(\wf∘\bPd⁢qdqΓ−\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ)⁢W=∫γ\wf⁢(W∘\bPd−1−W∘\bP−1),

where again \bPd−1 denotes the inverse of \bPd restricted to Γ. Since \wf has vanishing mean over γ, we can assume that so does W over Γ. This allows us to invoke (82) (uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs constant) to deduce ‖W‖H1⁢(Γ)≲‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ) and thus apply Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd) to obtain

I⁢I⁢I≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ).

Collecting the previous estimates, and using that β\T⁢(Γ)≤μ\T⁢(Γ), leads to

‖∇Γ(U−V)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲(h\T+μ\T⁢(Γ))⁢‖f‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\T⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)

because μ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(Γ) according to the definition (87) of μ\T⁢(Γ) and Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency for C2 surfaces). Invoking again Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)) yields the second assertion.

The first statement follows similarly upon replacing u~∘\bPd by u~∘\bP, \bPd by \bP and invoking Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces)

‖\bEΓ‖L∞⁢(Γ)≲λ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T⁢|\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ).

This concludes the proof. ∎

Comparing Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces) with Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) ones sees that using the distance function lift \bPd for error representation gives rise to a quadratic geometric error estimator for surfaces γ of class C2

μ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(Γ),

even though the FEM is designed in terms of a generic lift \bP also of class C2. Meanwhile the geometric estimator λ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T⁢|\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ) is linear for this regularity class. This does not affect the H1 a-priori error analysis for piecewise linear approximations of γ and u, which is first order, but it is crucial to derive optimal second-order L2 error estimates by a duality argument. We present next such estimates for surfaces of class C2 and a FEM based on a generic lift \bP also of class C2, a result that seems to be new in the literature.

{theorem}

[L2 a-priori error estimate for C2 surfaces] Let γ be of class C2 and be described by a generic lift \bP of class C2. Let the geometric conditions (69), (90), and (91) be satisfied. Let \wu∈H#1⁢(γ) solve (19) and U∈\V#⁢(\T) solve (78) with F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ. Then

(97) ‖\wu∘\bP−U‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

provided λ≤λ∗, where λ∗ is as in Proposition 4.2.

Proof.

We employ a standard duality argument, but enforcing compatibility (mean-value-zero) conditions. We use the lift \bPd and its inverse \bPd−1 when restricted to Γ to switch from γ to Γ back and forth. To this end we use the notation w~=w∘\bPd−1:γ→ℝ and \tv=\ttv∘\bPd:Γ→ℝ for functions w:Γ→ℝ and \ttv:γ→ℝ. We denote qd the area element induced by \bPd. We finally observe that if \bP is of class C2 then

β\T⁢(Γ)≤μ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢|\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ),

where β\T⁢(Γ) and μ\T⁢(Γ) are defined in (86) and (87). We split the proof into several steps.

Step 1: Duality argument. We associate with U∈\V#⁢(\T) the function U~#=qΓq⁢U~∈L2,#⁢(γ) with vanishing mean over γ and let \wz∈H#1⁢(γ) satisfy

∫γ∇γ\wz⋅∇γ\ww=∫γ(\wu−U~#)⁢\ww∀\ww∈H#1⁢(γ).

Observe that the Lax-Milgram lemma and Lemma 2.2 (Poincaré-Friedrichs inequality) guarantee existence and uniqueness of \wz∈H#1⁢(γ). Let also Z∈\V#⁢(\T) be the Galerkin approximation to \wz over Γ, that is

∫Γ∇ΓZ⋅∇ΓW=∫Γ(u#−U)⁢W,∀W∈\V⁢(\T),

where u#:=qqΓ⁢u has vanishing mean over Γ. Note also that u#−U=(\wu−\wU#)∘\bPd⁢qqΓ is a compatible right-hand side for Theorem 4.3 (H1 a-priori error estimate). We thus have

‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ)2=∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ(\wz−Z~)+∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γZ~.

Applying Lemma 2 (Galerkin orthogonality) the second integral becomes

∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γZ~=∫γ(\wf−F~⁢qΓqd)⁢Z~+∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γZ~,

with F~=F∘\bPd. Changing variables first via the lift \bPd and next via \bP, we get

∫γF~⁢Z~⁢qΓqd=∫ΓF⁢Z=∫γF∘\bP−1⁢Z∘\bP−1⁢qΓq=∫γ\wf⁢Z∘\bP−1.

Consequently, we have derived the following error representation:

(98) ‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ)2 =∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ(\wz−Z~)
+∫γ\wf⁢(Z∘\bPd−1−Z∘\bP−1)
+∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γZ~.

The first term is standard and the next two account for the mismatch between \bP and \bPd and geometric consistency. We examine them separately now.

Step 2: Bounds. Since γ is of class C2, Lemma 19 (regularity) gives for z

‖\wz‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ).

Combining Theorem 4.3 (H1 a-priori error estimate) for \wz with Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) yields the following estimate in L2⁢(γ) instead of L2⁢(Γ)

‖∇γ(\wz−Z~)‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T⁢‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ).

Applying Theorem 4.3 again, this time for u, implies

∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ(\wz−Z~)≲h\T2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ).

On the other hand, Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd) with w~=Z∘\bPd−1 leads to

∫γ\wf⁢(Z∘\bPd−1−Z∘\bP−1) ≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖Z∘\bP−1‖H1⁢(γ)
≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓZ‖L2⁢(Γ),

because Z has a zero mean on Γ. Since \bP is of class C2, one sees that β\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢|\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ). Hence the a-priori bound ‖∇ΓZ‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖u−U‖L2⁢(Γ) implies

∫γ\wf⁢(Z∘\bPd−1−Z∘\bP−1)≲h\T2⁢|\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖u#−U‖L2⁢(Γ).

Finally, Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency error for C2 surfaces), in conjunction with Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence), allows us to tackle the geometric error

∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γZ~≲‖∇ΓU‖L2⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇ΓZ‖L2⁢(Γ)⁢‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ)≲h\T2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖u#−U‖L2⁢(Γ),

where again we have used a priori bounds for ∇ΓU and ∇ΓZ. Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) and the nondegeneracy property (74) of qqΓ imply that ‖u#−U‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ). Collecting the previous estimates and dividing through by ‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ), we thus arrive at

‖\wu−U~#‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

Step 3: Discrepancy between U~ and U~# and final estimates. We still need to deal with the discrepancy between U~ and U~#=qΓq⁢U~. Using Lemma 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) and Lemma 3.1 again, we find that

‖U~−U~#‖L2⁢(γ)≤‖1−qΓ⁢q−1‖L∞⁢(γ)⁢‖U~‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T2⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ).

Applying the triangle inequality followed by Lemma 3.1 gives the intermediate estimate

‖\wu∘\bPd−U‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖\wu−U~‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\T2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

To conclude the proof, we simply note that

‖\wu∘\bPd−\wu∘\bP‖L2⁢(Γ)≈‖\wu−\wu∘\bPd∘\bP−1‖L2⁢(γ)≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wu‖H1⁢(γ)≲hT2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

according to Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd) and the estimate β\T⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢‖\bP‖W∞2⁢(Γ) for \bP of class C2 (see definition (86) of β\T⁢(Γ)). Finally, the triangle inequality leads to the asserted estimate. ∎

The estimate (97) is known for surfaces γ of class C3 and the distance function lift \bPd [Dzi88]. We insist that (97) appears to be new even for \bP=\bPd for surfaces of class C2 and is optimal both in terms of regularity of u and γ as well as order.

The C2 regularity of γ enters in three distinct places in Step 2 of the proof to tackle the right hand side of (98) as well as in Step 3. The first instance is via Lemma 19 (regularity) to handle the H2 regularity of both u and z in terms of the L2 norm of the forcing terms: it turns out that (20) becomes

|\wu|H2⁢(γ)≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

whence the factor |d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2 appears. The same happens with the term involving ‖\bE‖L∞⁢(γ) in view of (94), whereas a factor |\bP|W∞2⁢(Γ) shows up for the middle term in (98) and the end of the proof due to Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd). The complete estimate thus reads

(99) ‖\wu∘\bP−U‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\T2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

A-Priori Error Estimates for C1,α Surfaces. We end this section proving H1 error estimates for surfaces γ of class C1,α and solutions \wu of class H1+s⁢(γ) for 0<s≤1. We recall Lemma 2.2 (regularity for Wp2 surfaces) that establishes this regularity for s=1, provided n<p≤∞, along with

‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

In general, however, the relation between α and s is not well understood; we refer to [BDO] where it is proved the existence of s=s⁢(α)>0 such that \wu∈H1+s⁢(γ). We start with a variant of Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)).

{lemma}

[approximability in H1⁢(Γ)] Let γ be a surface of class C1,α and \wu∈H1+s⁢(γ), where 0<s<α<1 or 0<s≤α=1. Then we have

(100) inf\tV∈\V⁢(\T)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bP−\tV)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\Ts⁢|\wu|H1+s⁢(γ).
Proof.

We recall that u=\wu∘\bP and ∇Γu∘χΓ=D⁢\bchiΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢D⁢\bchit⁢∇γu~∘χ, according to (35), and that D⁢\bchiΓ,\bgΓ−1 and D⁢\bchi are uniformly of class C0,α; here \bchiΓ=\bX. Given T∈𝒯, a direct calculation using the definition of the seminorm |⋅|Hs⁢(T) shows that the composition of a Lipschitz map with a Hs function as well as the product of a C0,α function with a Hs function belong to Hs provided s<α or s≤α=1. Consequently, we infer that ∇Γu∈H1+s⁢(T) for all T∈𝒯 along with

|u|H1+s⁢(T)≲|\wu|H1+s⁢(T~).

A scaling argument guarantees that the constant hidden in this inequality is independent of T∈𝒯. We next apply the localized interpolation estimate of Vesser [Vee16] to deduce

infV∈𝕍⁢(𝒯)‖∇Γ(u−V)‖L2⁢(Γ)2≲∑T∈𝒯infV∈𝕍⁢(T)‖∇Γ(u−V)‖L2⁢(T)2≲h𝒯2⁢s⁢|\wu|H1+s⁢(γ)2,

which is the asserted estimate. ∎

We now compare Lemma 4.3 with Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)). We stress that the lift \bP=\bchi∘\bX−1 is of class C1,α for surfaces of class C1,α, whereas the distance lift \bPd is just of class C1 for surfaces of class C2. This is why the proof of Lemma 4.3 is considerably simpler than that of Lemma 4.3. The virtue of \bPd is reflected in a higher order geometric error μ\T⁢(Γ) in Theorem 4.3 (H1 a-priori error estimate for C2 surfaces) relative to the next H1 error estimate. This is also responsible for the optimal Theorem 4.3 (L2 a-priori error estimate for C2 surfaces) which does not have a counterpart in this context.

{theorem}

[H1 a-priori error estimate for C1,α surfaces] Let γ be of class C1,α, 0<α≤1, and assume that the geometric assumptions (69), (90), and (91) are valid. Let \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and \wu∈H1+s⁢(γ) be the solution of (18) and satisfy

‖\wu‖H1+s⁢(γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

provided 0<s<α<1 or 0<s≤α=1. If U∈\V#⁢(\T) is the solution to (78) with F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ defined via the lift \bP, then

‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bP−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h\Ts⁢‖\wu‖H1+s⁢(γ)+λ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)≲h\Ts⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

We proceed along the lines of Proof 1 of Theorem 4.3 (H1 a-priori error estimate for C2 surfaces), which splits the error into an approximation and a perturbation term. For the former we simply resort to Lemma 4.3 instead of Lemma 4.3 (approximability in H1⁢(Γ)). For the latter we argue exactly as in Theorem 4.3 and thus employ (82) (uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs constant), Lemma 3.1 (perturbation error estimate for C1,α surfaces) and Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency for C1,α surfaces). This shows the first asserted estimate. The second bound follows from the standard interpolation estimate

λ\T⁢(Γ)≲h\Tα⁢‖\bchi‖C1,α⁢(𝒱)

and the condition α≥s. This ends the proof. ∎

4.4. A-Posteriori Error Analysis

In contrast to the previous section, we now derive error estimates in H1 which rely on information extracted from the computed solution U of (78) and data, but do not make use of the exact solution \wu of (18). They are a-posteriori estimates of residual type, are fully computable, and are instrumental to drive adaptive procedures. In this vein, we mention [BCM+16, BCMN13] but we do not elaborate on this issue any longer.

The a-posteriori analysis requires a quasi-interpolation operator acting on H1⁢(Γ) functions, i.e. functions without point values. We use the Scott-Zhang operator \interpsz:H1⁢(Γ)→\V⁢(\T) and recall its local approximability and stability properties for all T∈\T

(101) ‖\tv−\interpsz⁢\tv‖L2⁢(T)≲hT⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(ωT),‖∇Γ\interpsz⁢\tv‖L2⁢(T)≲‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(ωT),

where ωT is a macro patch defined in (65) associated with T. We do not require that \interpsz⁢\tv∈\V#⁢(\T) even if \tv∈H#1⁢(Γ), as it happened earlier in the a-priori error analysis of Section 4.3.

In order to derive a posteriori error estimates, we first introduce the interior and jump residuals for any V∈\V⁢(\T):

RT⁢(V) :=F∣T+ΔΓ⁢V∣T∀T∈\T
JS⁢(V) :=∇ΓV+∣S⋅\bmuS++∇ΓV−∣S⋅\bmuS−∀S∈S\T

where for S=T¯+∩T¯− is the face shared by T±∈\T and \bmuS±:=\bmuT± are pointing outward co-normals to the elements T± (see Section 2.6). We point that when using piecewise affine functions V=V^∘\bX−1 on polyhedral surfaces Γ, the Laplace-Beltrami operator (13) vanishes within elements

ΔΓ⁢V=1qΓ÷qΓ⁢\bgΓ−1⁢∇V^=0∀T∈\T,

and that, in contrast to the flat case, \bmuS+≠−\bmuS− in general. If J∂T⁢(V) denotes the jump residual on ∂T, then we define the element indicator to be

η\T⁢(V,T)2:=hT2⁢‖RT⁢(V)‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖J∂T⁢(V)‖L2⁢(∂T)2∀T∈\T,

and the error estimator to be

η\T⁢(V)2:=∑T∈\Tη\T⁢(V,T)2.
{theorem}

[a-posteriori upper bound for C1,α surfaces] Let γ be of class C1,α, be parametrized by χ=\bP∘\bX and satisfy the geometric assumption (69). Let \wu∈H#1⁢(γ) be the solution to (18) and U∈\V#⁢(\T) be the solution to (78) with F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ∈L2,#⁢(Γ). Then, for U~:=U∘\bP−1:γ→ℝ we have

‖∇γ(\wu−U~)‖L2⁢(γ)2≲η\T⁢(U)2+λ\T2⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)2.
Proof.

Using definitions (19) and (79), along with the consistency relation (34), enables us to write for any \tv~∈H1⁢(γ),\tv=\tv~∘\bP∈H1⁢(Γ) and V∈𝕍⁢(\T)

(102) ∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ\tv~=I1+I2+I3

with

I1 =−∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇Γ(\tv−V)+∫ΓF⁢(\tv−V),
I2 =∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γ\tv~,
I3 =∫γ\wf⁢\tv~−∫ΓF⁢\tv.

Employing the definition F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqγ and changing variables we deduce I3=0.

On the one hand, decomposing I1 over elements T∈\T, and resorting to Corollary 2.6 (integration by parts) on T, leads to

(103) I1=∑T∈\T∫TRT⁢(U)⁢(\tv−V)+∑S∈𝒮∫SJS⁢(U)⁢(\tv−V)

and so

I1≲∑T∈\Tη\T⁢(U,T)⁢(hT−1⁢‖\tv−V‖L2⁢(T)+‖∇Γ(\tv−V)‖L2⁢(T)),

because of the scaled trace inequality

‖w‖L2⁢(∂T)≲hT−12⁢‖w‖L2⁢(∂T)+hT12⁢‖∇Γw‖L2⁢(∂T)∀w∈H1⁢(T).

We now choose V=\interpsz⁢\tv to be the Scott-Zhang quasi-interpolant of \tv. The local approximability and stability properties (101) imply

(104) I1≲η\T⁢(U)⁢‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≲η\T⁢(U)⁢‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ),

where we have used the finite ovelapping properties of the patches {ωT}T∈\T and Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence). Regarding term I2 we apply Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces) to arrive at

I2≲λ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇γU~‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ)≲λ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ),

because of the estimates

‖∇γU~‖L2⁢(γ)≲‖∇ΓU‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖F‖H#−1⁢(Γ)≲‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)

which are a consequence of Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence), F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ, Lemma 2.2 (Poincaré-Friedrich inequality) and ∫γf~=0. Combining the above estimates, we end up with the assertion. ∎

To assess the tightness of the upper bound in Theorem 4.4 it is customary to show a lower bound. To this end, we introduce the so-called data oscillation

osc\T⁢(F,T)2:=hT2⁢‖F−F¯‖L2⁢(T)2,osc\T⁢(F)2:=∑T∈\Tosc\T⁢(F,T)2,

where F¯ is the piecewise average of F. This quantity accounts for the fact that the residual is evaluated in a weighted L2-norm rather than the natural H−1-norm. This in turn makes the estimator η\T⁢(U) computable but perhaps at the expense of overestimation. This is the subject of our next estimate, proved in [BCMN13]. We recall that for T∈𝒯, ωT denotes the union of elements in \T that intersect T and ω~T stands for the lift of ωT to γ via \bP. Moreover, we set

\osc\T⁢(F,ωT)2:=∑T′⊂ωT\osc\T⁢(F,T′)2,λ\T2⁢(ωT):=maxT′⊂ωT⁡λT2.
{theorem}

[a-posteriori lower bound for C1,α surfaces] Under the same conditions of Theorem 4.4 (a-posteriori upper bound for C1,α surfaces), we have

η\T⁢(U,T)2≲‖∇γ(u~−U~)‖L2⁢(ω~T)2+\osc\T⁢(F,ωT)2+λ\T2⁢(ωT).
Proof.

The proof of the lower bound is standard and is only sketched here. It relies on an argument due to Verfürth [Ver13]. The starting point is the error relation (102) localized to T∈𝒯 via the test function \tv=F¯⁢bT, where bT∈H01⁢(T) is the cubic bubble taking value 1 at the element barycenter. Employing the norm equivalence (44) (valid elementwise), we realize that

‖∇γ\ttv‖L2⁢(T~)≲‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(T)≲hT−1⁢‖F¯‖L2⁢(T),

whence taking V=0 in (102) yields

‖F¯‖L2⁢(T)2≲∫TF¯⁢\tv≲hT−1⁢(‖∇γ(\wu−U~)‖L2⁢(T~)+\osc\T⁢(F,T)+‖\bE‖L∞⁢(T~))⁢‖F¯‖L2⁢(T)

upon recalling that I3=0 with our choice of F and the expression (103) for I1. Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces), combined with a triangle inequality, then leads to the desired estimate for the bulk term

hT2⁢‖F‖L2⁢(T)2≲‖∇γ(\wu−U~)‖L2⁢(T~)2+osc\T⁢(F,T)2+λT2.

As for the jump term, we define for a side S∈𝒮 with adjacent elements T±, bS∈H01⁢(ωS) as the quadratic bubble taking value 1 at the barycenter of S and 0 at all other quadratic nodes in ωS:=T+∪T−. We also let ω~S:=\bP⁢(ωS) be the lift of ωS to γ by the map \bP. Taking \tv=JS⁢(U)⁢bS and V=0 in (102), and recalling the expression (103) for I1 and that I3=0, yields

‖JS⁢(U)‖L2⁢(S)2≲∫SJS⁢(U)⁢\tv
≲(‖∇γ(u~−U~)‖L2(ω~S))+hT⁢‖F‖L2⁢(ωS)+max⁡(λT+,λT−))⁢‖∇γ\ttv‖L2(ω~S)).

Finally, it suffices to use the preceding estimate for hT⁢‖F‖L2⁢(T), together with

‖∇γ\ttv‖L2(ω~S))≲‖∇Γ\tv‖L2⁢(ωS)≲hT−1/2⁢‖JS⁢(U)‖L2⁢(S),

to conclude the proof. ∎

One important observation to make is that osc\T⁢(F) is generically of higher order than η\T⁢(U) for \wf∈L2⁢(γ), whence this term can be ignored relative to η\T⁢(U) asymptotically. However, the geometric estimator λ\T⁢(Γ) is linear and thus of the same order as η\T⁢(U), thereby making the lower bound of Theorem 4.4 questionable. This estimator comes from the estimate (89) of Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C1,α surfaces), which cannot obviously be improved for surfaces of class C1,α. However, Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) shows that this effect becomes of second order for surfaces of class C2. Practically, the estimator λ\T⁢(Γ) is pessimistic and leads to unnecessary and thus suboptimal refinements for C2 surfaces [BD19]. We discuss the impact of this superconvergence estimate next following [BD19].

{theorem}

[a-posteriori upper bound for C2 surfaces] Let γ be of class C2 and (67), (74), (90), and (91) hold. Let \wu be the solution of (18) with \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and U∈\V⁢(\T) be the solution to (78) with F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ, where q corresponds to the parametrization \bchi=\bP∘\bX of γ. Then

‖∇γ(\wu−U∘\bPd−1)‖L2⁢(γ)2≲η\T⁢(U)2+μ\T2⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)2.
Proof.

We proceed as in the proof of Theorem 4.4 (a-posteriori upper bound for C1,α surfaces) but using the distance function lift to represent the errors. We denote U~=U∘\bPd−1, \tv=\tv~∘\bPd for a generic \tv~∈H1⁢(γ) and get for any V∈𝕍⁢(\T)

(105) ∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ\wv=I1+I2+I3

with

I1 =−∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇Γ(v−V)+∫ΓF⁢(v−V),
I2 =∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γ\wv,
I3 =∫γ\wf⁢\wv−∫ΓF⁢\tv,

where we have used again (34) but with the error matrix \bE now defined with respect to \bPd and given by (51) of Lemma 3.2 (geometric consistency). We tackle I1 and I2 exactly as in Theorem 4.4, thereby obtaining

I1≲η\T⁢(U)⁢‖∇γ\ttv‖L2⁢(γ),I2≲μ\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\tv~‖L2⁢(γ),

except that we resort to (94) of Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) to estimate \bE.

On the other hand, I3 no longer vanishes because F=\wf∘\bP⁢qqΓ is defined via \bP and the function \tv via \bPd. Using \bP to change variables back to γ we obtain

∫ΓF⁢\tv=∫Γ(\wf∘\bP)⁢(\wv∘\bPd)⁢qqΓ=∫γ\wf⁢(\wv∘\bPd∘\bP−1),

whence I3 becomes

(106) I3=∫γ\wf⁢(\wv−\wv∘\bPd∘\bP−1).

Invoking Proposition 4.2 (mismatch between \bP and \bPd) yields

I3≲β\T⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\wv‖L2⁢(γ)

and concludes the proof because β\T⁢(Γ)≤μ\T⁢(Γ). ∎

We conclude with a lower bound for C2 surfaces. We point out that, compared with the existing results in the literature, see e.g. [DD07], we account for the mismatch between the two lifts \bP and \bPd.

{theorem}

[a-posteriori lower bound for C2 surfaces] Under the same conditions as Theorem 4.4 (a-posteriori upper bound for C2 surfaces), we have

η\T⁢(U,T)2≲‖∇γ(\wu−U~)‖L2⁢(ω~T)2+\osc\T⁢(F,ωT)2+μ\T⁢(ωT)2,

where μ\T⁢(ωT)=maxT′⊂ωT⁡μT′.

Proof.

The proof follows along the lines of Theorem 4.4 (a-posteriori lower bound for C1,α surfaces) with the following variants. We use Corollary 4.2 instead of Corollary 4.2 in the error representation (105) to tackle I2 and account for the fact that I3≠0 via (106) for a generic lift \bP. ∎

5. Trace Method

In this section we present a class of methods which are known as trace finite element methods or cut finite element methods [ORG09, BHL15, Reu15]. The setting for these methods is situations in which a PDE posed on an n-dimensional hypersurface γ embedded in ℝn+1 must be solved numerically, and a bulk or volume background mesh of some domain Ω⊂ℝn+1 is present with γ⊂Ω. It is often more convenient to describe γ and solve associated PDE employing the background mesh instead of independently meshing γ. A paradigm physical example is a two-phase flow problem. There Ω is subdivided into subdomains Ω1 and Ω2 (one for each phase) and γ is the interface between Ω1 and Ω2. In simulations Ω is typically meshed in order to solve equations of fluid dynamics (e.g., Stokes or Navier-Stokes), while accounting for interfacial effects such as surface tension also requires solving a surface PDE on γ. It can be particularly inconvenient to independently mesh Ω and γ in dynamic simulations in which γ evolves as either a specified or free boundary. In addition to the overhead associated with transferring information between unrelated bulk and surface meshes, remeshing is generally necessary from time to time when parametric methods are used to describe dynamic interfaces because mesh degeneracies may occur as the surface deforms.

Trace and cut FEMs were introduced by Olshanskii et al [ORG09] and have been further developed over the past decade as one option for circumventing these difficulties. In order to describe them more precisely, first let \T:=\TΩ be a simplicial decomposition of Ω⊂ℝn+1, n≥1. We let hT:=|T|1n+1 for any T∈\T and set h:=maxT∈𝒯⁡hT for the mesh-size of \T. We will omit to mention the explicit dependence on the shape regularity constant of \T

σ:=maxT∈𝒯⁡diam⁢(T)hT

in most estimates below. Assume that γ⊂Ω is a closed, C2 n-dimensional surface. As outlined in Section 2.3, γ is then the zero level set of a C2 distance function d defined on a tubular neighborhood 𝒩 of γ. Let \V⁢(𝒯)⊂H1⁢(Ω) consist of the continuous piecewise linear functions over \T. In order to fix thoughts, let dh∈\V⁢(𝒯) be the Lagrange interpolant \interp⁢d of d satisfying

‖d−dh‖L∞⁢(𝒩)+h⁢‖d−dh‖W∞1⁢(𝒩)≲h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).

The discrete computational surface Γ is then defined by

Γ:={\bx∈Ω:dh⁢(\bx)=0}.

Below we also discuss how to derive Γ from more general implicit representations of γ. Because dh is piecewise linear, Γ consists of intersections of hyperplanes with simplices and is thus a polyhedron having triangular and quadrilateral faces for n=2 (see Figure 3). We denote by ℱ the collection of faces of Γ. In addition, the conditions placed on dh ensure that ‖d‖L∞⁢(Γ)+h⁢‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(Γ)≲h2, so the perturbation results for C2 surfaces outlined in Section 3.2 hold on Γ with order h2 geometric perturbation error.

The surface finite element space \V⁢(ℱ) is simply the restriction of \V⁢(𝒯) to Γ:

\V(ℱ):={V|Γ:V∈\V(𝒯)}.

By its definition \V⁢(ℱ)⊂H1⁢(Γ) consists of the continuous functions which are affine over each face F∈ℱ. We also denote by \V#⁢(ℱ):=\V⁢(ℱ)∩L2,#⁢(Γ) its subspace consisting of functions with vanishing mean values. In order to approximate the solution \wu to the Laplace-Beltrami problem −Δγ⁢\wu=f~ on γ, we first define a suitable approximation FΓ to f and then seek U∈\V#⁢(ℱ) such that

(107) ∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇ΓV=∫ΓFΓ⁢V,∀V∈\V#⁢(ℱ).

This is the trace method and has two notable advantages:

  • •

    Only single mesh: The main advantage is that both bulk and interfacial effects can be computed using the same mesh.

  • •

    Error estimates: Optimal-order and regularity error estimates hold in the H1 and L2 norms.

On a practical and theoretical levels the method exhibits three main challenges:

  • •

    Implicit surface representation: The simplest option of taking the distance function d to define γ and its Lagrange interpolant of dh to define Γ is not generally practical as d is rarely available in applications. It is generally more practical to assume that the discrete surface Γ is derived from a more general level set representation ϕ of γ. We provide a brief discussion of general level set representations below.

  • •

    Surface integration: Computing the finite element system is more cumbersome than in standard parametric surface FEMs since both the mesh ℱ and the finite element space \V⁢(ℱ) are derived from their corresponding bulk counterparts. These difficulties are manageable in the case of the piecewise linear method presented here, but become significantly more cumbersome when a higher-order surface approximation is used.

  • •

    Linear algebra and stabilization: In contrast to parametric surface FEMs there is no obvious practical basis for \V⁢(ℱ), only spanning sets derived from subsets of the bulk space \V⁢(𝒯). In practice such a spanning set is derived from the degrees of freedom for \V⁢(𝒯) corresponding to elements touching Γ. Degenerate modes arise from this procedure. These are either handled at the linear algebra level or by various stabilization procedures.

Theoretical study of trace FEMs is also more involved than for parametric surface FEMs. One prominent issue is that the surface mesh ℱ does not consist of shape regular elements, as is documented in Figure 3. This is because the faces in ℱ consist of arbitrary intersections of hyperplanes with simplices (planes and tetrahedra for n=2). Thus elements may be arbitrarily small with respect to the bulk mesh-size h or fail to satisfy a minimum angle condition, and it is not possible to directly employ standard error estimation techniques. Properties of the “high-quality” bulk mesh \T and finite element space \V⁢(𝒯) must be invoked instead, which in turn requires careful use of extensions and restrictions of functions to and from γ and Γ. For purposes of intuition, it is however useful to note that the surface mesh ℱ does inherit some structure from the regularity of the bulk mesh \T. Elements in ℱ for example satisfy a maximum-angle condition [ORX12], and each element in ℱ also shares a vertex with a shape-regular element of diameter equivalent to h [DO12].

Below we prove a priori and a posteriori error estimates for a piecewise linear trace FEM. In keeping with the previous section, we concentrate on surface representations and regularity in our discussion. In particular, we only assume that γ is C2, whereas previous approaches require that γ be C3. The recent article [OR17] provides a broader survey of trace FEMs, including discussion of topics such as higher-order versions, stabilization procedures, and space-time trace FEMs that we omit here.

5.1. Preliminaries

Bulk and Surface Meshes. Below we need to carefully distinguish between mesh structures defined relative to the surface mesh ℱ and those defined relative to the volume mesh \T. First note that we shall consistently denote by F (n-dimensional) surface elements lying in ℱ, which as we have noted above may not be shape-regular. In addition, T will be used to denote (n+1)-simplices lying in \T. Given a face F∈ℱ, we denote by TF the simplex in which F lies (or one of them if F is a face shared by two bulk elements). In addition, given T∈\T we denote by ω\T1⁢(T) the patch of elements of \T surrounding T (first ring)

ω\T1⁢(T):=⋃{T′∈\T:T′∩T≠∅},

and by ω\T2⁢(T) the patch of elements of \T surrounding ω\T1⁢(T) (second ring). We also define

hF=diam⁢(TF)F∈ℱ,

whence the local mesh size of the face element F is taken to be the diameter of the corresponding bulk element. Note that it is possible that diam⁢(F)<<hF. We will also denote by hT the diameter of elements T∈\T. We finally let

\TΓ:={T∈\T:Γ∩T≠∅⁢ or ⁢γ∩T≠∅}

be the set of elements of \T touching either Γ or γ.

Geometric Assumptions. Above we described Γ as the zero level set of an approximate distance function dh. In this section we first place abstract requirements on Γ that are sufficient to obtain optimal-order and regularity a priori error estimates and then prove that these requirements are satisfied on sufficiently fine bulk meshes \T when Γ is built from a suitably general level set description of γ. We now list three main geometric assumptions.

  • •

    Description of Γ. We assume that Γ is a polyhedral surface whose faces F∈ℱ consist of the intersection of hyperplanes with simplices T∈\T. We further assume that Γ⊂𝒩 with 𝒩 the tubular neighborhood defined in (31).

  • •

    Geometric resolution of γ. Let d be the distance function to γ, \bnu=∇d and \bnuΓ be the outward unit normal on Γ. We assume that

    (108) ‖d‖L∞⁢(F)+hF⁢‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(F)≲hF2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)F∈ℱ.

    This assumption is sufficient to ensure optimal decay of the geometric consistency error in a priori error estimates.

  • •

    Local flattening. We assume that for each T∈\T with T∩γ≠∅, there is a ball BR of radius R with R≃1 (independent of hT) such that T⊂BR/2 and there is a uniformly bi-C2 map

    (109) Φ:BR→ℝ3,Φ⁢(γ∩BR)⁢ lies in a hyperplane.

The flattening assumption (109) follows from the C2 nature of the surface γ provided elements T∈\T intersecting γ are sufficiently fine with respect to the inverse of the maximum principal curvature. The flattening map Φ may be constructed by expressing γ as a C2 graph over tangent hyperplanes of γ, with the radius of the domain of these graphs bounded by the inverse of the maximum principal curvature of γ (cf. [Eva98, Appendix C] for the construction of Φ; the bound for R follows from the definition of curvature).

Level set representations. While we prove our results below under the abstract geometric resolution assumption (108) involving the distance function, in practice trace methods often build the discrete surface Γ from a more general implicit representation of γ. Such a representation may be obtained by assuming that γ is the zero level set of a level-set function ϕ:𝒩→ℝ

γ={\bx∈𝒩:ϕ⁢(\bx)=0}.

Broadening our assumptions concerning implicit representation of γ is important in many practical applications. Because the distance function d has a closed form expression only if γ is a sphere or a torus, there are many settings where γ may easily be represented as a level set even if d is not available. A simple example is the ellipsoid given by γ={\bx∈ℝ3:x2a2+y2b2+z2c2−1=0}. Level set methods in which an evolving free boundary is computationally approximated by the level set of a discrete function are also popular in many applications. In this case it is also natural to define γ via a generic level set function ϕ rather than restrict attention to the distance function d.

Our essential assumptions concerning ϕ are that ϕ∈C2⁢(𝒩) and

(110) ∇ϕ⁢(\bx)⋅\bnu⁢(\bx)≥cϕ>0∀\bx∈γ.

Because γ is a level set of ϕ, |∇ϕ|=|∇ϕ⋅ν| on γ, so the assumption (110) is equivalent to assuming that ∇ϕ is nondegenerate on γ and points in the same direction as \bnu=∇d. Let ϕh∈\V⁢(𝒯) be an approximation to ϕ satisfying

(111) ‖ϕ−ϕh‖L∞⁢(T)+hT⁢‖ϕ−ϕh‖W∞1⁢(T)≲hT2⁢‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩)T∈\T,

and define the discrete surface Γ by

Γ:={\bx∈𝒩:ϕh⁢(\bx)=0}.
{lemma}

[geometric resolution] Let γ be C2. Under the above assumptions, the inequality (108) holds for h:=maxT∈\T⁡hT sufficiently small, namely

(112) ‖d‖L∞⁢(F)+hF⁢‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(F)≲hF2⁢‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩)F∈ℱ.
Proof.

First let \bx∈𝒩, for which the projection \bPd⁢(\bx) on γ is uniquely defined. Let ζ⁢(s):=∇ϕ⁢(s⁢\bx+(1−s)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx))⋅\bnu⁢(\bx) and compute

|(∇ϕ⋅\bnu)(\bx) −(∇ϕ⋅\bnu)(\bPd(\bx))|=|ζ(1)−ζ(0)|=|∫01ζ′(s)ds|
=|∫01∇(∇ϕ⁢(s⁢\bx+(1−s)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx))⋅\bnu⁢(\bx))⋅(\bx−\bPp⁢(\bx))|
≤|\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|⁢‖∇(∇ϕ⋅ν)‖L∞⁢([\bPd⁢(x),\bx]).

Since (∇ϕ⋅\bnu)⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))≥cϕ>0, ϕ∈C2⁢(𝒩), and \bnu∈C1⁢(𝒩), there thus exists a constant Cϕ≤12⁢K∞ (depending on ‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩) and |d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)) such that

(∇ϕ⋅\bnu)⁢(\bx)≥cϕ2∀\bx∈𝒩ϕ:={\by∈Ω:|d⁢(\by)|≤Cϕ}⊂𝒩,

according to (31). Therefore, for any \bx∈𝒩ϕ we have ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=0 and

|ϕ⁢(\bx)|=|∫01∇ϕ⁢(s⁢\bx+(1−s)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx))⋅(\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx))|≃|\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|=|d⁢(\bx)|,

because \bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)=|\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|⁢\bnu⁢(\bx). Given any face F∈ℱ of Γ, we realize that ϕh⁢(\bx)=0 for all \bx∈F and

|ϕ⁢(\bx)|=|ϕ⁢(\bx)−ϕh⁢(\bx)|≲hF2⁢‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩).

If h≥hF is sufficiently small, then \bx∈𝒩ϕ and |d⁢(\bx)|≃|ϕ⁢(\bx)|≲hF2⁢|ϕ|W∞2⁢(𝒩). This is the desired bound for the first term on the left hand side of (112).

To prove the remaining bound in (112), we note that for \bx∈F∈ℱ, we have \bnuΓ⁢(\bx)=∇ϕh⁢(\bx)|∇ϕh⁢(\bx)| and \bnu⁢(\bx)=ν⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|. Consequently, for such \bx∈Γ, we use (111), the bound |d⁢(\bx)|≲hF2 already proved, and the C2 nature of ϕ to obtain

|(\bnuΓ−\bnu)⁢(\bx)|=|∇ϕh⁢(\bx)|∇ϕh⁢(\bx)|−∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))||≤|∇ϕh⁢(\bx)|∇ϕh⁢(\bx)|−∇ϕ⁢(\bx)|∇ϕ⁢(\bx)||+|∇ϕ⁢(\bx)|∇ϕ⁢(\bx)|−∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))||≲(hF+hF2)⁢‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩)≲hF⁢‖ϕ‖W∞2⁢(𝒩).

This completes the proof. ∎

Thus we have shown that it is possible to define the discrete surface Γ using a generic level set representation of γ in such a way that Γ has the same geometric approximation properties as if it were derived more directly from the distance function d. Below we assume practical access to the distance function d and associated geometric properties (curvatures and normal vectors) in two further places: the first one is the definition of the right hand side FΓ in formulating the trace FEM and the second one is the definition of geometric a posteriori error estimators. As outlined in [DD07], it is computationally feasible to accurately approximate d⁢(\bx), \bPd⁢(x), and ν⁢(\bx) for \bx∈Γ under the assumption that we have access to a level set function ϕ with the properties assumed above. In outline, the foundational building block of this procedure is a numerical approximation to \bPd⁢(\bx). Two such algorithms are proposed in [DD07], one being Newton’s method and the other an ad hoc first order method; cf. [Gra17] for generalizations and analysis of these methods. Once \bPd⁢(\bx) is computed, we then have

|d⁢(\bx)|=|\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx)|,ν⁢(\bx)=∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|,\bW⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=∇∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|∇ϕ⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|.

These relationships allow for the computation of all geometric information required to bound geometric errors in the trace method a posteriori. In addition, because we may reasonably assume access to \bPd it is in turn reasonable to assume a consistent definition of the right hand side FΓ, that is, FΓ=qqΓ⁢f∘\bPd. A different definition of FΓ would lead to an additional consistency term in the results below.

Harmonic Extension and Traces. Here we collect instrumental results for our proofs of a priori and a posteriori error estimates. For the latter we use the fractional-order space H3/2⁢(Ω), so we first define the seminorm of H1+s⁢(Ω)

|\tv|H1+s⁢(Ω)2:=∑|α|=1∬Ω×Ω|Dα⁢\tv⁢(x)−Dα⁢\tv⁢(y)|2|x−y|n+2⁢s⁢dx⁢dy

for a Lipschitz domain Ω⊂ℝn and 0<s<1, and corresponding norm

‖\tv‖H1+s⁢(Ω)2=‖\tv‖H1⁢(Ω)2+|\tv|H1+s⁢(Ω)2.

Our first lemma is a standard extension result which may for example be found in [Gri85, Theorem 1.4.3.1].

{lemma}

[H1+s extension] Let D be a bounded Lipschitz domain in ℝn, n≥2. Then there is an extension operator E:H1+s⁢(D)→H1+s⁢(ℝn) such that

(113) ‖E⁢\tv‖H1+s⁢(ℝn)≲‖\tv‖H1+s⁢(D)∀s∈[0,1),∀\tv∈H1+s⁢(D).

We also state a trace result relating H1⁢(ℝ2) and H3/2⁢(ℝ3); this is a special case of [Ada75, Theorem 7.58]. {lemma}[trace] If \tv∈H3/2⁢(ℝn), n≥2, and ℙ is any (n−1)-dimensional hyperplane in ℝn, then

(114) ‖\tv‖H1⁢(ℙ)≲‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(ℝn).

The following is an important technical lemma which expresses traces relationships between norms on surface elements (flat or curved) and corresponding norms on bulk elements. An essential component of these estimates is that they allow for surfaces to cut through bulk elements in an arbitrary fashion. Such estimates were essential in the proof of the first a posteriori estimates for trace methods in [DO12]. In the context of a priori error estimates for trace methods, these provide a substantially simplified proof of error bounds when compared with the original proofs given in [ORG09]; cf. [HH02, HH04, BHL15, Reu15].

{lemma}

[trace estimates for cut elements] Let D⊂ℝn (n≥2) be a (not necessarily bounded) Lipschitz domain, and let Dn−1 be the intersection of D with an arbitrary hyperplane of dimension n−1. Then

(115) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(Dn−1)≲‖\tv‖H1⁢(D)∀\tv∈H1⁢(D),

where the hidden constant depends on the Lipschitz nature of D but not on the orientation or size of Dn−1. In particular, let F∈ℱ with F⊂T∈\T. Then

(116) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(F)≲hT−1/2⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)+hT1/2⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T)∀\tv∈H1⁢(T).

In addition, given T∈\T there hold

(117) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)≲hT−1/2⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)+hT1/2⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T)∀\tv∈H1⁢(T),

and

(118) hT−1‖\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)+‖∇γ\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)≲hT−3/2⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)+hT−1/2⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T)+|\tv|H3/2⁢(T)∀\tv∈H3/2⁢(T).
Proof.

The estimate (⁢115⁢) is a special case of [Ada75, Lemma 5.19]. The scaled result (116) follows by a standard scaling argument.

To prove (117) and (118) we employ a flattening argument. First let K^ be the unit reference simplex in ℝn with standard affine reference mapping φ:K^→T satisfying ‖∇φ‖L∞⁢(K^)≲hT and ‖(∇φ)−1‖L∞⁢(T)≲hT−1. Let now Φ be the flattening map in assumption (109). It is possible to extend Φ to all of ℝn so that the resulting extension is also C2, still flattens T∩γ, and has derivative bounded above and below away from 0. To see this, take a smoothly weighted average of Φ and the identity with weight 1 for Φ on BR/2 and weight 0 outside of BR. Having thus extended Φ, we define Φ~:=φ−1∘Φ∘φ. It is easy to check that Φ~ and Φ~−1 are uniformly bounded in C2 and that Φ~⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ)) lies in some (n−1)-dimensional hyperplane ℙ.

For \tv∈H1⁢(T) with T∈𝒯 satisfying |T∩γ|>0, let now \tv^=\tv∘φ. We first prove (118) upon transforming to the reference element back and forth. We start with a simple scaling argument

|φ−1⁢(T∩γ)||T∩γ|≈hT1−n,

regardless of the actual size and orientation of T∩γ relative to T∈\T. Hence, applying a standard change of variables involving φ yields

hT1−n⁢(‖\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2+hT2⁢‖∇γ\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2)≈‖\tv^‖H1⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ))2.

We next resort to the extension operator E:H3/2⁢(K^)→H3/2⁢(ℝn) in Lemma 5.1 (H1+s extension), the smoothness of Φ~−1, the fact that Φ~⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ))⊂ℙ, the trace inequality (114), the smoothness of Φ~−1 again, and the boundedness (113) of E in H3/2⁢(K^), in this order, to arrive at

‖\tv^‖H1⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ)) =‖E⁢\tv^‖H1⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ))
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖H1⁢(Φ~⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ)))
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖H1⁢(ℙ)
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖H3/2⁢(ℝn)
≲‖E⁢\tv^‖H3/2⁢(ℝn)
≲‖\tv^‖H3/2⁢(K^).

The desired estimate (118) finally follows from a scaling argument from K^ to T employing again the map φ:

‖\tv^‖H3/2⁢(K^)2≲hT−n⁢(‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)2+hT2⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T)2+hT3⁢|\tv|H3/2⁢(T)2).

To prove (117), we argue similarly to above except that we now employ E:H1⁢(K^)→H1⁢(ℝn) and (115) instead of (114). Doing so yields

hT(1−n)/2⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ) ≲‖\tv^‖L2⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ))
=‖E⁢\tv^‖L2⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ))
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖L2⁢(Φ~⁢(φ−1⁢(T∩γ)))
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖L2⁢(ℙ)
≲‖E⁢\tv^∘Φ~−1‖H1⁢(ℝn)
≲‖E⁢\tv^‖H1⁢(ℝn)
≲‖\tv^‖H1⁢(K^)
≲hT−n/2⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)+hT(2−n)/2⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T).

Multiplying both sides by hT(n−1)/2 gives the desired bound (117). ∎

5.2. A Priori Error Estimates

We recall that we use the notation h:=maxT∈\T⁡hT and that we omit to mention the explicit dependence on the shape regularity constant of 𝒯 in most estimates.

Geometric resolution and extensions. Given a surface γ of class C2 and \wu∈H2⁢(γ), Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) yields the existence of an extension u of \wu to a tubular neighborhood 𝒩⁢(δ) with δ sufficiently small with respect to 12⁢K∞ lying in H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) and satisfying

(119) ‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ1/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).
  • •

    First assumption on geometric resolution by the bulk mesh. We assume

    (120) ⋃{ω\T1⁢(T):T∈\TΓ}⊂𝒩⁢(δ)

    with δ≃h sufficiently small so that (119) holds.

  • •

    Second assumption on geometric resolution by the bulk mesh. We assume that the layer DΓ,γ:={s⁢\bx+(1−s)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx):\bx∈Γ⁢ and ⁢0≤s≤1} satisfies

    (121) DΓ,γ⊂⋃{T:T∈\TΓ}.

    This clearly holds for h sufficiently small because the Hausdorff distance between γ and Γ satisfies \distH⁢(γ,Γ)≲h2 according to (108).

  • •

    Uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs estimate on Γ. We assume that

    (122) ‖\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)≲‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(Γ)∀\tv∈H#1⁢(Γ)

    holds with uniform constant. According to the discussion below (82) (uniform Poincaré-Friedrichs constant), this only requires that Γ⊂𝒩⁢(1/2⁢K∞) and that \bnu⋅\bnuΓ≥c>0 on Γ. These conditions are easily checkable and valid asymptotically.

Approximation properties of trace finite element space. We next state a fundamental approximation bound for the trace FEM, which we prove under the regularity assumption that γ is of class C2. We emphasize that this assumption is less restrictive than the hypotheses of previous approximation bounds for trace estimates, which assume that γ is of class C3.

{lemma}

[trace approximation] Let γ be of class C2 and the geometric resolution assumptions (108), (109), (120), and (121) hold. Then

(123) inf\tV∈\V⁢(ℱ)‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−V)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).
Proof.

Let δ≃h be sufficiently small so that (120) is valid. Let \interpsz be the standard Scott-Zhang interpolation operator on \T, and take V=\interpsz⁢u with u∈H2⁢(\Nd) given by Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) and satisfying (119). We then denote ud=\wu∘\bPd,Vd=V∘\bPd, add and subtract multiple terms, and apply the triangle inequality to find that

‖∇Γ(ud−V)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲∑i=17Ii

where

I1 :=‖∇Γ(ud−Vd)‖L2⁢(Γ),
I2 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[∇Vd−(∇V)∘\bPd]‖L2⁢(Γ),
I3 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[∇V∘\bPd−∇u∘\bPd]‖L2⁢(Γ),
I4 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[∇u∘\bPd−(\interpsz⁢∇u)∘\bPd]‖L2⁢(Γ),
I5 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[(\interpsz⁢∇u)∘\bPd−\interpsz⁢∇u]‖L2⁢(Γ),
I6 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[\interpsz⁢∇u−∇u]‖L2⁢(Γ),
I7 :=‖ΠΓ⁢[∇u−∇V]‖L2⁢(Γ).

Here we have applied the interpolation operator \interpsz componentwise to the (n+1)-vector ∇u and used that ∇Γ=ΠΓ⁢∇. We next estimate each term separately.

In order to bound terms I1 and I3, we employ Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) between γ and Γ and recall that |∇γ\tv|≤|∇\tv| pointwise to find that

I1+I3≲(∑T∈\TΓ‖∇(u−V)‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2)1/2.

We next apply the trace estimate (117), utilize standard approximation properties of \interpsz, and finally use the bound (119) to obtain

I1+I3 ≲(∑T∈\TΓhT−1⁢‖∇(u−V)‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(T)2)1/2
≲h1/2⁢‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).

Here we have used that ∇∇⁡V=0 elementwise since V is piecewise linear. Similar arguments lead to the following estimate for I4

I4≲(∑T∈\TΓhT−1⁢‖∇u−\interpsz⁢∇u‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖∇(∇u−\interpsz⁢∇u)‖L2⁢(T)2)1/2,

as well as I4≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ) provided ‖∇\interpsz⁢∇u‖L2⁢(T)≲‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T)). To show this estimate we let ∇u¯T:=|ω\T1⁢(T)|−1⁢∫ω\T1⁢(T)∇u be the meanvalue of ∇u in ω\T1⁢(T) and exploit the stability of \interpsz in H1⁢(T)

‖∇\interpsz⁢∇u‖L2⁢(T) =‖∇\interpsz⁢[∇u−∇u¯T]‖L2⁢(T)≲hT−1⁢‖\interpsz⁢[∇u−∇u¯T]‖L2⁢(T)
≲hT−1⁢‖∇u−∇u¯T‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T))≲‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T)).

Moreover, applying the trace estimate (116) directly to the terms I6 and I7 yields

I6 ≲(∑F∈ℱ‖\interpsz⁢∇u−∇u‖L2⁢(F)2)1/2
≲(∑T∈\TΓhT−1⁢‖\interpsz⁢∇u−∇u‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖∇[\interpsz⁢∇u−∇u]‖L2⁢(T)2)1/2≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ),

and

I7 ≲(∑F∈ℱ‖∇(u−V)‖L2⁢(F))1/2
≲(∑T∈\TΓhT−1⁢‖∇(u−V)‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(T)2)1/2≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).

In order to bound term I2, we first note that

ΠΓ⁢[∇Vd−(∇V)∘\bPd]=ΠΓ⁢(Π−d⁢D2⁢d−\bI)⁢(∇V)∘\bPd.

An easy computation using the assumption (108) yields

|ΠΓ⁢(Π−d⁢D2⁢d−\bI)|≲|ΠΓ⁢Π−ΠΓ|+|d|=|(\bnu⋅\bnuΓ)⁢\bnuΓ⊗\bnu−\bnu⊗\bnu|+h2≲h.

Thus employing the equivalence of norms on γ and Γ, the trace estimate (117), the H1 boundedness of \interpsz, and the boundedness (119) of the extension yields

I2 ≲h⁢‖∇\tV∘\bPd‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h⁢‖∇V‖L2⁢(γ)
≲h1/2⁢‖∇V‖L2⁢(\TΓ)≲h1/2⁢‖u‖H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲h⁢‖u~‖H2⁢(γ).

We finally bound term I5. Given \bx=\bPd⁢(\bx)+d⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))∈Γ, we infer that

|\interpsz⁢∇u⁢(\bx)−\interpsz⁢∇u⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|≤∫0d⁢(\bx)|∇[\interpsz⁢∇u⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)+s⁢∇d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)))]|⁢𝑑s

and |d⁢(\bx)|≲h2 according to (108), whence

I52≲h2⁢∫Γ∫0d⁢(\bx)|∇[\interpsz⁢∇u⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)+s⁢∇d⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)))]|2⁢𝑑s⁢𝑑σ⁢(\bx)≲h2⁢∫DΓ,γ|∇\interpsz⁢∇u|2.

In view of assumptions (121) and (120), and the bound ‖∇\interpsz⁢∇u‖L2⁢(T)≲‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T)), we deduce

I52≲h2⁢‖D2⁢u‖L2⁢(\Nd)2≲h3⁢‖D2⁢\wu‖H2⁢(γ)2,

and conclude the proof. ∎

{theorem}

[a-priori error estimates] Let γ be of class C2 and let Γ be so that the geometric assumptions (108), (109), (120), (121), and (122) are satisfied. Let \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and \wu∈H2⁢(γ) solve (19). If U∈\V#⁢(ℱ) is the finite element solution of (107) with FΓ=qqΓ⁢\wf∘\bPd, then

‖\wu∘\bPd−U‖L2⁢(Γ)+h⁢‖∇Γ(\wu∘\bPd−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

With the geometric resolution estimate (108) and Lemma 5.2 (trace approximation) in hand, the proof is nearly identical to those of Theorem 4.3 (H1 a-priori error estimate) and Theorem 4.3 (L2 a-priori error estimate) for parametric surface FEM. We thus sketch the proof without details.

Step 1: H1 error estimate. Let V∈\V⁢(ℱ) achieve the infimum in (123), W:=V−U, u=\wu∘\bPd, and write the error representation formula as

‖∇Γ(V−U)‖L2⁢(Γ)2=∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓW+∫Γ∇Γ(V−u)⋅∇ΓW,

because FΓ=qqΓ⁢\wf∘\bPd. In view of Lemma 3.2 (geometric consistency) and the geometric resolution estimate (108) we deduce |\bEΓ|≲h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) and

|∫Γ∇Γu⋅\bEΓ⁢∇ΓW|≲h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wu‖H1⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ)≲h⁢‖f~‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ).

On the other hand, Lemma 5.2 (trace approximation) yields

|∫Γ∇Γ(V−u)⋅∇ΓW|≲h⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇ΓW‖L2⁢(Γ).

The desired estimate follows from Lemma 19 (regularity).

Step 2: L2 error estimate. Let \bPd−1 denotes the inverse of \bPd restricted to Γ. Let U~:=U∘\bPd−1:γ→ℝ and U~#:=qΓq⁢U~∈H#1⁢(γ); likewise, let u#:=qqΓ⁢u∈H#1⁢(Γ). We now solve dual problems on γ

\wz∈H#1(γ):∫γ∇γ\wz⋅∇γw=∫γ(\wu−\wU#)w∀w∈H#1(γ)

and on Γ

Z∈\V#(ℱ):∫Γ∇ΓZ⋅∇ΓW=∫Γ(u#−U)W∀W∈\V#(ℱ).

Note that the right-hand sides u#−U=qqΓ⁢(\wu−\wU#)∘\bPd are compatible and Step 1 applies. We set Z~=Z∘\bPd and proceed as in Theorem 4.3 (L2 a-priori error estimate) to deduce the error representation

‖\wu−\wU#‖L2⁢(γ)2=∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ(z~−Z~)+∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γZ~,

because FΓ=qqΓ⁢\wf∘\bPd. Applying Lemma 19 (regularity) to \wz yields ‖\wz‖H2⁢(γ)≲‖\wu−\wU#‖L2⁢(γ). This together with Step 1 implies

|∫γ∇γ(\wu−U~)⋅∇γ(\wz−Z~)|≲h2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖\wu−\wU#‖L2⁢(γ).

Making use again of Lemma 3.2 (geometric consistency) and the geometric resolution estimate (108) we deduce |\bE|≲h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩), whence

|∫γ∇γU~⋅\bE⁢∇γZ~|≲h2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖u#−U‖L2⁢(Γ).

Consequently,

‖\wu−\wU#‖L2⁢(γ)2≲h2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢(‖\wu−\wU#‖L2⁢(γ)+‖u#−U‖L2⁢(Γ))

and the asserted bound follows from Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) and the auxiliary estimate

‖U~−U~#‖L2⁢(γ)≲h2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

The latter hinges on Corollary 4.2 (geometric consistency errors for C2 surfaces) and the geometric resolution estimate (108), as in the proof of Theorem 4.3. This completes the proof. ∎

5.3. A Posteriori Error Estimates

A posteriori error estimates for the trace FEM were first proved in [DO12], while a posteriori estimates for a trace FEM based on octree meshes were proved in [CO15]. The proof of the estimates given in [DO12] is significantly different than that of the a priori estimates given above. A main reason for the difference is that, in contrast to the framework above that deals with quasi-uniform meshes, we assume that the bulk mesh \T is merely shape-regular. This is necessary to allow for meaningful mesh grading in adaptive algorithms. Moreover, the extension used in Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) is not immediately useful here because the parameter δ specifying the width of the tubular neighborhood about γ is taken to be proportional to h when \T is quasi-uniform; such a global mesh size parameter is no longer meaningful on graded meshes. A local counterpart of Proposition 3.3 on graded meshes, that uses the normal extension instead of the regularized normal extension, is employed in [CO15] to prove a posteriori bounds, but with the drawback that the constants in the estimates depend on the difference in refinement depth between the largest and smallest elements in the bulk mesh. We thus present here the framework of [DO12], which relies on the harmonic extension of \tv∈H1⁢(γ) into H3/2⁢(ℝ3) instead of either the normal extension \tvd or the extension of Proposition 3.3.

Notation and surface resolution assumptions. We make the following two assumptions concerning resolution of γ by the bulk mesh \T:

  • •

    Resolution of skin layer between γ and Γ. Given a discrete surface element F∈ℱ, let

    DF={𝐲∈Ω:𝐲=t⁢\bx+(1−t)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx)⁢ for some ⁢0≤t≤1⁢ and some \bx∈F}.

    The set DF is the collection of all points lying on line segments connecting points in \bx∈F and their images \bPd⁢(\bx)∈γ. We assume that

    (124) DF⊂ω\T1⁢(TF),

    that is, DF lies in the volume element patch ω\T1⁢(TF) (first ring) corresponding to the face element F, which is defined in section 5.1.

  • •

    Normal projections of elements have finite overlap. We assume that

    (125) \bPd⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF))⊂ω\T2⁢(TF)∀F∈ℱ,

    where the second ring ω\T2⁢(TF) is also defined in section 5.1.

The above assumptions hold if γ is sufficiently resolved by the bulk mesh \T. To see this, note first that ‖d‖L∞⁢(DF)≲hF2 by (108), so that dist⁢(𝐲,F)≲hF2 for all 𝐲∈DF. On the other hand, dist⁢(F,∂ω\T1⁢(TF))≳hF. Thus there is a constant C such that the assumption (124) is satisfied when hF≤C; C here depends on geometric properties of γ, the shape regularity constant of \T and properties of the Lagrange interpolant. In principle an upper bound for C could be computed and this condition checked, but this has not been attempted in the literature and we do not do so here. A similar but more involved argument holds for the assumption (125).

Extension for a posteriori error estimates. The next essential result states that a given a function \wv∈H1⁢(γ) can be boundedly extended to \tv∈H3/2⁢(ℝn+1). {lemma}[harmonic extension] Let γ be a closed surface of class C2 and dimension n embedded in ℝn+1 for n≥1. Given \wv∈H1⁢(γ), there is \tv∈H3/2⁢(ℝn) such that trace⁢(\tv)=\wv and

(126) ‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(ℝn+1)≲‖\wv‖H1⁢(γ).
Proof.

First let \tv∈H1⁢(D) solve Δ⁢\tv=0 on the bulk domain D comprising the interior of γ, with \tv=\wv on γ. By [JK95, Theorem 5.15], we have that \tv∈H3/2⁢(D), trace⁢(\tv)=\wv, and ‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(D)≲‖\wv‖H1⁢(γ). Boundedly extending \tv to H3/2⁢(ℝn+1) via the extension operator E defined in Lemma 5.1 (H1+s extension) completes the proof. ∎

Preliminary results. We now give a technical lemma that quantifies the evaluation mismatch between Γ and γ for a discrete function. {lemma}[evaluation mismatch between γ and Γ] Let \tV∈\V⁢(𝒯), and let the conditions (108), (109), and (124) hold. For all F∈ℱ, we have

(127) ‖\tV−\tV∘\bPd‖L∞⁢(F)≲hF2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖∇\tV‖L∞⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF)).
Proof.

Fix \bx∈F, and let g⁢(t)=\tV⁢(t⁢\bx+(1−t)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx)), 0≤t≤1. Then g⁢(0)=\tV⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx)) and g⁢(1)=\tV⁢(\bx). Since \bPd⁢(\bx)=\bx−d⁢(\bx)⁢ν⁢(\bx), we see that

g′⁢(t)=∇\tV⁢(t⁢\bx+(1−t)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx))⋅(\bx−\bPd⁢(\bx))=d⁢(\bx)⁢∇\tV⁢(t⁢\bx+(1−t)⁢\bPd⁢(\bx))⋅ν⁢(\bx),

whence \tV⁢(\bx)−\tV⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))=g⁢(0)−g⁢(1)=∫01g′⁢(t)⁢𝑑t and

|\tV⁢(\bx)−\tV⁢(\bPd⁢(\bx))|≲|d⁢(\bx)|⁢‖∇\tV‖L∞⁢(DF).

The assertion follows from assumptions (108) and (124). ∎

A posteriori upper bound. First we define a residual error indicator

η\F(U,F):=hF∥FΓ+ΔΓU∥L2⁢(F)+hF1/2∥⟦∇ΓU⟧∥L2⁢(∂F)F∈ℱ,

and corresponding estimator

η\F⁢(U):=(∑F∈\Fη\F⁢(U,F)2)1/2.

Here ⟦⋅⟧ denotes the jump in the normal component of the argument over ∂F. Because we have assumed access to the closest point projection \bPd, we also employ a geometric indicator that directly accesses information from \bPd

ξF:=‖d‖L∞⁢(F)⁢‖K‖L∞⁢(\bPd⁢(F))+‖\bnu−\bnuΓ‖L∞⁢(F)2F∈\F,

and corresponding geometric estimator

ξ\F⁢(Γ):=maxF∈ℱ⁡ξF.
{theorem}

[a-posteriori upper estimate] Let γ be of class C2 and let Γ be defined so that the geometric assumptions (108), (109), (124), and (125) hold. Let \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and \wu∈H#1⁢(γ) solve (19). If U∈\V⁢(ℱ) is the finite element solution of (107) with FΓ=qqΓ⁢\wf∘\bPd, and Ud=U∘\bPd−1 where \bPd−1 is the inverse of \bPd restricted to Γ, then

(128) ‖∇γ(\wu−Ud)‖L2⁢(γ)≲η\F⁢(U)+ξ\F⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇ΓU‖L2⁢(Γ).
Proof.

We proceed in several steps.

Step 1: Error representation via the residual equation. First we note that

‖∇γ(\wu−Ud)‖L2⁢(γ)=sup\wv∈H1⁢(γ),‖∇γ\wv‖L2⁢(γ)=1∫γ∇γ(\wu−Ud)⋅∇γ\wv

and then write as in (102) that

∫γ∇γ(\wu−Ud)⋅∇γ\wv=I1+I2+I3

with

I1 :=−∫Γ∇ΓU⋅∇Γ(\tvd−\tV)+∫ΓFΓ⁢(\tvd−\tV),
I2 :=∫γ∇γUd⋅\bE⁢∇γ\wv,
I3 :=∫γ\wf⁢\wv−∫ΓFΓ⁢\tvd.

Here \bE is as in (51), \tvd=\wv∘\bPd, and V∈\V⁢(𝒯) is a suitable approximation of the H3/2 extension \tv of \wv given by Lemma 5.3 (harmonic extension). Note that I3=0 because of the definition FΓ=qqΓ⁢\wf∘\bPd.

Step 2: Bounding the geometric error terms. Using (56) (or more accurately the corresponding pointwise bound from which it is derived) directly yields

‖𝐄‖L∞⁢(F)≲ξFE∈ℱ.

Thus making use of Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) implies

|I2|≲ξ\F⁢(Γ)⁢‖∇γUd‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\wv‖L2⁢(γ)≤ξ\F⁢(Γ)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖∇γ\wv‖L2⁢(γ).

Step 3: Bounding the residual term. In order to bound I1, we first decompose the integrals over faces F∈\F and then integrate by parts to arrive at

|I1|≲∑F∈ℱη\F⁢(U,F)⁢(hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F)+hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(∂F)).

We may thus complete the proof upon showing that

(∑F∈ℱhF−2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F)2+hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(∂F)2)1/2≲‖\wv‖H1⁢(γ).

Given F∈ℱ, we begin by considering the quantity hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(e) for any edge e⊂∂F. We first use the triangle inequality to obtain

hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(e)≲hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(e)+hF−1/2⁢‖\tVd−\tV‖L2⁢(e)

with Vd=V∘\bPd, and examine the last term first. Since e is an (n−1)-dimensional edge with diam(e)≤hF, combining Hölder inequality and Lemma 5.3 (evaluation mismatch between γ and Γ) with an inverse estimate over the (n+1)-dimensional patch ω\T1⁢(TF) yields

hF−1/2⁢‖\tVd−\tV‖L2⁢(e) ≲hF(n−2)/2⁢‖\tVd−\tV‖L∞⁢(F)
≲hF(n+2)/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖∇V‖L∞⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF))
≲hF1/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖∇V‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF)).

For the first term hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(e) we argue as follows. Let ℙ be the n−dimensional hyperplane containing F. While it may be that diam⁢(e)<<hF, the shape regularity of \T implies that

dist(e,∂ω\T1(TF))≥dist(TF,∂ω\T1(TF)≃hF.

Thus there exists an n−dimensional ball B⊂ℙ∩ω\T1⁢(TF)⊂ℙ so that e⊂B and diam⁢(B)≃hF. This ball B is the candidate for applying the hF-scaled version of (115) of Lemma 5.1 (trace estimates for cut elements), namely

hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(e)≲hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(B)+‖∇ℙ(\tvd−\tVd)‖L2⁢(B).

Since \tvd−\tVd=(\wv−V)∘\bPd, we change variables from B to γ while employing Lemma 3.1 (norm equivalence) to get

hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(e)≲hF−1⁢‖\wv−\tV‖L2⁢(\bPd⁢(B))+‖∇γ(\wv−\tV)‖L2⁢(\bPd⁢(B)).

We observe that \bPd⁢(B)⊂\bPd⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF))⊂ω\T2⁢(\TF) in light of (125), whence

hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(e)≲hF−1⁢‖\tv−\tV‖L2⁢(ω\T2⁢(TF)∩γ)+‖∇γ(\tv−\tV)‖L2⁢(ω\T2⁢(TF)∩γ).

We now carry out a similar but more direct computation for the term hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F) appearing in I1. Again using Lemma 5.3 we obtain

hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tVd‖L2⁢(F) ≲hF−1⁢‖\wv−V‖L2⁢(T∩γ)
hF−1⁢‖\tVd−\tV‖L2⁢(F) ≲hF(n+2)/2⁢‖∇V‖L∞⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF))≲‖∇V‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF)).

Combining the previous estimates we end up with

hF−1 ‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F)+hF−1/2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(∂F)
≲hF−1⁢‖\wv−\tV‖L2(ω\T2(TF))∩γ)+‖∇γ(\wv−\tV)‖L2(ω\T2(TF))∩γ)+‖∇\tV‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(TF)).

Summing over F∈ℱ while using finite overlap of the patches ω\T2⁢(TF) yields

(∑F∈ℱhF−2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F)2+hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(∂F)2)1/2
