≲(∑T∈\TΓhT−2⁢‖\wv−\tV‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2+‖∇γ(\wv−\tV)‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2)1/2+‖∇\tV‖L2⁢(Ω).

Step 4: Interpolation. We next apply (118) to the function \tv−\tV while realizing that |\tV|H3/2⁢(T)=0. Doing so yields |\tv−\tV|H3/2⁢(T)=|\tv|H3/2⁢(T) and

hT−1⁢‖\wv−\tV‖L2⁢(T∩γ) +‖∇γ(\wv−\tV)‖L2⁢(T∩γ)
≲hT−3/2⁢‖\tv−\tV‖L2⁢(T)+hT−1/2⁢‖∇(\tv−\tV)‖L2⁢(T)+|\tv|H3/2⁢(T).

Next let \tV=I\Tsz⁢\tv, where I\Tsz is the Scott-Zhang interpolation operator on the bulk space \V⁢(𝒯). Standard approximation theory in \V⁢(𝒯) then yields

hT−3/2⁢‖\tv−\tV‖L2⁢(T)+hT−1/2⁢‖∇(\tv−\tV)‖L2⁢(T)+|\tv|H3/2⁢(T)≲‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T))

and

‖∇\tV‖L2⁢(T)≲‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(ω\T1⁢(T))

for every T∈\TΓ. Using the finite overlap of the patches ω\T1⁢(T) and the bound ‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(ℝn+1)≲‖\wv‖H1⁢(γ) of Lemma 5.3 (harmonic extension), we finally obtain

(∑F∈ℱhF−2⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(F)2+hF−1⁢‖\tvd−\tV‖L2⁢(∂F)2)1/2 ≲‖\tv‖H3/2⁢(ℝ3)≲‖\wv‖H1⁢(γ).

This completes the proof. ∎

{remark}

[efficiency] In a posteriori error analysis it is standard to prove lower (efficiency) bounds such as those in Theorems 4.4 and 4.4. For trace methods such estimates would ideally take the form

ηℱ⁢(U,F) ≲‖ud−U‖H1⁢(ω\F1⁢(F))+\oscℱ⁢(FΓ,ωℱ1⁢(F))
+ξℱ⁢(ωℱ1⁢(F))⁢‖∇ΓU‖L2⁢(ω\F1⁢(F)).

where ωℱ1⁢(F) is the patch of elements about F∈ℱ and \oscℱ⁢(FΓ,ωℱ1⁢(F)) is a heuristically higher-order term measuring the deviation of FΓ from the piecewise constants. However, the standard proof of this result does not work for trace methods due to the irregular structure of the surface mesh ℱ. The paper [DO12] contains partial efficiency results for the volume residual but none for the jump residual term. Numerical experiments suggest that a local efficiency result may hold, but also show a slight degeneration of the constant as the mesh is refined. Thus it is not clear whether the estimators we have studied for the trace method are efficient, and if so what form an efficiency estimate would take.

6. Narrow Band Method

In the narrow band approach, the partial differential equation (19) on γ

−Δγ⁢\wu=\wf

is extended to the tubular neighborhood \Nd of γ defined in (29)

𝒩⁢(δ):={\bx∈ℝn+1:|d⁢(x)|<δ}⊂ℝn+1;

we refer to the original papers [BCOS01, Bur09]. The finite element method is then posed over a discrete approximation to 𝒩⁢(δ). We assume that γ is of class C2 and 0<δ<12⁢K∞ so that (61) holds, namely \Nd⊂𝒩\eps⁢(δ\eps), and all the properties of the distance function detailed in Section 2 are valid in 𝒩⁢(δ).

A natural / standard way to extend \wu and \wf to 𝒩⁢(δ) is to use the constant extensions along the normal direction

u=\wu∘\bPd,f=\wf∘\bPd.

We use the latter to design the FEM. However, we need u∈H2⁢(\Nd) to derive optimal a-priori H1 error estimates for the FEM, which entails γ∈C3 when using the closest point projection \bPd. We circumvent this extra regularity on γ via Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension), which defines u as a normal extension relative to a perturbation \gae of γ constructed as a zero level set of a regularized distance function \de. We will show below in Lemma 140 (narrow band PDE consistency) that such a function u satisfies

(129) |∫𝒩⁢(δ)∇u⋅∇v−∫𝒩⁢(δ)f⁢v|≲δ3/2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖v‖H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)).

The specific choice of u adds several technicalities to the proof of (129) but reduces the regularity of γ to C2. This seems to be a new result in the literature consistent with the underlying regularity \wu∈H2⁢(γ). This also motivates the narrow band FEM as a straightforward (bulk) finite element approximation of (129) upon replacing \Nd by a polygonal approximation 𝒩h⁢(δ) dictated by dh, the Lagrange interpolant of d in the bulk. We discuss this next. We refer to [OS16] for higher order FEMs and [DDEH10, DER14] for an algorithm based on a level-set function, rather that the less practical distance function. The essential ideas, however, are similar to those below but are more technical.

6.1. The Narrow Band FEM

We assume that 𝒩 is enclosed in a n+1 dimensional polyhedral domain D and denote by 𝒯 a partition of D made of simplices. We omit to mention the explicit dependence on the shape regularity constant of \T

σ:=maxT∈𝒯⁡diam⁢(T)hT

in most estimates below; we use the notation hT=|T|1n+1 and h=maxT∈𝒯⁡hT. Let dh stand for the Lagrange interpolant of the distance function d by continuous piecewise linear functions over \T. The discrete distance function dh induces the discrete narrow band

𝒩h⁢(δ):={\bx∈D:|dh⁢(\bx)|<δ}.

Notice that standard interpolation estimates imply

(130) ‖d−dh‖L∞⁢(𝒩)+h⁢‖∇(d−dh)‖L∞⁢(𝒩)≤cI⁢h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩),

where cI is a constant only depending on σ. This implies the non-degeneracy property

(131) |∇dh|≥||∇d|−|∇(d−dh)||≥|1−|∇(d−dh)||≥12,

provided h is sufficiently small so that cI⁢h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≤12. Combining estimates (130) and (131) we deduce that the Hausdorff distance between \Nd and 𝒩h⁢(δ) satisfies

(132) \distH⁢(\Nd,𝒩h⁢(δ))≤2⁢cI⁢h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).

Moreover, to guarantee that 𝒩h⁢(δ)⊂𝒩, we observe

|d⁢(\bx)|≤|dh⁢(\bx)|+|(d−dh)⁢(\bx)|≤δ+cI⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢h2∀\bx∈𝒩h⁢(δ).

In view of (31), it thus suffices to restrict δ and h so that

(133) δ+cI⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢h2≤12⁢K∞.

Hereafter we make the structural assumption

(134) C1⁢h≤δ≤C2⁢h

with cI≤C1≤C2 so that (133) holds for h sufficiently small.

We denote by 𝒯δ the restriction of 𝒯 to 𝒩h⁢(δ) in the sense that

𝒯δ:={T∈\T:T∩𝒩h⁢(δ)≠∅}.

The finite element space associated with 𝒯δ is then constructed in the usual way

𝕍⁢(𝒯δ):={V∈C0⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ)¯):V|T∈𝒫,T∈𝒯δ},

where we recall that 𝒫 stands for the space of polynomials of degree 1. The subspace of functions with vanishing mean value is denoted 𝕍#⁢(𝒯δ).

With this notation at hand and inspired by (129), we define the narrow band finite element solution U∈𝕍#⁢(𝒯δ) to satisfy

(135) ∫𝒩h⁢(δ)∇U⋅∇V=∫𝒩h⁢(δ)F⁢V,∀V∈𝕍#⁢(𝒯δ),

where F is an approximation to f=f~∘\bPd satisfying ∫𝒩h⁢(δ)F=0. In order to make a convenient choice of F, we first define 𝐌h:𝒩h⁢(δ)→𝒩⁢(δ) by

𝐌h⁢(\bx)=\bPd⁢(\bx)+dh⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx);

the properties of 𝐌h are explored thoroughly later in this section. With this definition in hand, we let

(136) F=f∘𝐌h−1|𝒩h⁢(δ)|⁢∫𝒩h⁢(δ)f∘𝐌h.

This requires having access to d,dh and \bPd, which we assume hereafter. Since F has vanishing meanvalue, (135) is also valid for all V∈𝕍⁢(𝒯δ). The existence and uniqueness of U∈𝕍#⁢(𝒯δ) follows directly from the Lax-Milgram lemma.

6.2. PDE Geometric Consistency

We intend to prove (129) for the extension u∈H2⁢(\Nd) in Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) of \wu∈H2⁢(γ). We recall Proposition 3.3 (PDE satisfied by u)

−÷\mue\bBe∇u=\fe\mue,

multiply by a test function \tv∈H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) and integrate by parts in \Nd to obtain

(137) ∫𝒩⁢(δ)\bBε⁢∇u⋅∇\tv⁢με=∫𝒩⁢(δ)fε⁢\tv⁢με+∫∂𝒩⁢(δ)\bBε⁢∇u⋅∇d⁢\tv⁢με.

Notice that we have used that \bnu=∇d is the outward pointing normal to ∂\Nd. We start by estimating geometric quantities appearing in (137).

{lemma}

[properties of \mue and \bBe] Let γ be of class C2 and C⁢δ≤\eps≤δ2 be sufficiently small. Then for all \bx∈\Nd we have

(138) ‖1−με‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

and

(139) ‖Π\eps−\bBε⁢με‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).
Proof.

We recall the definitions of \mue from Proposition 3.3 (PDE satisfied by u) and \wmue from Lemma 3.3 (PDE satisfies by \ue)

\mue=1\wmue∘\bPe⁢det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde),\wmue=det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢(∇d⋅∇\wde)∘\bQe,

where \bP\eps is the projection from 𝒩⁢(δ) onto γ\eps={\wde⁢(\bx)=0} and \bQ\eps is its inverse when restricted to γ. Note that in \Nd

1−\mue=(1−1\wmue∘\bPe)+1\wmue∘\bPe⁢(1−det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)).

We thus need to examine the eigenvalues (ζi⁢(\bx))i=0n of

\bI−\wde⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢\wde⁢(\bx)∀\bx∈\Nd,

with ζ0⁢(\bx)=1 corresponding to the eigenvector ∇\wde. We infer that

ζi⁢(\bx)=1−ηi⁢(\bx)

where

|ηi⁢(\bx)|≲|\wde⁢(\bx)|⁢|\wde|W∞2⁢(\Nd)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

according to Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) and (61) with δε≤32⁢δ. Hence

|1−det(\bI−\wde⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢\wde⁢(\bx))|=|1−∏i=1nζi⁢(\bx)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

for all \bx∈\Nd. This takes care of the second term in the equation for 1−\mue. It remains to estimate 1−\wmue∘\bPe. Since 1−\wmue∘\bPe reads as follows on γ

1−\wmue=(1−det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde))+det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢(1−∇d⋅∇\wde),

combining the previous estimate with Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) yields

|1−\wmue⁢(\bPe⁢(\bx))|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)∀\bx∈\Nd.

This implies |\wmue⁢(\bPe⁢(\bx))|≥12 for δ suficiently small and thus leads to (138).

We now prove (139) which, in light of (138), reduces to the estimate ‖Π\eps−\bBε‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩). We recall from Proposition 3.3 that in \Nd

\bBe=(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1⁢Π\eps⁢\wbAe∘\bPe⁢Π\eps⁢(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1.

Since \wde⁢(\bx)≤δ~≤32⁢δ for \bx∈\Nd and ‖D2⁢\wde‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩) thanks to Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde), the Taylor expansion of (\bI−t⁢\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1 centered at t=0 and computed at t=1 converges for δ sufficiently small. It reads

(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−1=\bI+\wde⁢(\bI−ξ⁢\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)−2⁢D2⁢\wde

for some 0<ξ<1. The definition of \wbAe given in Lemma 3.3 yields

\bBe=Π\eps⁢(Π∘\bQ\eps∘\bP\eps)⁢Π\eps+\wde⁢\bG,

where \bG:𝒩⁢(δ)→ℝ(n+1)×(n+1) satisfies ‖\bG‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲1. Moreover,

Π\eps−Π\eps⁢(Π∘\bQ\eps∘\bP\eps)⁢Π\eps=Π\eps⁢∇d∘(\bQ\eps∘\bP\eps)⊗Π\eps⁢∇d∘(\bQ\eps∘\bP\eps)

whence for all \bx∈\Nd we see that

Π\eps⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx)))=∇d⁢(\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx)))−∇\wde⁢(\bx)⁢(∇d⁢(\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx)))⋅∇\wde⁢(\bx)).

Since

|∇\wde⁢(\bx)−∇d⁢(\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx)))| ≤|∇(\wde⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx))|+|∇d⁢(\bx)−∇d⁢(\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx)))|
≲(δ+|\bx−\bQ\eps⁢(\bP\eps⁢(\bx))|)⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

thanks to Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde), we get

‖Π\eps−\bBe‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

as asserted. This concludes the proof. ∎

{remark}

[estimate of μ] Lemma 3.2 (relation between q and qΓ) gives the expression μ⁢(\bx):=det(\bI−d⁢(\bx)⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx)) for the change of infinitesimal area between γs:={d−1⁢(s)} and γ:={d−1⁢(0)}. Proceeding as in the proof of the above lemma, we get

(140) ‖1−μ‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

provided δ is sufficiently small so that 𝒩⁢(δ)⊂𝒩. We are now in position to prove a consistency estimate measuring the discrepancy between f and Δ⁢u in 𝒩⁢(δ). {lemma}[narrow band PDE consistency] Let γ be of class C2 and u be the extension of Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) with C⁢δ≤\eps≤δ2 sufficiently small. If \wf∈L2⁢(γ), then for all \tv∈H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)), we have

(141) |∫𝒩⁢(δ)∇u⋅∇\tv−∫𝒩⁢(δ)f⁢\tv|≲δ3/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)).
Proof.

In view of (137), we deduce

I⁢(\tv):=∫𝒩⁢(δ)∇u⋅∇\tv−∫𝒩⁢(δ)f⁢\tv=I1⁢(\tv)+I2⁢(\tv)+I3⁢(\tv)∀\tv∈H1⁢(\Nd),

where

I1⁢(v) :=∫𝒩⁢(δ)(\bI−\bBε⁢με)⁢∇u⋅∇\tv,
I2⁢(v) :=∫𝒩⁢(δ)(fε⁢με−f)⁢\tv,
I3⁢(v) :=∫∂𝒩⁢(δ)\bBε⁢∇u⋅∇d⁢\tv⁢με

with fε=\wf∘\bQε∘\bPε. We now examine these three terms separately.

Step 1: Term I1⁢(v). Since u is constant along the direction ∇\wde, we realize that ∇u=Π\eps⁢∇u and Lemma 6.2 (properties of \mue and \bBe) directly yields

|I1⁢(\tv)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖∇u‖L2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)).

Step 2: Term I2⁢(\tv). Let −δ<s<δ and consider the isomorphisms

\bRs:=\bQ\eps∘\bP\eps∘\bQs:γ→γ,\bRs−1=\bPd∘\bQ\eps,s∘\bP\eps:γ→γ,

where \bQs:γ→γs is the inverse of \bPd on γs and \bQ\eps,s:\gae→γs is the inverse of \bP\eps on γs. Using the coarea formula (63) together with |∇d|=1 we write

I2⁢(\tv)=∫−δδ∫γs(\fe⁢\mue−f)⁢\tv,

and combining with Lemma 3.2 (relation between q and qΓ), we obtain

I2⁢(\tv) =∫−δδ∫γ(\wf∘\bRs)⁢(\tv∘\bQs)⁢(\mue∘\bQs)⁢(μ−1∘\bQs)
−∫−δδ∫γ\wf⁢(\tv∘\bQs)⁢(μ−1∘\bQs)=I⁢I1⁢(\tv)+I⁢I2⁢(\tv)+I⁢I3⁢(\tv),

where

I⁢I1⁢(\tv) :=∫−δδ∫γ(\wf∘\bRs)⁢(\tv∘\bQs)−\wf⁢(\tv∘\bQs),
I⁢I2⁢(\tv) :=∫−δδ∫γ\wf⁢(\tv∘\bQs)⁢(1−μ−1∘\bQs)
I⁢I3⁢(\tv) :=∫−δδ∫γ(\wf∘\bRs)⁢(\tv∘\bQs)⁢((\mue∘\bQs)⁢(μ−1∘\bQs)−1).

We proceed to estimate each term separately. To manipulate I⁢I1⁢(\tv) we first observe that changing variables from γ to γs, γs to \gae, and \gae to γ and invoking Lemma 3.2 (relation between q and qΓ) yields

(142) ∫γ(\wf∘\bRs)⁢(\tv∘\bQs)=∫γ(\wf∘\bQe∘\bPe∘\bQs)⁢(\tv∘\bQs)=∫γs(\wf∘\bQe∘\bPe)⁢\tv⁢μ=∫\gae(\wf∘\bQe)⁢(\tv⁢μ⁢\mue−1)∘\bQes=∫γ\wf⁢(\tv⁢μ⁢\mue−1)∘\bQes∘\bPe⁢\mue,

where

μ=det(\bI−d⁢D2⁢d),μ\eps=det(\bI−\wde⁢D2⁢\wde)⁢(∇d⋅∇\wde).

Therefore, denoting by μ\bR the infinitesimal change in area induced by \bRs−1 on γ

μ\bR:=(μ⁢\mue−1)∘\bQes∘\bPe⁢\mue,

we infer again from the coarea formula (63) that

I⁢I1⁢(\tv) =∫−δδ∫γ\wf⁢((\tv∘\bQes∘\bPe)⁢μ\bR−\tv∘\bQs)
=∫−δδ∫γs(f⁢(\tv∘\bQes∘\bPe∘\bPd)⁢μ\bR⁢μ−f⁢\tv⁢μ)⁢|∇d|
=∫\Ndf⁢(\tv∘\bL−\tv)⁢μ\bR⁢μ+∫\Ndf⁢\tv⁢(μ\bR−1)⁢μ,

where \bL is defined on each γs by \bL|γs:=\bQes∘\bPe∘\bPd:γs→γs . Notice that the map \bL:\Nd→\Nd is a bi-Lipschitz perturbation of the identity with perturbation constant

r=‖\bI−\bL‖L∞⁢(\Nd)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd),

because

‖\bI−\bPd‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)) +‖\bI−\bQs‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))
+‖\bI−\bP\eps‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))+‖\bI−\bQ\eps,s‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd).

Moreover, since μ\bR−1=(μ⁢\mue−1−1)∘\bQes∘\bPe⁢\mue+(\mue−1), (138) and (140) imply

‖μ\bR−1‖L∞⁢(γ)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd).

These estimates in conjunction in Proposition 4.2 (Lipschitz perturbation) give

|I⁢I1⁢(\tv)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(\Nd);

we observe that to apply Proposition 4.2 we take Ω1=Ω2=\Nd, which are Lipschitz domains, and extend \tv to Ω=𝒩 so that ‖\tv‖H1⁢(𝒩)≲‖\tv‖H1⁢(\Nd).

Upon utilizing the coarea formula (63) once more, we obtain for I⁢I2⁢(v)

I⁢I2⁢(\tv)=∫\Ndf⁢\tv⁢(1−μ−1)⁢μ,

so that (140) yields

|I⁢I2⁢(\tv)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(\Nd).

We proceed similarly for I⁢I3⁢(v) but using in addition that

∫−δδ‖\wf∘\bRs‖L2⁢(γ)2⁢𝑑s≲∫−δδ‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢𝑑s≲‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)2,

and

‖(\mue∘\bQs)⁢(μ−1∘\bQs)−1‖L∞⁢(γ)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)

thanks to (138) and (140) again. We thus obtain for I⁢I3⁢(v) an estimate similar to those for I⁢I1⁢(\tv) and I⁢I2⁢(\tv), whence

|I2⁢(\tv)|≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(\Nd).

Step 3: Term I3⁢(\tv). In view of Π\eps=\bI−∇\wde⊗∇\wde, we first note that

∇dT\bBεμ\eps=∇dT(\bBε\mue−Π\eps)+∇(d−\wde)T+∇\wdeT(1−∇d⋅∇\wde).

Invoking Lemma 6.2 (properties of \mue and \bBe) and then Lemma 3.3 (properties of \wde) yields

‖∇dT⁢\bBε⁢μ\eps‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd).

It remains to use trace inequalities to obtain

I3⁢(\tv) ≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖∇u‖L2⁢(∂N⁢(δ))⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(∂N⁢(δ))
≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)).

Step 4: Normal extension. Gathering the above estimates we find that

I⁢(\tv)≲δ⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢(‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))+‖f‖L2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)))⁢‖\tv‖H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)).

We finally deduce ‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)≲δ12⁢|d|W∞2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ) because f is the normal extension of \wf to γ, and

‖∇u‖L2⁢(\Nd)≲δ12⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

upon combining Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) with Lemma 19 (regularity). This leads to the desired estimate. ∎

6.3. Properties of the Narrow Band FEM

To begin with, we recall the definition of \bMh:𝒩h⁢(δ)→𝒩⁢(δ), that accounts for the mismatch between 𝒩h⁢(δ) and 𝒩⁢(δ):

(143) \bMh⁢(\bx)=\bPd⁢(\bx)+dh⁢(\bx)⁢∇d⁢(\bx)=\bx+(dh⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx))⁢∇d⁢(\bx).

Note that if \bx∈\Nhd⊂𝒩 then \bPd⁢(\bMh⁢(\bx))=\bPd⁢(\bx), because this is what happens with all points in the line s↦\bx+s⁢∇d⁢(\bx) within 𝒩. Since |dh⁢(\bx)|<δ,

|d⁢(\bMh⁢(\bx))|=|\bMh⁢(\bx)−\bPd⁢(\bMh⁢(\bx))|=|dh⁢(\bx)|⁢|∇d⁢(\bx)|<δ

implies that \bMh⁢(\bx)∈\Nd and the map Mh is well defined. Further properties of \bMh are discussed next. Before doing so, we mention that the results provided below are not optimal (to avoid technicalities) but are sufficient for our analysis. We refer to [DER14, OS16] for higher order estimates.

{lemma}

[properties of \bMh] Let γ be of class C2 and h be sufficiently small. Then, the map \bMh:𝒩h⁢(δ)→𝒩⁢(δ) is bi-Lipschitz with

(144) ‖D⁢\bMh‖L∞⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))+‖D⁢\bMh−1‖L∞⁢(𝒩⁢(δ))≤L

for some constant L independent of h and δ. Moreover, there holds

(145) ‖\bI−\bMh‖L∞⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))+h⁢‖\bI−D⁢\bMh‖L∞⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)

and

(146) ‖det(D⁢\bMh)−1‖L∞⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).
Proof.

From the definition (143) of \bMh and the interpolation estimate (130), we find that

|\bx−\bMh⁢(\bx)|≤|d⁢(\bx)−dh⁢(\bx)|≤cI⁢h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩).

Furthermore, we compute

D⁢\bMh⁢(\bx)=\bI+∇(dh⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx))⊗∇d⁢(\bx)+(dh⁢(\bx)−d⁢(\bx))⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx)

to deduce

‖\bI−D⁢\bMh‖L∞⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≤cI⁢h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)+cI⁢h2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)2.

The above two estimates yield (145) because cI⁢h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)≤12 for h sufficiently small. Exploiting (145), we also deduce that \bMh is invertible, bi-Lipschitz and that (144) holds for h sufficiently small.

We are left to show (146). This follows from D⁢det\bA=(det\bA)⁢\bA−1 for any invertible matrix \bA and the first order Taylor expansion of

ψ⁢(t):=det(\bI−t⁢(∇(d⁢(\bx)−dh⁢(\bx))⊗∇d⁢(\bx)−(d⁢(\bx)−dh⁢(\bx))⁢D2⁢d⁢(\bx)))

about t=0 and evaluated at t=1, along with (145) and the fact that ψ⁢(1)=det(D⁢\bMh⁢(\bx)). This concludes the proof. ∎

The previous lemma is instrumental to estimate the consistency error

(147) Eh⁢(V):=∫𝒩h⁢(δ)∇u⋅∇V−∫𝒩h⁢(δ)F⁢V∀V∈𝕍⁢(𝒯δ),

due to the approximation of the narrow band 𝒩⁢(δ) by 𝒩h⁢(δ) and to the use of F in the discrete formulation (135). Since \Nd⊂𝒩 is of class C2, we assume without loss of generality that the function u:\Nd→ℝ constructed in Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) extends to 𝒩 and satisfies ‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩)≲‖u‖H2⁢(\Nd). In light of \Nhd⊂𝒩, the consistency error (147) is well defined.

{lemma}

[narrow band geometric consistency] Let γ be of class C2 and δ and h satisfy the structural condition (134) and be sufficiently small. Let \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ), \wu∈H2⁢(γ) solve (18), and u∈H2⁢(\Nd) be the H2 extension of \wu given by (62) with C⁢δ≤\eps≤δ2. Let also F be given by (136). Then the consistency error (147) satisfies for all V∈𝕍⁢(𝒯δ)

|∫𝒩h⁢(δ)∇u⋅∇V−∫𝒩h⁢(δ)F⁢V|≲δ3/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖V‖H1⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ)).
Proof.

We compare the consistency errors (147) and (141) term by term.

Step 1: Dirichlet integrals. Utilizing the change of variables induced by the map \bMh:\Nhd→\Nd we end up with

∫\Nhd∇u⋅∇V−∫\Nd∇u⋅∇(V∘\bMh−1)=I1⁢(V)+I2⁢(V)+I3⁢(V),

where

I1⁢(V) :=∫\Nhd(∇u−∇u∘\bMh)⋅∇V⁢det(D⁢\bMh)
I2⁢(V) :=∫\Nhd∇u⋅∇V⁢(1−det(D⁢\bMh))
I3⁢(V) :=∫\Nd∇u⋅(∇V∘\bMh−1−∇(V∘\bMh−1)).

In view of Proposition 4.2 (Lipschitz perturbation) and Lemma 6.3 (properties of \bMh), we infer that

|I1⁢(V)|,|I2⁢(V)|≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖u‖H2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖V‖H1⁢(\Nhd).

Similarly for I3⁢(V), we observe that

∇V∘\bMh−1−∇(V∘\bMh−1)=(\bI−D⁢\bMh−1)⁢∇V∘\bMh−1,

so that employing Lemma 6.3 (properties of \bMh) yields

|I3⁢(V)|≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖∇u‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖∇V‖L2⁢(\Nhd).

Recalling the structural assumption C1⁢h≤δ, Lemma 19 (regularity) as well as ‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)≲δ12⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ), the estimates for I1⁢(V), I2⁢(V) and I3⁢(V) guarantee

|∫\Nhd∇u⋅∇V−∫\Nd∇u⋅∇(V∘\bMh−1)|≲δ3/2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖V‖H1⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ)).

Step 2: Forcing. Recalling (136), we rewrite the forcing term in (147) as

∫\NhdF⁢V−∫\Ndf⁢V∘\bMh−1=I⁢I1⁢(V)+I⁢I2⁢(V),

where

I⁢I1⁢(V) :=∫\Ndf⁢V∘\bMh−1⁢(det(D⁢\bMh)−1−1),
I⁢I2⁢(V) :=−1|𝒩h⁢(δ)|⁢∫𝒩h⁢(δ)f∘\bMh⁢∫𝒩h⁢(δ)V.

We make use of (144) and (146), along with a change of variables, to compute

I⁢I1⁢(V) ≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖V∘\bMh−1‖L2⁢(\Nd)
≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)⁢‖V‖H1⁢(\Nd).

Since |𝒩h⁢(δ)|≃|\Nd|≃δ, the first equivalence resulting from (144) and the second from the coarea formula, using (146) again we obtain

I⁢I2⁢(V) ≲δ−1/2⁢‖V‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))⁢|∫𝒩h⁢(δ)f∘\bMh⁢(det⁢(D⁢\bMh)−1)−∫\Ndf|
≲‖V‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))⁢(h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖f‖L2⁢(\Nd)+δ−1/2⁢|∫\Ndf|).

To estimate the rightmost term we exploit the fact that \wf has a vanishing mean on γ. Using the coarea formula (63), we see that

∫\Ndf=∫−δδ∫γsf =∫−δδ∫γ\wf⁢μs=∫−δδ∫γ\wf⁢(μs−1)
≤2⁢δ⁢‖μs−1‖L∞⁢(γ×[−δ,δ])⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

where μs=det(\bI−d⁢D2⁢d)−1∘\bQs according to Lemma 3.2 (relation between q and qΓ). Remark 6.2 (estimate of μ) in turn leads to

|∫\Ndf|≲δ2⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

Consequently, collecting the previous estimates and using the structural assumption C1⁢h≤δ again readily gives

|I⁢I2⁢(V)|≲δ32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖V‖L2⁢(\Nhd).

Gathering the bounds for I⁢Ii⁢(V) for i=1,2, we discover

|∫\NhdF⁢V−∫\Ndf⁢V∘\bMh−1|≲δ32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)⁢‖V‖H1⁢(\Nhd).

Step 3: Conclusion. The assertion follows from the bounds derived in Steps 1 and 2 together with the estimate (141) of Lemma 140 (narrow band PDE consistency) with \tv=V∘\bMh−1∈H1⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)). The proof is complete. ∎

6.4. A Priori Error Estimates

All of the ingredients for a-priori error analysis in the narrow band norm are now in place. We recall that the extension u:\Nd→ℝ constructed in Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) is further extended to 𝒩 and satisfies

(148) ‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩)≲‖u‖H2⁢(\Nd)≲δ12⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wu‖H2⁢(γ).
{theorem}

[a-priori error estimate] Let γ be of class C2 and δ and h satisfy the structural condition (134) and be sufficiently small. Let \wu∈H#1⁢(γ) be defined by (18) with \wf∈L2,#⁢(γ) and u be its extension given by (62) with C⁢δ≤\eps≤δ2. Let U∈𝕍#⁢(𝒯δ) be the finite element solution to (135) with F given in (136). Then, the following error estimate is valid

‖∇(u−U)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲infV∈𝕍⁢(𝒯δ)‖∇(u−V)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))+h32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ),

with hidden constant independent of h and δ.

Proof.

The proof consists of a Strang type argument. For any V∈𝕍⁢(𝒯δ) the equation (135) satisfied by U and the definition (147) of Eh(.) give

‖∇(V−U)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))2=∫𝒩h⁢(δ)∇(V−u)⋅∇(V−U)+Eh⁢(V−U).

Invoking Lemma 6.3 (narrow band geometric consistency), together with the structural assumption (134), yields

‖∇(V−U)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≤‖∇(V−u)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))+c⁢h32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

The desired error estimate follows from a triangle inequality. ∎

{corollary}

[rate of convergence in \Nhd] Under the assumptions of Theorem 148 we have

‖∇(u−U)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲h32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

In view of (148) standard polynomial interpolation theory gives

‖∇(u−Ihsz⁢u)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲h⁢‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩)≲h⁢‖u‖H2⁢(𝒩⁢(δ)),

where Ihsz⁢u is the Scott-Zhang interpolant of u. It remains to use Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) and Lemma 19 (regularity) to arrive at

‖∇(u−Ihsz⁢u)‖L2⁢(𝒩h⁢(δ))≲h32⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).

The asserted estimate follows from Theorem 148 (a-priori estimate). ∎

In addition, we follow [OS16] to deduce a rate of convergence for ‖∇γ(\wu−U)‖L2⁢(γ). {corollary}[rate of convergence on γ] Under the assumptions of Theorem 148 we have

‖∇γ(u~−U)‖L2⁢(γ)≲h⁢‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ).
Proof.

We recall the scaled trace inequality (117): for a bulk triangulation 𝒯 there exists a constant C only depending on the mesh shape regularity constant of 𝒯 such that for T∈𝒯δ and \tv∈H1⁢(T), one has

‖\tv‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2≤C⁢(hT−1⁢‖\tv‖L2⁢(T)2+hT⁢‖∇\tv‖L2⁢(T)2),

where hT=diam⁢(T). We apply this inequality with \tv=∇(u−U), and hT≈h sufficiently small, to obtain

‖∇(u−U)‖L2⁢(T∩γ)2≲(h−1⁢‖∇(u−U)‖L2⁢(T)2+h⁢|u|H2⁢(T)2).

Summing up over all T∈𝒯δ with non-empty intersection with γ, Proposition 3.3 (H2 extension) and Corollary 6.4 (rate of convergence in \Nhd) give

‖∇γ(u~−U)‖L2⁢(γ)≤‖∇(u−U)‖L2⁢(γ)≲h⁢|d|W∞2⁢(𝒩)⁢(‖\wf‖L2⁢(γ)+|\wu|H2⁢(γ)).

The desired estimate follows from Lemma 19 (regularity). ∎
